PARA.EMPHASIS: House of Representatives reasons for disagreeing to Senate amendments—

BREAK.PARA: The Senate Amendments seek to impose the beer rate of excise to any product in the National Food Authority Standard P 5. The House of Representatives considers that the effect of this amendment will be twofold on alcoholic beverages in the P5 category with an alcoholic content of less than 5 per cent:
. the rate of excise on spirit based pre‐mixed drinks in the P5 category will fall from $36.99 per litre of alcohol to $ 15.89 per litre of alcohol; and
. for the first time, excise will be imposed on other alcoholic products in the P5 category not currently subject to excise.

The House of Representatives considers that it is the intention of the Senate amendment to reduce the disparity in the taxation of alcoholic products by reducing the excise payable on highly taxed spirit based products and impose for the first time excise on currently excise free beverages.

The House of Representatives remains of the view that the Bill as originally introduced is necessary as a result of a decision by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, which may have had the effect of removing excise from previously excisable products.
The intention of the original Bill was to maintain the status quo in relation to the excise status of alcoholic beverages, by ensuring they continue to be taxed according to their alcoholic base.
Motion (by Senator Parer) proposed:
That the committee does not insist upon its amendments to which the House of Representatives has disagreed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion before the Senate, as we have just heard, is that the Senate does not insist upon its amendments. The amendments moved by Senator Margetts and supported by the ALP do seek to improve the taxation regime applying to some alcohol products. The ALP supported the amendments in order to demonstrate that whilst we are staunch opponents of the GST we are not opposed to sensible taxation reform.

SPEECH.PARA: The taxation regime that applies in Australia for alcoholic products is clearly something that needs to be reviewed. There is a very great variation between the rate of excise that applies to various alcoholic products. Add to this the differing rates of wholesale sales tax that also apply, and the resultant system is in need of review and reform. I do not say here what the precise outcome should be, but fairer competition between producers and a better deal for consumers are clearly two important objectives.

The Greens (WA) amendment sought to partially address this issue by introducing a new system of excise to apply to ready‐to‐drink mixed spirit beverages. The amendment had two aspects: firstly, to broaden the coverage of excise to include beverages using fermented alcohol as well as distilled alcohol as a base, and, secondly, to alter the rate of excise payable on these premixed beverages, that is, those beverages covered by food standard P5, to equate the level of tax for those drinks under five per cent alcohol content with the lower rate of tax applicable to beer. This would have broadened the base and lowered the rate, supposedly the rationale being followed by the government in the tax reform process, but it has been rejected out of hand by the government.

The amendment would have closed a loophole in the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1997 to stop changes in production methods to avoid tax. It would have given a strong incentive for these beverages to be reduced in alcoholic content below five per cent, thereby reducing the aggregate consumption of alcohol with obvious health and other social benefits hopefully flowing from that. Most importantly, it would have given a great boost to consumers in the form of lower prices on some drinks. It is a policy position which the ALP still supports.

BREAK.PARA: However, if the Senate insists upon the amendment, we have the prospect of the government not accepting the amendment and therefore not proceeding with this bill. This would mean that all these beverages would completely escape excise, confirmed in the sub ZERO case, which would produce a huge windfall for the producers and further distort the taxation of alcoholic products. Accordingly, therefore, the opposition supports this bill and will not jeopardise passage of the bill by insisting upon the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —The Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1997 is a bill about competing interests. Effectively, there has been special treatment of designer drinks because they are not traditional alcoholic drinks. Traditionally, alcoholic drinks have been made by fermenting some sort of vegetable product: hops, rye, wheat, rice, grapes, apples, sugarcane, honey, dandelions, elderberry or rhubarb. Sometimes that fermented product has been used directly, sometimes it has been distilled. In either case, the resulting product is one which partakes of the essence of the seed or fruit from which it is made.

SPEECH.PARA: It is the hops and the water and the way fermentation occurs which gives beer its flavour. Rhubarb wine is very nice, I have to say. It is the grapes, with all the variability of the soil, the weather for the year, the type of grape, and so on which determines the taste of wine. The same sorts of factors determine the taste of good rums, whiskies or bourbons.

Basically, fermented drinks include cider, mead, wine and beer. Spirits are distilled drinks. These are commonly understood terms. Fermented drinks are usually drunk as they are. Spirits are sometimes drunk neat or on ice but can also be mixed with cola, soda, and so on and possibly with other spirits to form cocktails. Nonetheless, the flavour of these drinks is often dependent on the flavour of the spirits added. The new class of drinks is a product of mixing alcohol from which virtually all taste is extracted into what is essentially soft drink or water.

Alcoholic soda, alcoholic cola and alcoholic lemonade are not drinks on classical lines. The source of alcohol does not matter; the point is to create a soda or spring water that will make someone drunk. `The stronger the better' seems to be something of a motto, and many of these drinks are fairly strong. At around 5.5 per cent alcohol, they are therefore stronger than most beer and most common cider. For example, Carlton Cold is 4.9 per cent and Strongbow Dry is 4.7 per cent alcohol content.

I am not talking about the high strength ciders like e33 that have come out with the designer drinks.I think there is some argument to be made that these new high potency ciders have come out because of the designer drinks. These new drinks, with their taste completely independent of the alcohol they use, can use alcohol from virtually any source. They can use alcohol from the making of light beer. They can use alcohol from wine or from cider. They are not adding wine or cider or beer to cola; they are adding alcohol that has been purged of its taste. Since they can use alcohol from any source, the differing tax regimes for various sources will play a major part in determining that source.

Until recently, the government attempted to tax these drinks as spirits. That does not make a lot of sense, particularly when they contain no quantity of what is commonly defined as spirits. The courts agreed that they were not spirits. The government sought to redefine spirits to be anything with alcohol from a distilled source. The industry changed sources. The outcome is that tax will remain minimal, with some companies able to avoid paying a large part of tax.

Our amendment was designed to allow these drinks, plus the premixed drinks, to be taxed under a single regime. This also addresses the pressures that have led the makers of premixed spirits to start mixing only traces of true spirits to high quantities of fermented alcohol. Lemon Ruski is a good example: one per cent real vodka is mixed with 4.5 per cent wine sourced alcohol. This is not mixed wine, since all wine flavour was removed to allow it to be marketed as ersatz vodka. I have not tasted it, but I have been told it does not taste much like vodka. It manages to fit into the least tax regime for alcoholic drinks. Likewise, Bundaberg is considering changing their premixed drinks to drinks using alcohol primarily sourced in non‐spirits with a lashing of spirits so they can say it has some in there.

Is this what the government is aiming for? Our amendment, in treating the class of designer and premixed drinks identically, makes source of alcohol irrelevant, unless a drink is a wine, a beer, a cider or a spirit. Manufacturers can then use the alcohol which is cheapest and sourced closest. I imagine that the beer companies will go back to using the alcohol they generate from making light beer, regardless of how that alcohol is extracted. Bundaberg can go back to using rum. The industry will have to stop chopping and changing to address new tax regimes which leave loopholes.

The point is that the tax regime has resulted, and is resulting, in a situation where the industry keeps changing. Whatever calculations may be made about loss of revenue based on the current amount of premixed drinks cannot be based on current production and consumption patterns. Manufacturers are changing production and pushing for consumers to move to their new products. In a couple of years, we will see most premixed drinks made from designer alcohols. The government will lose this revenue anyway. If the government does not change the taxation regime to something like the Greens' model, it will lose even more because the manufacturers will go for the loopholes the government has left.

Once you have a classification such as P5, you can tax these drinks under that. You can argue that lemon Ruski is not wine, no matter where the alcohol comes from, and commonsense and ordinary usage of words are on your side. If you do not, you need to say that lemon Ruski is 82 per cent wine and eight per cent spirits. You certainly cannot claim that it is all spirits if it is made from fermented grape alcohol under the current regime or under the proposed government regime.

So you are left with the government arguing against commonsense that lemon Ruski is 82 per cent wine, otherwise there is no regime at all under which it can be taxed. How long will it be before there is an AAT challenge that says it is not `wine' on the ordinary usage of the word? The government will lose on the same basis as it lost on `spirit'. At that point we will see the government coming back and probably trying to redefine `wine' to mean `any fermented product'. What does that do to the definition of wine? What does that do to the useful time spent in this chamber?

There is no way you can juggle the current definitions of traditional drinks to cover, in any consistent way, what is happening in the alcoholic drink industry. What is needed is a new classification under which these drinks, and any new hybrid or mixed alcoholic drinks, clearly fit. Personally, I think the P5 standard works. If you want to create some other definition for mixed drinks other than `wine coolers', fine, but it will not work to try to fiddle with the definitions of traditional drinks—wine, beer, cider and spirits—to try to bring these new drinks under one or more of the new regimes. They are not really like traditional drinks, and the changes in the drink market need to be addressed through the creation of a new category.

The amendment the Senate passed has an advantage beyond creating a category under which the new drinks can be taxed. This advantage is that there is a two-step regime—progressive taxation based on alcohol content. What we said is that where a drink contains less than five per cent alcohol it should be taxed at the beer rate. Currently, a number of the designer drinks, and most of the premixed spirit drinks, are above that. Therefore, they would be taxed at the spirit rate, not because they are spirits but because they are P5 and of higher alcohol content which is similar to premixed spirit drinks.

I think one of the big outcomes will be that many makers of designer drinks will bring the alcohol content down. Since these drinks are mainly marketed to young people, I think that would be a good thing. It is socially worth while, and I understand that about 80 per cent of the premixed drinks would also be brought down below five per cent. I think that is a good thing too, and I do not buy the argument that in the interests of tax revenue people should drink more alcohol. Revenue is not the bottom line. We need to consider the social impacts of what we are doing. This is why I was arguing in relation to the `Charter of Budget Dishonesty Bill'. The budget bottom line is not the only criteria on which we should be making policy. It certainly is one factor, but I do not see it as the prime factor. Funnily enough, I think we have some other values in our society.

In respect of the social factors, I would like to point out that Peter Holland, of 6WF in Perth, interviewed Chris MacDonald of the Western Australian Institute of Alcohol and Other Drugs. During the interview, Mr MacDonald said:
Some research a while back indicated that when people over 18 were asked how often they drank those drinks—
that is, designer colas and soft drinks with alcohol—
it was only about 3‐5% of the drinking population who drank them. So primarily they were people who were under the age of 18 who appeared to be drinking them.

Whether or not this research was accurate, there is no doubt that the market for these drinks is certainly for people under 30, and mainly for those under 25. I would say that the younger the drinker the more likely they are to be drinking these drinks. In such a case, I cannot understand why they should be higher in alcohol content than beer or traditional cider. We are not only encouraging young people to drink but to drink strong drinks. This is the basis for the support the Senate amendment has attracted from health organisations concerned with substance abuse. Mr MacDonald went on to make this point:
I don't necessarily want to see increases in prices for consumers, but we know that young people are very price sensitive, more than any other group, any other consumer group.
In talking of some research on price impacts, he said this about the research:

. . . talked about if the price of a 6 pack of beer was raised by 20 or 30 cents, it would have the impact on young people, the equivalent effect of raising the drinking age by 1 year in terms of the amount of alcohol that was consumed.

These are some of the factors behind the health non-government organisations supporting the Senate amendment. Of course, this means less gross domestic product and less tax, but that simply highlights the fact that gross domestic product and tax revenue are not indicators of social good. It also highlights the fact that the true cost benefit is not considered. Reduced youth alcohol consumption would result in less crime, less road accidents and road trauma, and less trouble for young people with the police. What does that cost on an annual basis? All of that translates into savings in economic terms, although all of these reduce gross domestic product. They are added in in terms of work that is done but the actual social cost is not taken away from the gross domestic product.

We have heard today that the Labor Party is not going to insist on the Senate's amendments. Senator Cook has indicated that the reason for that is that the government may withdraw the bill and not get any revenue at all. I think that would be ludicrous action on behalf of the government. I believe there are very narrow interests being represented here, and I believe the government has created for itself a further headache. There is no doubt about the fact that the government would deserve censure for the time that would be taken up in the chamber debating these headaches that it will continue to create in the future.

The Labor Party is taking this attitude: we have given the government the chance to adopt reasonable legislation. If it stubbornly refuses to do so, it is not the job of the Senate to fix up the bad legislation of government. I have to say I differ on this. I think fixing poor legislation is exactly our job. That is the function of this place. We are not just here to make political points. It is the function of the Senate far more than the function of the House of Representatives which, because of numbers and party discipline, has no capacity to affect legislation at all and can only be a forum for political point scoring. The Senate, happily, has more voting power than that, which is why debate here is often more considered, frequently more polite and more to the point. The Greens will insist on our amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —For the reasons that have just been outlined by Senator Margetts, I initially voted for her amendments to the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1997 . I have always been one to believe that the decision of the government should have as its base the excisability on the level of alcohol content rather than the derivation of the manufacture of the drinks, whether that is fermentation or distillation. I have strongly been of that opinion for many years. I was pleased when Senator Margetts moved her amendments when the bill was first before us and I was very happy to support them.

SPEECH.PARA: The bill, as has been acknowledged I think pretty well around the chamber, ensures that the proportion of a beverage that is distilled alcohol will be subject to excise. The taxation of beverages in the P5 food standards is anomalous and this bill presents an opportunity to correct that. That opportunity was grasped by the amendments. Producers will simply substitute fermented alcohol for distilled alcohol, eroding collections by the Commonwealth. The high alcohol content drinks based on fermented alcohol will continue to be non-excisable and, as indicated by Senator Margetts, will be more attractive to young people.

The government, however, is insisting upon its legislation. I would like to raise with the minister a point made by the Senate Economics Legislation Committee in its consideration of the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1997 . Page 12 of that report states:
1) THE COMMITTEE RECOMMENDS that the bill be passed.
2) . . . the Committee agrees that any loophole in the principal legislation that allowed a class of alcoholic beverage to escape the revenue net should be closed.

However the Committee noted a number of serious concerns raised by the industry about differing tax treatments of alcohol according to the production method used. This tax treatment also has social consequences as set out earlier in the report. The committee recommends that these matters should be the subject of an immediate review by government and that a review should look at the equity of tax treatment between RTD products and designer drinks in the P5 category particular reference to:
a) the social effect on consumption patterns caused by the differential taxation treatment according to the production method of the alcohol;
b) Potential loss of government revenue with a change to the use of different forms of alcohol (other than distilled spirits) in RTD products; and
c) The possibility of introducing common taxation treatment for RTD products with an alcohol content of 5% or less and those above 5%.

I want to know—and I am sure you, Mr Temporary Chairman Ferguson, being the distinguished Chairman of the Senate Economics Legislation Committee would like to know—precisely what the government is going to do about those recommendations if it is going to insist upon its bill. I heard Senator Murray interject a while ago, `What is it going to do about the recommendations that have emerged from that committee?' I think we would all be very interested in this if the government is going insist upon its bill and reject the amendments that have been put forward by Senator Margetts and adopted, might I say, by the chamber.

That leads me to my final point. Senator Cook indicated that the Labor Party still supports the amendments that were adopted by the Senate, but he seemed to indicate that the Labor Party would not support them now because it was concerned that the government might drop the whole legislation and thus forgo a considerable amount of excise tax. I have been here for 22 years and that is the first time I have heard that argument put forward for actions—`because the government might forgo some tax'. I really cannot recall the last time the government had forgone tax of whatever complexion. If it chose to do so, it would be because it did trumpet it as an election commitment or something of that order.

I just simply wish to advise the committee that I am opposing the motion proposed by the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Parer) on behalf of the government. I am supporting the bill as it was amended by the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —There are three issues, which have been well expressed by Senators Margetts and Harradine. The first issue is that of economics. If we as a chamber accede to the government's motion to reject our own amendments, then we will be encouraging imports, we will be encouraging substitution and we will be encouraging a worse position for Australia than we would enjoy if the amendments were passed. Secondly, the encouragement of the amendments to push the alcohol level for measured drinks, ready-to-drink drinks, below five per cent is an extremely useful social mechanism. It is one the government has spurned and spurned wrongly. The third issue is that of imposing an excise on alcoholic products which are presently excise free. Excuse us for being consistent here: isn't the purpose of having an excise on alcoholic drinks that they should be consistent, that they should be applied and that they should contribute to a measure of price stability and to a measure of certainty in the consumption of alcoholic products?

SPEECH.PARA: I note that we have a new minister in this portfolio in the other House, the Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs (Mr Truss). When the minister presented the reasons from the Committee of Reasons—that sounds an interesting committee—he said:
The committee has worked very quickly. On behalf of the committee appointed to draw up reasons for the House disagreeing to the amendments of the Senate . . .

I for one wish that they had worked a bit slower. I am not convinced that they have had good advice or that they have really come to grips with the issues which were very well worked through by our Senate Economics Legislation Committee—of which you, Mr Temporary Chairman Ferguson, are the distinguished chairman and, might I say, a very good chair. One of the two recommendations made by our committee was unanimously supported. In other words, senators from the National Party, the Liberal Party, the Independents, the two Greens, the Australian Democrats and the Labor Party who were members of the committee agreed on the matter. But, no, the executive and Customs in their wisdom do not like unanimous agreement on issues from the Senate.

As it stands, the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 1), fails to rectify a tax anomaly which is perpetuating the growth in designer drinks that do not incur any excise duty—and that will be the consequence. The taxation of beverages in the P5 category is anomalous. The government simply want to ensure that the proportion of a beverage composed of distilled alcohol be made subject to excise and to leave off the issue of fermented alcohol. They want to do this even though their bill will provide a competitive advantage in terms of excise duties for ready-to-drink products containing fermented alcohol as distinct from distilled alcohol.

For those of you who have never had a drop of alcohol touch their lips—and I am sure there must be a few in the chamber—I will remind you that distilled alcohol has the very same physiological effect as does fermented alcohol. It is a remarkable feature but it is true. Quite frankly, it is foolish to have different rates of excise for these two kinds of alcohol.

Evidence has been presented to the committee showing that many drinks of this type, which are already on the market, are imported from New Zealand. I am sure it is very helpful to our neighbours for us to encourage more imports from New Zealand, but I thought our balance of trade was something that we should pay attention to. In a small measure, Senator Margetts's amendments did deliver a helpful kick along to our balance of trade in this area but, no, the government would prefer to encourage the imports from New Zealand.

Domestic manufacturers, such as the distillers, who appeared before the committee told us on oath that they will be encouraged to substitute fermented alcohol for distilled alcohol in so-called ready‐to‐drink or premixed beverages in order to minimise tax. Because those manufacturers do not have brewing facilities at their plants, they will be encouraged to import fermented products from overseas. In time, this will have a negative impact on Australian investment and will result in significant revenue losses. We were advised that, if substitution occurs, we could face a revenue loss—as a result of this motion moved by the minister—of about $30 million over the next three years.

Then there is the failure to impose an incentive to lower alcohol beverages. The issue is of significant concern to health and community organisations, a number of whom made submissions to the Senate committee inquiry on this point. Those of you who have been in the chamber longer than I have will know that a number of those organisations have consistently pursued this theme in previous committee reports on these matters. They want drinks taxed progressively in accordance with their level of alcohol and not in accordance with the method of production. It does not matter a row of beans to anyone who is consuming alcohol whether it comes from distilled or fermented alcohol. What matters is the effect. That is what health and community organisations attend to and that is what Senator Margetts's amendments attended to. Those organisations saw the amendments as important from a health perspective because it would encourage moderate and responsible alcohol consumption.

Only one industry player has come back to complain about the Senate's amendments and, unfortunately, that one industry player looms far too large in the government's consideration of this matter. The government should have ignored that industry player and done the right thing. I regret that Customs has given bad advice on this matter to the minister or, alternatively, that the minister has ignored good advice and has decided to insist on the bill as it was previously put.

We all thought Senator Margetts's amendments were helpful on issues of revenue, public policy, health and economics. Accordingly, the Australian Democrats record that they will continue to insist on the amendments and to oppose the minister's motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their contributions. The original purpose—and it is still the purpose—of the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1997 is to amend the Excise Tariff Act 1921 to ensure the continuing excisability of all beverages which contain distilled alcohol, including spirits, regardless of their alcohol content.

SPEECH.PARA: In November 1994, Carlton and United Breweries commenced the manufacture of the product known as Subzero, an alcoholic soda which had an alcohol content of approximately 5.5 per cent. The Australian Customs Service considered Subzero excisable under subitem 2(H) of the schedule to the Excise Tariff Act as a spirituous beverage. Carlton and United Breweries appealed the decision of the ACS to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

On 7 June 1996, the AAT determined that the product Subzero had such a low alcohol content by volume that it could not be described as spirituous and was, therefore, non‐excisable under subitem 2(H). The decision was based on what the AAT considered is commonly regarded as the definition of `spirit' in the community—that is, a strong alcoholic liquor, usually containing not less than 37 per cent alcohol by volume. The matter is still subject to appeal to the full Federal Court.

In its original form, the bill sought to amend the Excise Tariff Act 1921, in effect to maintain the status quo with the legislation. The Senate amendments seek to impose the beer rate of excise on any product in the National Food Authority's standard P5. This amendment will have a twofold effect on alcoholic beverages in the P5 category with an alcohol content of less than five per cent.

The rate of excise on spirit based premixed drinks in the P5 category will fall from $36.99 per litre of alcohol, to $15.89 per litre of alcohol. For the first time, excise will be imposed on other alcoholic products in the P5 category not currently subject to excise. It is apparent that the intention of the Senate amendments is to reduce the disparity in the taxation of alcoholic products by reducing the excise payable on highly taxed spirit based products and, for the first time, to impose excise on currently excise‐free beverages.

The government remains of the view that the bill as originally introduced should not be amended. I note that the ALP will not insist on the amendments. I also note that in Senator Harradine's contribution he raised the point that the committee report had agreed that any loopholes should be closed. This also basically supports the view taken to some degree by Senator Cook and to a wider degree by the government, in that we recognise that the whole taxation regime should be reviewed.

One of the reasons we recognise that should happen—and I think the general public at large wants that to happen—is that, to a large extent, much of the taxation act, apart from being complicated, is illogical. In response to Senator Harradine, I say that I will draw to the attention of the Treasurer (Mr Costello) that the matter raised in the committee report should be part of the overall review of taxation that the government is undertaking.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for his comments. I agree that much of the tax act is illogical. The Greens (WA) were endeavouring to create some logic, especially in the handling of alcoholic drinks, to make it simpler for industry to follow. The vast majority of the members of the industry—not just the non‐government organisations which are concerned about the health and social impacts of the current regime—apart from one very large player, believe that it was good to know exactly what they are dealing with and not have to have a situation where, to compete, they had to swap their sources of alcohol.

SPEECH.PARA: We are dealing with a case where numerically they might be financially influential—perhaps analogous to whether or not you are a financially rich nursing home proprietor—not large in numbers, but perhaps large in influence. With a product like Subzero—a product of Carlton and United Breweries—which is currently fermented from sugar, can the minister tell me what excise is currently payable on that product?

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer is zero.

—How can the government justify a situation where a product of this nature from a particular industry is basically exempt from tax? Where is the fairness and equity? For all those people who have, for instance, had money taken from nursing homes and health and so on, what is the fairness of a handout from the taxpayer of tens of millions of dollars to big players in the alcohol industry?

—The response I gave you earlier reflected the attitude of the government. If you look at the tax act, going back over many years, one of the problems, and one of the reasons for its complexity and illogicality, is that ad hoc decisions have been made on it. The aim of this government, as stated quite openly by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) on a number of occasions, is to have a total review of the taxation act.
—I have one more question of clarification. If our amendments were passed, at what rate would Subzero be taxed? What excise would be payable on it?
—If it is above five per cent, it would be taxed at the rate of $36.99. Below five per cent, it would be at the beer rate, which is $15.89.

SPEECH.PARA: The committee recommends that these matters should be the subject of an immediate review by government and that a review should look at the equity of tax treatment between RTD products and designer drinks in the P5 category [with] particular reference to:

The possibility of introducing common taxation treatment for RTD products with an alcohol content of 5% or less and those above 5%.

One of the problems with our current taxation act is that it suffers from a lot of disadvantages, hence the reason for the overall review. I think that is about all I can say to you on that.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Consideration of House of Representatives Message

PARA.EMPHASIS: House of Representatives reasons for disagreeing to Senate amendments—

PROCTEXT.PARA: . The House of Representatives considers this Amendment—to broaden the principles of sound fiscal management to include: the achievement of full employment in Australia; the overall economic prosperity and welfare of the people of Australia; and maintenance of real wages and conditions—should not proceed. It is unnecessary as these issues are already, and more appropriately, covered in Clause 4 of the Bill. That clause provides that fiscal policy should be directed to maintain the on‐going economic prosperity and welfare of the people of Australia.

. This Amendment requires the annual preparation of a report by the Secretary to the Treasury and the Commissioner of Taxation on material threats to the integrity of the tax system, including the fiscal impact of such threats and specific action necessary to counter these threats. The House of Representatives considers that this Amendment should not proceed, as it would draw the attention of tax planners to weaknesses and anomalies in tax legislation, risking larger losses in revenue than would otherwise be the case. Moreover, Clause 12 of the Bill already requires that material threats to the fiscal outlook, quantified where feasible, be outlined in a Statement of Risks.

. The House of Representatives considers that this Amendment—which requires an intergenerational report to be produced within three years after the commencement of the Act and thereafter within three years of the public release of the preceding report—should not proceed.

The House of Representatives considers that it is not appropriate to require the release of reports at a greater frequency than five years, as assessments of the long term sustainability of policy are unlikely to change quickly. Assessments in an intergenerational report will be more affected by factors such as demographic change and Australia's long term growth potential, rather than short-term budgetary and economic developments. The House of Representatives notes that the Bill only prescribes a minimum reporting frequency and that does not prevent governments from releasing reports more frequently if appropriate.

. This Amendment requires responsible Secretaries to jointly release a pre-election economic and fiscal outlook report two years and nine months after the first sitting day of the House of Representatives following the previous election. If an election is called before then, a pre-election economic and fiscal outlook report would be required within five days of the issue of writs for a general election.

The House of Representatives considers this Amendment should not proceed. In the case where a report is produced two years and nine months after the first sitting following an election, the Amendment could allow economic and fiscal developments in the subsequent months prior to an election announcement to go unreported. This would be inconsistent with providing up to date information on the economic and fiscal outlook to the electorate prior to an elec tion. In the case where an earlier election is called, the House of Representatives considers that a requirement for a pre-election economic and fiscal outlook report to be produced within five days of the issue of writs is impractical. A minimum period of ten days is required for a report to be produced.

. The House of Representatives considers that this Amendment—requiring Ministers to not participate in the pre-election economic and fiscal outlook report other than to provide needed information—should not proceed. The Amendment is not necessary as the Bill already requires that the Treasury and Finance Secretaries must sign off on the report stating that it reflects the best professional judgement of officers of their Departments.

. These Amendments will allow the possibility of the Departments of the Treasury and Finance costing unannounced policies for the Government and Opposition in the caretaker period prior to an election. Further, the Amendments allow for the making of requests for costings by the Leader of the Opposition to be authorised by the Prime Minister, but that the details of the policies being costed need not be disclosed to the Prime Minister. They also provide that the details of policies, which are the subject of a request by the Leader of the Opposition, shall not be disclosed by the Secretaries of the Departments of Treasury and Finance to anyone not authorised by the Leader of the Opposition. The Secretaries may decline to prepare costings under any request where they consider that policy advice is being sought.

The House of Representatives does not consider that these Amendments should proceed. The Amendments will result in the loss of transparency in the costing process. The lack of transparency under the Amendments is also inconsistent with Clause 31 of the Bill. This Clause requires that all policy costings are made public by the Secretaries of the Departments of Treasury and Finance as soon as practicable before polling day.

As the requests for the costing of unannounced policies would be permitted, requests could be made for a range of alternative policy options to be costed. The House of Representatives considers that this risks placing the Departments of Treasury and Finance in the position of developing policy for the Opposition, inconsistent with usual conventions. It could also add substantially to the workload of Departments, which could be required to cost a myriad of alternative options.

. This Amendment requires that policy costings must indicate what assumptions have been used and explain any limitations on the methodology used. The House of Representatives considers that this Amendment is unnecessary as costing guidelines issued by Secretaries of the Departments of the Treasury and Finance for the preparation of policy costings (provided for in subclause 30(1)) would detail such processes.
Motion (by Senator Kemp) proposed:
That the committee does not insist upon its amendments to which the House of Representatives has disagreed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to say immediately that the Charter of Budget Honesty Bill has been misnamed. If the government insists that this bill not pass, it would have to be renamed, to be consistent, the Charter of Budget Dishonesty Bill. It would produce an outcome which would dishonestly represent what the true position was to the taxpayers and voters of Australia. This motion, that the government does not oppose the sensible amendments agreed to by the Senate, has therefore got to be seen as a political stunt. Contrary to the opposition, the government does not want to entrench a superior system of accountability within this legislation. It just wants the appearance of reform, not the fact of reform.

SPEECH.PARA: The first point to make in considering the Senate amendments is that the government also succeeded in stopping two very important amendments that would have improved the legislation even further. Let me mention what they were. The first is the requirement that the charter be legally binding. This legislation is not enforceable through the courts. In addition, there are no penalties for non‐compliance. The Senate attempted to make the charter enforceable but the government refused to accept that position. The government has insisted that this charter is, in fact, an optional charter. It is an optional charter of budget honesty, which makes a farce of the government's rhetoric in this area. In making this point on this very subject, I acknowledge the contribution of Senator Andrew Murray who has also made this point, often with greater force than I have. Nonetheless, I endorse it entirely.

BREAK.PARA: The second unsuccessful amendment in the Senate was our proposal for the budget documents to contain an estimate of the effect of budget measures on national savings. The Treasurer (Mr Costello) has repeatedly told us—and it has been repeated here in the Senate—that the overriding objective of budget policy is to increase the level of national savings. Surely, in legislation that is supposed to improve budget transparency, it is not unreasonable that the government be asked to attempt to quantify the effect of its budget in achieving a key objective.

However, the government succeeded in excluding this key measure from the legislation. You could ask the question: what are they afraid of? Labor is perfectly happy to have such information included in budget documentation. Why is the government so opposed to such a fundamental proposition? What is the Treasurer so afraid of? Why shouldn't the public be able to know what the effects of the budget are on national savings? And why shouldn't the Treasurer be held accountable for whatever targets are included? It has to be said that the government has no answers to these questions, and hence has no credibility at all in this debate.

There are 10 amendments that the Senate carried to this bill, and I want to say a few things about them. Amendment No. 1 is fundamentally important in terms of the objectives of the government. The opposition believes that fiscal policy should be directed to worthwhile community goals; it should not be just about accounting outcomes. Why do governments set fiscal objectives? They do so—or they should do so—to ensure that their broader objectives can be achieved.

Senate amendment No. 1 proposes to add to the principles of sound fiscal management in clause 5. We consider that, at a minimum, two further paragraphs should be added to these principles. The amendment requires the government to have regard to, firstly, the achievement of full employment in Australia and, secondly, the overall economic prosperity of the welfare of the people of Australia.

I might say that a charter of budget honesty should bring out the implications of economic policy for the people of Australia at election time. Clearly, the electors want to know, among other things, how it will impact on the achievement of full employment. Joe Blow, the elector out there, will want to know that. He will also want to know how the budgetary situation and the promises made by the contending parties impact on the overall economic prosperity of the welfare of the people of Australia.

To exclude them is to deny access to that knowledge through this process by the electors. It seems to me to be an exercise in misinformation rather than about transparency, which this is supposed to be about. Many people will recognise that the principles I have mentioned are contained within the Reserve Bank legislation, which the bank must take into account in the conduct of monetary policy in Australia.

They also add a humanising element to the principles of sound fiscal management rather than there being a narrowly focused fixation on the bottom line and accounting standards, as the bill currently contains. It is not merely appropriate that a statement of principles of fiscal management simply addresses the accounting criteria; it should also recognise that the application of fiscal management techniques has a very real impact on the lives and welfare of people. That is the fundamental point here: putting up a set of accounting outcomes but not explaining what they mean to human beings is a sterile exercise.

For people's welfare to be enhanced and for their prosperity to increase, there has to be a focus on the achievement of full employment and on the economic wellbeing of Australians. The pursuit of better employment outcomes should be the key priority of the government. Unfortunately, we know that this has not been the case—or, if it has been, the government has been a woeful failure.

The record since the last budget continues this awful trend. Let me give you some figures. The Australian economy has actually lost around 4,500 full‐time jobs since budget time—that is, we have not even stayed still on the jobs front; Australia has actually gone backwards. The government created an employment committee of cabinet to supposedly focus policy on employment. That has to be marked down as a spectacular failure.

These amendments seek to compel the government to focus on national welfare, which they are obviously not doing at the moment. I regard it as unbelievable that the government will not accept this amendment; to do so indicates that they do not support improved employment and national welfare outcomes. That was a fundamental amendment of ours that the Senate carried which the government now want to turn over. That is a very important reason why we will not support the motion.

Let me turn to the second amendment the Senate carried, which was a very important amendment. One hopes that this will have the unanimous support again of the Senate. The integrity of the tax base is fundamental to the delivery of adequate public services. Taxes are necessary to finance public services, and these are most fairly raised when everyone so able to contributes to them. Ensuring the integrity of the tax base is therefore crucial to ensure that all taxpayers are paying their fair share. The second amendment the Senate made requires the Commissioner of Taxation and the Secretary to the Treasury to provide a report on any material threats to the integrity of the tax system, including the fiscal impact of any of those threats, as a permanent and integral part of fiscal reporting.

It is a very important proposal because it will allow the government, and especially the Treasurer, to be held accountable for the conduct of tax policy. The opposition believes that there can be few duties of higher importance to the Treasurer than maintaining a fair tax system. Critical to that is that the current tax base be maintained. We are concerned to ensure that the revenue involved is made public to enable scrutiny of the Treasurer's performance in his duty of protecting the public revenue.

The tax commissioner can advise the Treasurer on matters that should be undertaken to maintain the tax base, but he has no power to force the Treasurer to act in the national interest. The discretion is all with the Treasurer to either accept or reject the advice of the tax office and the Treasury, all in comfortable secrecy. By this amendment we do not seek to alter the Treasurer's right to make tax policy on behalf of the government, but we do seek to ensure that material threats to the taxation system are codified in a systematic public basis so as to enable the performance of the Treasurer, in dealing with these revenue threats, to be openly evaluated.

Future Treasurers will still be able to refuse to act on the advice of the revenue authorities, but they will not be able to hide their actions, or lack of action, from the Australian people. Clause 12 of schedule 1 is currently worded to include only some references to the sorts of risks that may have a material effect on the fiscal outlook. There is no explicit reference to particular threats proposed to fiscal outcomes due to the integrity of the tax system coming under sustained attack.

When this was last debated in the Senate—and I am pleased that he is here representing the government—Senator Kemp made two ludicrous claims: firstly, that the few pages of information in the statement of risks in Budget Paper No. 1 actually cover the issue. That is rubbish. What we envisage is that this independent statement by the bureaucrats will provide much more detail on specific schemes and issues which will complement the broad information already provided. Secondly, through you, Mr Temporary Chairman: Senator Kemp, you made the ludicrous proposal that the publication of information about schemes or other threats to the tax base will in fact increase their use. As I recall, you put out a press release on this point.

The tax office does not dream up theoretical schemes. The tax office and Treasury detect taxpayer behaviour, often many years after it has become established practice, and then advise the government of the problem and the possible solutions. It is simply wrong to suggest that the tax office could advise the taxation industry on ways to avoid tax; the contrary is the case. If this principle were correct then the tax office should never take any taxpayers to court.

TALK.START.PARA: —From Mr R&D syndicates, it is pathetic.

—I advise you, Mr Assistant Treasurer, through you, Mr Temporary Chairman, to listen to this point. If your principle was correct then the tax office should never take anyone to court, on the basis that a loss in the courts would alert taxpayers to possible schemes. Clearly that is utterly at odds with current practice. What we do know though is that the tax system, under threat to its integrity, suffers constant and sustained attack. In some instances this is a direct result of government legislation opening up loop‐holes such as the family trust losses changes which were debated last week. In other cases it arises through a lack of action on tax avoidance; through allowing such things as salary repackaging by senior public servants. As we believe that risks to the integrity of the tax system will always exist, the opposition is convinced that one way of ensuring that these are properly dealt with by the Treasurer is to ensure that the government can be held accountable for inaction. This amendment achieves that goal.

BREAK.PARA: Let me turn now to amendment No. 3. This amendment changes the frequency of the intergenerational fiscal reports from five years to three years. It was moved by the Democrats but was supported by Labor. This sensible reform ensures that there will be such a report during every normal term of parliament. This reporting framework of three years aligns with the other long‐term fiscal report which is presented to this parliament, namely, the report by the Government Actuary into the long‐term costs of the Commonwealth civilian and military superannuation funds. These reports are prepared every three years and we consider this to be an appropriate interval for updated reports to be released.

Amendments Nos 4 and 5 seek to replace and improve the proposed provisions for a pre‐election economic and fiscal outlook report being published prior to an election. The bill proposes that, within 10 days of the issue of writs for an election, the responsible economic bureaucrats produce a report to inform the electorate of the fiscal and economic outlook after the election. The amendment proposes that, instead of waiting until an election is called, the report should be published two years and nine months after the first day of sitting of a new parliament or, if an election is called prior to that time, that the report be produced within five days and not 10.

The opposition moved this amendment for the very simple reason that, if a pre‐election economic and fiscal report is to be published, then for it to be useful and to contribute towards public debate in the context of an election campaign it needs to be timely and available as soon as the election is called. It should not just be used as a political tactic by the government of the day in order to advance its own political agenda.

I am going to run out of time to cover all of the amendments. I will not have time to conclude on 8, 9 and 10, but amendments Nos 6 and 7 involve minor rewriting of the proposed costings regime in the current bill and, in the opposition's view, involve some key and fundamental aspects of the costing regime proposed. They should go ahead. On amendment No. 8, we seek to amend the bill to remove from the Prime Minister the discretion, granted in clause 29 of the bill, to decline a request from the opposition for a costing to be made by the relevant departmental secretary, and to eliminate the proposal that the Prime Minister should be given a copy of the opposition policies. That is a fairly fundamental change.

In amendment No. 9 we add some new subclauses, 29(6) and 29(7), which will grant the responsible secretaries a discretion to decline to provide advice that would include policy advice. Amendment No. 10, the final amendment, again by the Democrats, is for the assumptions upon which costings have been made to be spelled out when a costing is provided. Again, we support that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not propose to speak for long because I think other senators will wish to join in this debate, but I want to quickly respond to what I would call a threshold comment that was made by Senator Cook.
—Aren't you going to listen to the rest of the debate before you respond? It doesn't make any sense.

—I am just going to respond to one thing that he said, then we will leave it. I will be very brief—mark my words, Senator. What was a fundamental error from Senator Cook was that the Charter of Budget Honesty is designed, of course, to ensure that governments are up‐front, as they were not prior to the last election, among other things with the fiscal position of the budget as it is when we go into an election period. It is in that sense a restriction on government.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not a bill which is designed to advantage government. If this advantaged governments, this bill would have been brought in decades ago. Failing that, it would certainly have been brought in by Senator Cook and his colleagues in a way before the last election. This bill does not advantage government. This bill is designed to, in a sense, place restrictions on government. What Senator Cook has done is to attempt to advantage the opposition out of this policy position; hence a number of the amendments which he referred to are designed essentially to benefit the opposition. We do not accept those.

This is an election promise. We went to an election on a charter of budget honesty. We believe that it is an important bill. We have canvassed extensively the wide range of issues in these amendments in this parliament, and I do not propose to go through them now, but it is important, in light of the comments by Senator Cook, to put on the record that this bill does not advantage government. This bill is designed to ensure greater transparency. Unlike Senator Cook, we welcome comments that Senator Murray has made on the importance of this bill. This bill has its genesis in the dishonesty of the previous government; in the dishonesty of Senator Cook and his colleagues before the last election.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Kemp, I think that comment is unparliamentary and I ask you to withdraw it.
—In the misleading approach of the former government.
—Senator Kemp, I have asked you to withdraw.

—I withdraw the comment and refer to the misleading approach of the previous government before the last election. There is no error which will echo more down the years, Senator Cook, while you are in this chamber, than the famous quote of yours in November 1995 when you indicated that the current budget was in surplus this year and next year without the addition of asset sales. No greater error—you made a $10 billion error—will echo down while you remain in this chamber and we will continue to remember it.

SPEECH.PARA: Frankly, in relation to your comments on tax avoidance, there is no doubt that the Taxation Office detects tax avoidance schemes. Clearly these schemes are marketed. The more they are publicised, the more people will be attracted to them. I would have thought that was a matter of logic. You, Senator Cook, with your attitude to R&D syndicates, do not come to this debate with clean hands. I will leave my comments there.

TALK.START.PARA: —I beg your pardon.
—With your attitude to R&D syndicates, you do not come to this debate with clean hands.
—That's a lie.
—Withdraw that comment.
—Senator Cook, I think that comment is unparliamentary and I would ask you to withdraw.
—I will withdraw, but I would ask the minister to withdraw his reflection on my character as well.

—What I said was that with your attitude to R&D syndicates you do not come to this debate with clean hands. It is an interesting point, I would have thought, and quite accurate as demonstrated by your attitude in the Hansard . Senator Cook, I know you are sensitive on this comment and the truth is that we can ascertain your attitude to R&D syndicates from the way you debated this when it was before the chamber. It therefore flows as a matter of logic that you do not come to the debate on tax avoidance with clean hands. I wanted to get a couple of those comments on the record, and I will listen with interest to the contributions by other senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I find the whole debate we have had on the Charter of Budget Honesty Bill extraordinary. If you recall me asking questions about things like the Uruguay Round of GATT and projections about what the benefits or otherwise would be of that, we had no real debate on that in this chamber—and there is still no real debate despite the fact that there are no actual benefits in our trade figures. It could be argued that our balance of payments is considerably worse as a result of the leap we have made into free trade.

SPEECH.PARA: Those kinds of things do not even figure in these kinds of equations. I call this a charter of budget dishonesty because it is largely a load of codswallop. It is about taking certain figures and it is about saying that these are the most important things when we make social policy, environment policy and just about any other policy.

I believe that it is being and will continue to be used dishonestly on many occasions to justify unconscionable decisions. That is why I oppose the moves to make this type of nonsense compulsory. The amendments which the government is throwing back are in fact amendments which I thought were acceptable. Therefore, I have no need to change the way I have voted on those. I still do not think the bill is much chop anyway, but I am prepared to continue to vote the same way I did the first time the bill was put to us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, I think that if what you would regard as the unthinkable happened—namely, that you were not re-elected at the next election—you would regret the opposition amendments not being passed and, indeed, our own amendments not being passed. I think you would also regret the Charter of Budget Honesty Bill not being enforceable. The National Party, along with the Australian Democrats, the two Greens, the Independents and the various Independents and parties in the House of Representatives, would regret that they have been left out of this cosy arrangement which you have got into whereby only you and the opposition would be subject to the costings available through this bill.

SPEECH.PARA: I have been so perplexed—and, as you would know, I disagree with Senator Margetts on this matter—by a bill coming to us which is unenforceable that I have had to ask you some questions on notice concerning it. Persons who have been in this chamber and in this parliament longer than I might be able to tell me, but I am not aware that there can be or should be an act which is incapable of being enforced. I draw the attention of senators in the chamber to page 27 of today's Notice Paper in which I have put questions on notice to the Minister Representing the Treasurer (Senator Kemp) concerning these matters. I want to know, out of all the hundreds—I presume it is thousands—of federal acts we have, how many are unenforceable and in which parts? I want to know what would happen if the Charter of Budget Honesty Act were not complied with. Would the minister say, `Whoops, terribly sorry, I was dishonest, but what can you do about it?'

I want to know how parliament and the public can enforce the act. I have also asked in those questions on notice for any advice as to the validity of the bill in the absence of enforceable rights or duties and whether a copy of that advice can be required. Minister, I remain perplexed on those matters. Having said that, I continue to be a very strong supporter of your bill. I am glad you have introduced it. But I must also indicate to you that I continue to be a very strong supporter of the amendments which were passed by the Senate on this matter. Nothing in the statement of reasons, nor in the remarks that have been made, incline me to change my mind. I do not think the government or the tax system or anybody will be disadvantaged by these amendments.

I freely acknowledge that the amendments do in fact advantage the opposition more than you intended, but I think that is right. If they are the alternative party of government, I think the public deserve to have their policies costed on the same basis as they deserve to have the Liberal Party policies costed. I only wish you had had the decency to allow the National Party policies to be costed and not to exclude them from this matter as you have. Accordingly, Minister, you have my full support for your bill. You have my full opposition to your intention to reject the amendments we put forward.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to support the questions that have been put to the minister by the Australian Democrats spokesman, Senator Murray, who has just resumed his seat. Senator Murray has done this chamber and the people of Australia a service by inquiring intelligently of the government what other bills bar this—what other acts bar this—would not be enforceable? I do await with baited breath a cogent list of such bills from the minister, although I must say my expectation of getting one outstrips my belief of the likelihood of it occurring.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to say a couple of things too, since the minister has spoken in direct reply to the remarks I made. With the greatest of respect to you, Minister, I have to say that this is the sort of behaviour that gives politicians a bad name. No wonder people in Australia are cynical about politicians when we see performances such as the one that we saw just a moment ago. There is a fundamental and basically cynical and manipulative view that, if you repeat something often enough, it assumes its own truth and then all you have to do is keep repeating it. Because it has been said often enough, there is a tendency for people to believe it might have some substance.

What we heard from you, Minister, with the greatest respect to you, is the repetition of a number of half truths or mistruths in the belief that, by continuing to repeat them and by people continuing to hear them, they might develop some credence. Well, they do not.

Let us get a few of the facts clearly on the table.The Senate amended this bill not to advantage the opposition but to make it fair and reasonable. It was amended so that the man or woman in the street could say, `That's a fair shake for both of the major political parties. We're coming up to an election. We want to know what the true costs of their promises are. We want that arbitrated on by the Department of Treasury and the Depart ment of Finance, by the specialist bureaucrats, and not interfered with by politicians.' Prior to an election, the people of Australia want to see what the bureaucrats believe the implications are and that this not be interfered with by politicians.

One of the amendments the Senate made which you are now wanting to turn over is that the opposition has to give a copy of its policies to the Prime Minister and he will then choose to pass on what he wishes to the bureaucrats for costing and pretend that that is the opposition's position. You might like to tell us why you think that is fair. Don't come back, Minister, if I can anticipate you, with the blather that you came back with before that there are forms and conventions and therefore the Prime Minister is the only one who can direct the Public Service. The Senate heard you on that last time and wrote an amendment, which originated from a suggestion by Senator Harradine, which overcame that problem. That amendment removes the problem of direction by the parliament of the Public Service. It removes the problem that hitherto only ministers sworn in by the Governor-General can direct the Public Service.

But you now want to go back and change that. You want to change it back to a situation in which the Prime Minister will see up‐front what the opposition's policies are and, if he wishes to, select from them what he wants to pass on for costing, borrow from them what he wants to use for himself or do whatever he wants to do. You have not answered the question as to why you want to change back to that situation. If people want to know what is fair about this bill, they will want to know why the opposition has to have the Prime Minister interfere with its promises in order to get a costing of them. That is another question you might care to answer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —All the questions that you have raised have been canvassed very extensively in the debate. Senator Murray has put down a range of questions. Senator Murray, we are, as you would expect us to do, rapidly preparing you answers to that. I have a draft here which we are still checking, but we will provide you with a list which will show fairly clearly, at least on the advice I have, that this bill, in the way you expressed it, is not without precedent in this chamber. It is a matter of doing the work. You have asked some questions. The work is being done. I have a draft before me which shows how assiduous our officers have been in preparing this. So there will be an answer to those questions.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no answer, regrettably, to the question that other people may ask as to the hypocrisy of the Labor Party. It is just awesome that Senator Cook should stand up here and attempt to lecture the government while completely forgetting that this bill had its genesis in the disgraceful behaviour of the Keating government, of which he was a minister. Let us remember the history. Prior to the election, Mr Keating and Mr Willis apparently did not have additional figures that they could give to the Australian public to show the state of the budget.

Funnily enough, after the election Monday the figures were presented to the Prime Minister and the Treasurer. You had the figures and you hid them, and you were part of that government. So don't you get up here and lecture others. We have put a bill before this parliament which will stop such behaviour by the likes of you and your colleagues.

You are attempting to move a whole host of amendments, some of which are unnecessary, some of which complicate the bill and some of which are already covered in the bill. Whilst reiterating what I have said, Senator Murray has said—and at least, Senator Murray, you are straightforward—first of all, that this is a very important bill and, secondly, that the amendments that have been moved advantage the opposition. That is correct. That is exactly what I have been saying. That is what the Labor Party has been doing. But we rest on the fact that this is a bill on which we went to the election. We stated that this was a promise, and this bill gives effect to that promise.

The Labor Party has moved a whole host of amendments which, I regret to say, have been supported in the Senate by a majority. They are amendments which for a variety of rea sons are simply not acceptable to us. In the first place, quite a number of them unduly complicate the bill and are not needed. Secondly, we are worried about the effect that these amendments may have on the typical conventions between public servants, governments and oppositions. Naturally, we are concerned about that. Some of them we think are just plain unworkable. We are not going to accept these amendments. We have had an excellent debate on them. Senator, I am sorry that you do not like me reminding you of your statements of the past.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish you would do it honestly. That's all.

—Every time you want to stand up and talk about things such as tax avoidance I will be talking about your attitude to things like R&D syndicates. I put that on notice. When you want to get up and talk about being honest, I will talk about how you and your government went to an election pretending there was not a massive deficit and there was. I will remind you of that. If you do not like it, that is just tough, but you are going to wear the costs of the way you behaved in government and the Australian public are quite entitled to be constantly reminded of it when you get up and purport to lecture this government. This is an important bill. We urge that the bill be passed so that the charter of budget honesty can come into effect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a pretty speech, Minister—pretty dishonest, I might say.
—Pretty weak humour, on your part.

—No. Will you now bother to answer the question that I asked you? I asked you a specific question; you have not answered it. You have tried to do everything else but answer it, including smear me personally and attack the Labor Party.
—Aw shucks!
—Yes, aw shucks.
—After your speech! Big deal!
—Order! Minister!

—Do you want to have a political debate? If you want to have a political debate, we will have a political debate, but we are in the committee stage of a bill in which the opposition and other senators are able to ask questions about what the government means by its proposal. I am wanting a factual answer to my question which I am in order to ask. And would you now answer it, Minister?

SPEECH.PARA: To remind you of what that question is, one of the amendments made by the Senate is to create a way in which opposition election undertakings cannot be interfered with by the Prime Minister and must be costed by the bureaucrats. By your insisting that that amendment should not stand, it means that the opposition will have to submit their election undertakings to the Prime Minister and, within the meaning of the bill, he will choose, if he wishes, to pass on those promises to the bureaucracy or not, or to borrow from them, or to delay their passage to the bureaucracy.

My question is: in view of that meaning, why do you want to insist that the Prime Minister be able to interfere in that way? I would be grateful if you would give us the answer to that question. Depending on the answer, I may have other questions for you, Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —We are always happy to answer your questions, Senator Cook. I just repeat myself: I will continue to remind you of your performance in government. I think that is a perfectly fair and reasonable response, and you would expect that.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments which we are debating—I think they are Senate amendments 6, 7, 8 and 9—allow for the possibility of the departments of Treasury and Finance costing policies for the government and opposition in the caretaker period prior to an election. Further, the amendments allow for the making of requests for costings by the Leader of the Opposition to be authorised by the Prime Minister but that the details of the policies being costed need not be disclosed to the Prime Minister. They also provide for the details of policies—

TALK.START.PARA: —They may be!

—Look, you have asked a question, Senator, and I am giving you a detailed answer. As soon as you are given a detailed answer, you start butting in and interjecting. Where are your manners, Senator Cook?
—You're kidding! You jest!
—Now you have behind you a chorus of ill-mannered people butting in.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Lundy interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —There is another one. They also provide that the details of policies, the subject of a request by the Leader of the Opposition, shall not be disclosed by the secretaries to the departments of the Treasury and Finance to anyone not authorised by the Leader of the Opposition. The secretaries, of course, may decline to prepare costings under any request where they consider that policy advice is being sought.

SPEECH.PARA: We do not consider that these amendments should proceed. The amendments will result in a loss of transparency in the costing process. The lack of transparency under the amendments is also inconsistent with clause 31 of the bill. This clause requires that all policy costings be made public by the secretaries to the departments as soon as practicable before polling day. As the request for the costing of unannounced policies would be permitted, requests could be made for a range of alternative policy options to be costed. The short answer is that that is why we are opposing them. If they are public policies you wish to have costed, you can pass them to the Prime Minister, who can then pass them to the departments.
Progress reported.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question without notice is directed to Senator Hill representing the Prime Minister. Minister, with regard to the nursing home up‐front bonds, did the Prime Minister say, `This measure is a very desirable long‐term reform'? Did he also say, `The fundamentals of the policy are right'? Minister, why did the Prime Minister not take his latest version on nursing home bonds to cabinet? Is it a fact that the decision regarding this backdown was taken without the benefit of any departmental submissions or papers? Is it also a fact that the Prime Minister merely telephoned a few of his close colleagues to get a clearance for this policy reversal? Why was the Prime Minister unable to answer detailed questions about his latest proposals, and why is he still unable to answer them?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister was reflecting the fact that the sector is badly in need of capital. There is no doubt that it was significantly run down under Labor. I did not think there was any dispute about the fact that an answer needs to be found to enable the upgrading of the quality of care that we would expect for all Australians that enter nursing homes. That is basically what the Prime Minister was saying.

ANSWER.PARA: I guess our mistake was to copy Labor's solution, because Labor's solution in relation to hostels was to apply bonds. I guess, on reflection, we are better aware that there are different circumstances in relation to nursing homes and bonds. As a result of that, we have decided to withdraw from that previous policy position.

The position remains, of course, that there is a need for a capital inflow in the sector, and that is why the Prime Minister has put down the alternative of, in effect, the payment of a capital sum of money. We believe that that will achieve the same outcomes and achieve them without the necessity for any aged person to have to sell their home to do so. Undertakings have been given in that regard.

With regard to process, I would not have thought it would be any surprise to Senator Faulkner to know that this matter was looked at in great depth within government and that careful consideration was given before the announcement by the Prime Minister. It is true that there were aspects of detail that needed to be further worked up and, in fact, some of those details are still being worked up, but it was believed important not to delay the announcement in relation to the bonds vis‐a‐vis the capital contribution. I think aged Australia applauds the Prime Minister for making the decision when he did rather than delaying it until all the fine detail was finally concluded. We hope to be able to put down all of that detail as soon as possible, but in the meantime we are pleased that we have been able to assure the aged of Australia that they can not only get the care that they would have got in the past under Labor but better quality care as a result of their making a contribution to the capital costs—when they can afford to do so—of the nursing home sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, perhaps you could let us know if the Prime Minister has any plans to apologise to Ms Judi Moylan for humiliating her for her failure to sell a policy which has now been rejected by the Prime Minister himself. If he perhaps will not apologise to Ms Moylan, will the Prime Minister at least apologise to thousands of elderly Australians who have suffered trauma because of his ill‐conceived and ill‐executed policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a policy of the government's which went through a number of processes and, of course, through a legislative form in this place. Nevertheless, a decision was made that it was a mistake. I think that the Prime Minister is to be applauded for being prepared to say so and to give the elderly the confidence of the fact that there is another way of achieving the same outcome by which they need not be concerned about matters relating to their family home.

ANSWER.PARA: It has taken a while to get there, I concede, but it is a successful outcome in terms of a response to meet the deficiency we inherited from Labor—and that is a run‐down sector—whilst giving confidence to the aged community that they will be contributing only what they can afford.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to Senator Hill, Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the statement last week of the Governor of the Reserve Bank about the recent instability in the Asian region when he said, `We are in a much better position to handle this financial instability than we have been at any stage, I think, in the last quarter of a century.' Could the governor be reflecting on the fact that this is due to Australia enjoying record low inflation, record low interest rates, record home affordability, record booming retail sales, increasing business investment and now reducing unemployment? Will the minister further outline the achievements of the Howard government in fixing Labor's economic mess and assisting families and small business?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly. I appreciate the question because, yes, there is a contrast between sound economic management under this government and the economic mess that we inherited from Labor—a more than $10 billion deficit. Senator Cook did not even know that it existed—he did not even know that his government was $10 billion in the red.
