But, yes, the importance of taking those hard decisions and putting the economy in a stronger state has certainly been demonstrated in recent times.

ANSWER.PARA: The point that the Governor of the Reserve Bank is making is that the economy is in a better position to withstand these pressures now than at any time in the last 25 years. There is a real message in there for the Australian people that they have a government that is determined to adopt economic principles that will withstand any stresses that might occur within the region. Yes, there is no doubt, Senator Coonan, that the matters you referred to were relevant to the Reserve Bank Governor being so confident in making that statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about unemployment?

—The lowest inflation rate in 35 years under the Howard government, Senator Cook. Interest rates are now at their lowest for 20 years, Senator Cook. Home affordability is now at a record high, Senator Cook. Business investment is also at high levels again. Business and consumer confidence is showing a significant improvement, retail sales are booming and we have the largest quarterly rise in the series since its commencement. Unemployment, I am pleased to see, is now trending down. I am sure that will be applauded by all senators.

ANSWER.PARA: All this has been achieved in just 18 months of good government, adopting sound economic principles. What a contrast from the economic mess that we inherited. It demonstrates that it is worthwhile to take those hard decisions and to face up to the need to constrain expenditure to get the fundamentals right, and then all Australians can benefit from what flows therefrom.

You are right again, Senator Coonan: particularly small business. Small business is the engine room for growth, for jobs and for families. Families are then able to have the benefit of homes that they can afford and interest rates that they can afford, giving them greater confidence in the future. That is what this government was elected to do, and I am pleased that the Governor of the Reserve Bank recognises our achievements.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coonan, Sen Helen

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the minister outline further initiatives of the Howard government in fixing this economic mess?

QUESTION.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator, I did not hear the supplementary. Would you deliver it again?
—Order! I need to hear the questions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coonan, Sen Helen

TALK.START.PARA: —Would the minister outline any further achievements of the Howard government in helping to fix this economic mess that it has been left by the Labor government?

QUESTION.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senators on my left will stop interjecting.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the point Senator Coonan is making is that, although so much has been done, there is still more to do because there were so many areas in which Labor was not prepared to show the leadership that the nation really needed.What remains, of course, is fundamental taxation reform. Which government is prepared to do that for the benefit of all Australians? Which government is prepared to—

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are far too many interjections on my left. Senators will cease interjecting.

—Which government is prepared to build on the pillars of sound economic management that we have already seen—industrial relations reform, fiscal reform? Which government? Of course, it is the Howard government. We will go down that path because, although we recognise it will be just as difficult as the other areas, it is in the national interest. Ultimately, it will also be applauded by all Australians.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Family Services, Senator Herron. Minister, isn't it a fact that you misled the Senate when you told it on 20 October:

QUESTION.PARA: Nobody to date has paid that sort of sum.
in relation to nursing home fees of $90,000?

Minister, has your attention been drawn to the case of the 83‐year‐old mother of Kathy McLaren who paid $125,000 to enter the Ginninderra Nursing Home in Page in the ACT? What do you say to Ms McLaren and will you now correct the record?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lundy obviously believes everything she reads in the papers. No, I did not mislead the Senate. The information that had been received at the time was that the maximum bond which had been paid into the scheme was about $78,000. The prudential scheme had no record whatsoever, Senator Lundy, that a higher payment had been made. I also understand that the facility concerned has since repaid the bond to its resident.

ANSWER.PARA: I gave an accurate report at the time. Apparently, a bond had been paid to a residential care facility which had not notified that to the government. We cannot report things of which we are unaware. We were totally unaware of that. I gave a factual reply to the question. The answer that I gave then was correct. Senator Lundy should stop believing everything she reads in the newspapers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Don't you think it is your responsibility as a minister to ensure that you are properly briefed so you can answer questions without making basic errors of fact and misleading the Senate? Have you personally apologised to Ms McLaren and her mother after causing such distress?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to say that I am accurately briefed. I would think that the Canberra Times should have been accurately briefed. The Canberra Times was notified that that report was inaccurate before it was printed, and then went ahead and printed it. With respect to Senator Lundy, I think she can be forgiven for that statement because it was inaccurate when it was printed.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Lundy, I do not know the address of that lady. Her name and address were not given, as I understand it, in the paper. The Canberra Times should apologise to that lady. The Canberra Times printed an inaccurate report. Despite the fact that they were notified that it was inaccurate they went ahead with it, so they should apologise both to the lady and to Senator Lundy.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. Minister, the Howard government has given a high priority to the process of reconciliation. Will the minister assure the Senate that the reconciliation process will be vigorously pursued?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Ferris for her question. Yes, the government is strongly committed to the reconciliation process. We were at the beginning, when the Reconciliation Council was established, and we have continued to be so. I also believe that within the community there is a belief that more can be achieved than we have to date. I also believe that reconciliation must grow from the community level and that this government will promote that growth. In fact, I have spoken on this matter on many occasions outside the Senate. It is something that I believe in very strongly, but we must not lose sight of the fact that Australia is a decent and harmonious nation based on fairness, on tolerance and mutual respect, and on an appreciation of racial and cultural diversity. This government is committed to upholding these values and is totally committed to continuing the reconciliation process.

ANSWER.PARA: I am extremely disappointed in some who have sought to turn the process into a political football in recent days. It is too important for it to be turned into a political football. It is far too precious to see it damaged in that way, and I would repeat what I said on Friday in a statement released to the media:

As a nation we simply cannot afford to have reconciliation damaged in the political arena . . . I ask those who have been politicising this issue to stop and think seriously about the implications of their actions.

The facts are fairly straightforward. The government strongly encouraged Patrick Dodson to continue as chairman of the council. Despite that, he wrote to me on Thursday, 30 October and then verbally, on a number of occasions over the following four days, repeated that he did not want reappointment. It was fully a week after I received his written decision not to seek reappointment that Mr Dodson wrote saying he had changed his mind. By that time, we had already approached someone else to be our nominee for the position and she had accepted.

Evelyn Scott is an outstanding Australian. Ms Scott has been involved in Aboriginal affairs for over 30 years and, during that time, has made an outstanding practical contribution to reconciliation through her life work. She is a member of the National Multicultural Advisory Council, a member of the Ministerial Advisory Committee for Queensland and a member of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. Ms Scott is also President of the National Aboriginal and Islander Skills Development Association in Sydney and Chairman of the Cairns and District Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders Cooperation for Women. She was recognised at the Reconciliation Convention in May.

I firmly believe that there are three essential elements in achieving a lasting reconciliation between indigenous and non-indigenous Australians. First, there needs to be a shared commitment to overcoming indigenous disadvantage and providing equality of opportunity for all Australians. Second, there needs to be an honest and realistic acknowledgment of the injustices of the past. Third, there needs to be a mutual acceptance of the importance of working together in ensuring that our differences do not prevent us from sharing equally in a common future. It is important to understand that the council was established with unanimous cross-party support. Once again, I would ask those who have sought to politicise the reconciliation process to stop and consider their actions.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to Senator Herron in his capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Family Services. Minister, can you confirm that under the Prime Minister's most recent proposal—nursing home policy mark 3—the average yearly fee for nursing home accommodation will be $4,000? Minister, how can the government be sure that this will, in fact, be the average? On what basis is the government making this claim? What will be the upper limit of that yearly fee?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the things that we are doing, as distinct from the Labor Party, is consulting with the providers of nursing home care. We are consulting widely with them. This consultation process will include a meeting on Thursday to develop that process.

ANSWER.PARA: It has been announced that the average fee under the new arrangements will be $4,000, as Senator Evans has mentioned, but it is an average. What must be known is that there are 130,000 people in nursing homes in this country. Currently, the taxpayer picks up 70 per cent of the cost of that nursing home care. It is an average of $28,000 a year. The best line that I saw on this—I am indebted to Alan Ramsey—was in the Sydney Morning Herald. Alan Ramsey said this about the opposition:
Oppositions are like that, of course. All scare and no responsibility.
It was a great line by Mr Ramsey. He also went on to say:
"Let's see what there is at the end of it," was all he—
that is, Mr Beazley—

would say when pressed this week. What Beazley did promise, though, was "to keep flogging this. Let me tell you." He told Steve Liebmann on Nine's Today program, "we are going to get a bit of justice here."
Really! For a former finance minister in a Labor Government that cut capital spending on nursing homes by some $30 million in its last three Budgets, it was a pledge with an utterly empty ring to it.
The scare campaign continues. We have made a mistake. We are going to the industry. We are going to the providers. We are going to those recipients—

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I rise on a point of order. Senator Herron was asked if he could confirm that the average yearly fee for nursing home accommodation would be $4,000. He was also asked: how can the government be sure that this will, in fact, be the average? On what basis was the claim made? What was the upper limit of the yearly fee? None of those questions has the minister attempted to address. Madam President, I ask you to draw the minister's attention to the questions that were directed to him. They were very specific questions. On the grounds of relevance, I ask you to direct the minister to answer these questions.
—The minister is dealing with the question as he sees appropriate and may continue.
—Thank you, Madam President. It has been stated that that is believed to be the average. I can give no further detail on that because it is not available to me.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, it is clearly most inadequate that you cannot provide to concerned Australians any detail on this issue. Can't you confirm that, at the time of the announcement of the nursing home policy mark 1, the Prime Minister said that the average accommodation bond would be $26,000? Isn't it the case that, during the short lifespan of mark 1, the average bond turned out to be over $40,000? Why then should we believe the Prime Minister's claim that the new yearly fee will average $4,000?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been figures dropped all over the place in relation to these matters. As I said previously, they will be revealed after consultation with the providers and the representatives of people in nursing homes. It all will be revealed in due course.

—My question is also to the Minister representing the Minister for Family Services. I also refer to the recent announcement of the Prime Minister that accommodation bonds are out and that they are going to be replaced by an average annual fee of $4,000. We acknowledge that some of the fine detail may not have been worked out, but could you please answer three basic questions? Which nursing homes will be able to charge these fees? Who in these nursing homes will be expected to pay them? For how many years will they be expected to pay them?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Lees for the question. In relation to your last question, Senator Lees, as I understand the announcement, the fees will be paid for a period of five years. As to which nursing homes, that will be decided in consultation with the nursing home providers. You will appreciate, Senator Lees, that 27 per cent of people in nursing homes will not be affected by the charges because they fall under the category that will not be affected by those charges. In relation to the first question, that will be determined after consultation with the industry on Thursday.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, at the last budget you took some $500 million out over four years. Presumably, as we will not be seeing this legislation this session, it will be not until this time next year that the charges can be made—
—The Democrats have come a bit late to this debate, haven't they?
—Order! There are far too many interjections. Will you start again please.

—Thank you. Minister, your government last budget took some $500 million out and put in the system that we have now seen abandoned. It will probably be this time next year before the new system takes over, so nursing homes will have at least 12 months with no income to upgrade. In the interim, will the government put some money into the homes so that they can continue the process of upgrading?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —The facts of the matter are that, when we came into government, we inherited a $10,300 million deficit. The fact also is that nursing homes are in crisis because the opposition, who had control of the levers for 13 years, produced that result. We would not be facing this problem if it were not for the inaction of the Labor Party when they were in government.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Lees, the minister made a statement that those changes would take effect from the date when he issued the press release—and that is available to you. Certainly they will not be delayed for 12 months. He said, for example, that the government would retain the arrangement for exempting an estimated 27 per cent of people entering residential care from making capital payments; that this would be replaced by an annual payment similar to the periodic payment option that already exists and that the annual payment would be capped. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Family Services. It concerns the mess that the government has made of nursing homes.
—There is no question then.
—Senators on my right will cease interjecting.

—Will the rental income from homes the elderly are forced to rent in order to pay nursing home fees affect their liability to pay the new income‐tested extra daily fee, which is to be introduced on 1 March next year and which could be as high as $63 a day?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —The only mess that was left was the mess in nursing homes that the Labor Party left us to pick up, and we are attempting to do that in consultation. We made a mistake in relation to bonds because we followed the lead of the Labor Party in relation to hostels.
—That is a lie! You did not!

—It was the same principle that we followed in relation to nursing homes. But because of the all scare and no responsibility that was carried on by the opposition, we are now consulting—as we did before—with the providers of nursing homes and with the representatives of those people in nursing homes to come up with an answer. We are coming up with an answer by consulting everybody who is involved in the process.

ANSWER.PARA: The detail, as I said, will be developed on Thursday at the meeting and the minister will announce it in due course. I am happy to come back to the Senate with the detail when it has been sorted out.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, I note that you have evaded giving a direct answer to a direct question. Perhaps you can tell me the answer to this question then: when will the government make available a document which clearly sets out how these latest charges will operate? Will you guarantee that this time the document will not be the 47 pages of legalistic gobbledegook that you offered before?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I would not say that it was legalistic gobbledegook. It was certainly difficult to understand, Senator Cook, and I acknowledged that to Senator Collins.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Bob Collins interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I acknowledged that to you but I did not say it was legalistic gobbledegook. That was Senator—
—You did.

—I am more inclined to agree with things that Senator Collins says than Senator Cook. When the detail has been developed, it will be available to honourable senators opposite. But it remains to be determined.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. My question relates to the Howard government's major attack on the illegal drugs trade in Australia. How will the `tough on drugs' initiative assist the fight against drugs which is causing so much concern in our community?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Minister for Justice

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Ferguson for the question. The Prime Minister, in announcing the `tough on drugs' initiative, made it very clear that the Commonwealth and this government intends to take a lead in the war against illicit drugs, the menace facing so many Australian families. In doing so, the Prime Minister underlined the need for state governments to work cooperatively with the Commonwealth government and for law enforcement agencies around Australia and internationally to work together. It has certainly been made clear that cooperation is without a doubt the most effective way forward in law enforcement.

ANSWER.PARA: Drugs and the drug barons do not recognise state boundaries, nor do they recognise national boundaries. It is a slim hope held by a naive few to imagine that focusing on the efforts of one particular agency will ever have a chance of being effective in this battle. We saw on the weekend an example of just how effective law enforcement can be when the agencies work together.

In my own state of South Australia, we saw 13.6 kilograms of heroin being seized and nine arrests being made across two states. The operation was between two states. It involved the following stakeholders: the South Australian Police, the National Crime Authority, the Australian Federal Police—I hope I have not left anybody out—and Customs. Customs played an exemplary role in this particular matter. As I understand it, customs officers went just a bit further than a profile of customs checking required them to do. Putting in that extra effort and going that bit further is what enabled us to seize 13.6 kilograms of heroin. But I want to underline that it was a cooperative effort between a range of agencies and between states. That is the way forward.

The Australasian Police Ministers Council met recently in Adelaide. It noted progress in a national heroin supply reduction strategy and endorsed a greater collaborative effort in the war against illicit drugs. Briefly, I would like to highlight a number of the initiatives announced by the Prime Minister in the `tough on drugs' campaign. There will be three additional AFP mobile strike teams. This means some 54 additional agents at a cost of some $15½ million working on intelligence driven drug operations.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senators opposite can keep interjecting if they like. They might think that members of the public think senators are paid to sit here and interject and to be a rabble, but they are not necessarily doing themselves any favours. They might do well if they just pipe down and let ministers give their answers.

ANSWER.PARA: The mobile strike teams will be supported by informant and witness protection programs with more money going into those programs—nearly $3 million in that respect. Of particular interest is the national heroin signature program and research into illicit drug use at a cost of over $1 million. That program will allow us to detect the pathways through which drugs have come. It is not true to say that it is a sort of DNA testing. But each packet of drugs has a particular characteristic that can allow us to pretty well source where it has come from. By continuing with that program over a number of years, we will have much better intelligence as to where to place customs officers, AFP officers, NCA officers and so on.

That is just the start of a range of things: the Customs Service has an additional $8 million to profile and examine cargo; there is an additional $7 million for more communica tions and technology for the AFP and the NCA; more coastal detection, especially in the Torres Strait with nearly $7 million; and more money for intelligence analysis in the Customs Service. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Family Services. The Prime Minister announced last week on A Current Affair that he would be talking to institutions about reverse mortgage arrangements for frail elderly people. What institutions has the government talked to? Were financial institutions consulted about offering reverse mortgage schemes before the Prime Minister's spectacular backflip?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Crowley for the question. I am unaware of the answers to those questions. I will certainly ask the minister for the reply and come back to the Senate in due course.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, if you are coming back with further information, could you please answer a question raised by Mr Ross McDowall, General Manager of the Queensland Credit Union, on today's World Today program regarding research his credit union has done into reverse mortgage home loans. He quoted the extraordinary figure that, if a person in a nursing home is drawing $4,000 a year on 7.5 per cent, after 15 years they will owe $112,000. What happens to that person once their loan equals the value of their home—say $80,000—and what happens to that person if interest rates rise?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not hear the World Today program but I certainly saw a newspaper report as to that statement. I believe that is incorrect but I will get back to Senator Crowley with a response when that is looked into in detail.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Could the minister please explain the delay in delivering to the Romanian committee on adoptions the signed renewed inter‐country adoption agreement with Romania? Is the minister aware of allegations in regard to the Romanian inter‐country adoption program that, despite the Romanian government's suspension of all agreements and agents in January 1997, the Department of Human Services in Victoria, which is the lead agency in the agreement with Romania, continued to hold information seminars on the program, continued to forward files to unlicensed agents in Romania and continued to instruct adoptive parents to forward monies to these agents despite advice from Romania not to do so? Is the minister aware that currently 20 files and at least $US40,000 have been sent by Australian couples to these unlicensed agents?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —This question has something of a familiar ring to it, but it relates to a different state. I am aware of difficulties that have been occurring in relation to the program with Romania. I understand that the program was, at least temporarily, terminated as a result of problems at the Romanian end. Fortunately, the problems did not relate to the files of prospective Australian adoptive parents, they related to others, but it has required a new agreement to be reached.

ANSWER.PARA: There was an attempt to have an extension, as I understand it, of the old agreement, but that was not regarded as satisfactory. I gather that the new agreement has now been achieved. I am aware that there are, as Senator Harradine says, a number of anxious families at this end waiting for children. I am told that, because of these difficulties, the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs has become involved and has been given copies of the correspondence. I understand that he has been in touch with the state agency to which Senator Harradine referred.

As in the China case, we are trying to make as much progress as quickly as possible but, as Senator Harradine understands better than most in this chamber, these matters are complex and difficult. I will get an up‐to‐date report from the minister for immigration and get it to Senator Harradine as soon as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to Senator Herron, the Minister Representing the Minister for Family Services. Has the government appointed the special representative as an advocate for elderly people who were forced to sell their homes for the now discredited accommodation bond scheme? If so, who is it? Will you guarantee the refund of all up‐front bonds? Will this require legislation? Will it need to have retrospective effect? If there is a refusal by some institutions to refund the bond, will the government consider an act of grace payment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Ray for the question. They are rolling out the big guns. I am delighted to have him asking a question from the back bench. Instead of directing the questions, he is now asking them, and I think we should be grateful for that. At least it is going back to the source.

ANSWER.PARA: As I understand it, the minister will be appointing the special representative today or tomorrow. That special representative will then negotiate with the nursing home representatives in discussing this matter. He will be discussing what bonds were paid prior to 6 November and if they had entered into a legally binding agreement which would require them to pay an accommodation bond to an accredited nursing home provider.

The minister's intention is that people who have already paid a bond or entered into a legally binding agreement to pay a bond on entry to a nursing home will have the choice of moving to the annual payment system. He is seeking the cooperation of the nursing homes to make that choice available. To assist the special representative in this task, he has also asked the chair of the Aged Care Accommodation Bond Trust to take whatever action is within his powers to identify those persons who will need the assistance of the special representative.

He has stated that, in the first instance, it is critical to identify those who have been adversely affected and to assess their position. The government is obviously concerned about the adverse effect of these policies on the individual, and we will help those who need assistance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, if it has the effect that there is no legal weight behind the special representative's attempts to solve people's problems, will this government consider legislating? Will it have retrospective effect, which this government always says it will never legislate on? Finally, if none of the methods works, will the government consider an act of grace payment to resolve the situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said in my preliminary answer, it is too early to give a response to the supplementary question because the special representative has not even been appointed yet. It remains to be seen what results follow from the special representative meeting with those people who are affected and with the nursing home representatives to see what equitable arrangements can be achieved.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister Representing the Minister for Trade, Senator Hill. Given the downturn in Asian markets, trade in our other markets is even more important. Is the minister aware that the German government has called on the Australian government to reverse its decision not to participate in the World Trade Fair in Hanover in the year 2000?

QUESTION.PARA: Minister, why does your government continue to jeopardise Australia's trade in European markets by refusing to sign the standard human rights clause in European trade treaties, by resisting the privacy legislation the Europeans use to underpin data transfer and, now, by being the only major trading nation to refuse to participate in the Expo 2000 World Trade Fair in Germany, which would provide an ideal opportunity to showcase Australia on the world stage in the lead‐up to the Olympics? Why is the government more concerned with short‐term budget savings rather than with long‐term growth in export opportunities?

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not quite see what this has got to do with human rights clauses in trade agreements with the European Union. In any event, as I understand it, that matter has been resolved. In relation to the Expo, our principal concern really was an issue of cost. That might not mean much to the Australian Democrats because they would be a high expenditure alternative if they were ever in government. But it is another $21 million, as I understand it, at a time when we are, as a nation, investing in a number of major international events.
—Like what?
—How about the Olympics for a start?
—They're not trade, they're sport.

—Do you know how much the Olympics is costing in that year, Senator Cook? Of course, you are the one who did not realise that we were $10 billion in the red. He is demonstrating why he did not know that we were $10 billion in the red. The World Economic Forum is meeting in Melbourne at about the same time, and there will also be considerable expenditure on preparation for the centenary of Federation in the following year. All of these matters were taken into account and it was believed by the government that we could not afford this extra investment. That is why that decision was made at that time.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister it is a trite saying, but true, that you have to speculate to accumulate. Everyone knows that the government needs to invest in Australia's future if it is going to get a return on jobs and growth. Minister, for your $21 million, did you do any cost‐benefit analysis to assess whether the cost of $21 million forgone in this area would result in a loss in jobs and long‐term growth opportunities? Whilst you are at it, the issues of privacy and of human rights legislation—these kinds of issues—relate to our ability to interact easily with our European competitors within European markets.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Just dealing with the last part first, we do not have to do it the way the Europeans require on every occasion to achieve a good trade outcome, and we did not in that instance. As I said, as I recall it the matter was resolved satisfactorily to both sides.

ANSWER.PARA: Obviously, assessment was made of the benefits that would flow—of course, that is very difficult to calculate—but there are many opportunities and, as you know, many investments by this country in trade fairs, particularly within the region.
Senator Cook interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You tell us to concentrate on the region, Senator Cook. The decision was made at the time that this was an extra expenditure which we could not afford. That was the basis on which the decision was made.

—My question is to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. Minister, has the government decided to replace Mr Ian Viner QC as the deputy chairperson of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation? Were leaders of other political parties consulted about Mr Viner's successor? If so, was this before the event? Finally, Minister, will you take this opportunity to publicly acknowledge the work that Mr Viner has carried out as deputy chair of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the newly depilated Senator Bolkus for his question. I am pleased that I have the opportunity to put the facts on the record. Mr Viner sent me a fax, on the same day that I received a fax from Mr Patrick Dodson, saying that he would not be prepared to submit his name for reappointment to the Council for Reconciliation. I replied to him on the same day, thanking him for the service that he had done the reconciliation council. I told him that I disagreed with some of the statements in his letter in relation to the government's commitment to reconciliation.
—Which ones did you disagree with?

—Senator Cook has asked me what they were. I do not have the letter with me, but I can tell you that I dis agreed on the momentum with which I believed that reconciliation needed to be achieved. I thanked him for the work that he had done. He has done great service, as Senator Bolkus intimated—there is no question about that—but he said that he was not prepared to be considered for reappointment, so I acted on that. Under the terms of the act, I am required to consult. When the Labor Party were in power they did not. My predecessor sent a final list to the government—that is how much consultation occurred when they were in power. I have sent a list of about 50 names to the Democrats and to the Labor Party asking them to consider those lists.
—And asked for responses by 12 November—in two days time!

—Senator Collins has interjected. I recognise that consultation. We did not get any. We were sent a final list, with which we agreed. I recognise the contribution made by Mr Viner, but Mr Viner stated that he was not prepared to be considered for reappointment on the same day that I received the fax from Mr Dodson. Both faxed me their letters on 30 October and said that they did not wish to be considered for reappointment but that they would continue in their present roles up until the next meeting of the reconciliation council in December.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, a mere letter of advice does not constitute consultation. I ask a supplementary question. Minister, is it true that the outgoing deputy chairman of the council, Mr Ian Viner—someone you have just praised—has accused you of lacking frankness, understanding and vision? I ask you whether Mr Viner is correct in asserting that your vision is:

QUESTION.PARA: barren, in terms of objectives for which the Council was created or what Australia can achieve in reconciliation between indigenous Australians and the wider community.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister and I met with Mr Viner and Mr Dodson in August. I subsequently met with Mr Viner and Mr Dodson in Brisbane. At no time was this stated by Mr Viner in my presence. I do not have the letter in front of me. Senator Bolkus obviously has if he says that that is in it. Is that what Senator Bolkus is saying?
—I didn't say it was in the letter.
—He did not say that was in the letter. He has just acknowledged that. So here we go again—sliding over it; an attempted smear.

—On a point of order: Senator Herron should be asked to answer the question. The question was: has Mr Viner said this? It has been publicly reported across the country. Just because Senator Herron has not noticed it does not mean that that comment is in the letter. It was never asserted that it was in the letter. It has been publicly acknowledged as being all over the country. I ask Senator Herron: why is Mr Viner wrong when he makes such a frank assessment of your abysmal performance?
—There is no point of order.

—There is a difference between Senator Bolkus saying that Mr Viner said something and Mr Viner saying something. Mr Viner said nothing to me. I got a letter from him. I have not spoken to him subsequently.

—I have a question for Senator Ellison, the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. My question relates to the Prime Minister's announcement last week of the $87.5 million national drug strategy.
—He's already answered that, Alan.
—This is a different question. Will the minister outline the amount of funding allocated for drug education in schools and how these funds will be targeted towards our young people?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Schools, Vocational Education and Training

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Eggleston for that question. I would point out to Senator Schacht at the outset that the drug strategy, which involved an expenditure of $87.5 million over three years, involved three prongs that dealt with health, law enforcement and education. In relation to education, I can tell the Senate that there is a schools aspect which deals with an expenditure of $7.4 million over three years. But, of course, added to this you have to have education in the community. And that is why we have two other aspects—expenditure of $4.8 million for education in the community where parents, health workers and people working in universities can have assistance in combating illicit drug usage; and expenditure of $1.8 million on a one‐stop shop to disseminate information.

ANSWER.PARA: Madam President, it is terribly important that we educate the next generation against illicit drug usage. It is no use having one part of your drug strategy dealing solely with law enforcement or health. That is why education is so important to bring up the third aspect of this drug strategy.

But what are we doing in schools? We have adopted a zero tolerance policy. This is the policy of the states, and we are going to consult closely with the states to achieve this. Some of the aspects we are going to work towards are a national goal of no illicit drugs in schools and the development of a new high quality curriculum consistent with national goals for drug education in schools. We are also going to work towards professional development to assist teachers in delivering drug education in schools. It is, after all, the teachers who deliver this message in the schools, and they are going to need assistance of this sort.

We are going to conduct research into the usage of drugs by school‐age students in different situations and how best to target measures to ensure that our schools are drug free. We will be looking around Australia to see where there are schools which have successfully conducted campaigns and which could be drug free. We want to learn from those schools. Where there are schools which have a problem, we need to assess what are the problems regionally which are being addressed by those schools. That is where we are going to look at specific strategies to address the problem in particular regions. We recognise that the situation varies across this great country of ours, and we need to address it on a regional basis. We are also going to have an annual national award for combating drug abuse in schools.
Might I say that this initiative has been well received in the community. In fact, Karen Hart, the President of the Australian Secondary Principals Association, told the Herald‐Sun on 5 November:
The broadness of the campaign is what impresses us. It is a whole of society problem with a wide‐ranging response.
Lawrie Kavanagh, in the Courier‐Mail of 8 November, attacked the usual apologists for criticising the Prime Minister's zero tolerance strategy. He wrote:

So wake up you zero tolerance detractors. Give kids some credit. If they are given irrefutable evidence about the death and destruction drugs can cause to themselves and their peers, they are not going to try the stuff to show their defiance. No‐one is that dumb, not even adolescents.

There are some people who have likened this campaign to a `Just say "No"' campaign. It is a lot more than that, and I have outlined the strategies that we are going to adopt and the goals that we are going to work towards.
Jeanette Wilson, from the Victorian Council of School Organisations, summed it up when she said:
There is no doubt that there is a wide range of drugs easily accessible to school students. It is pleasing to see the government trying to tighten up the availability.
This is a large problem facing Australia. We will not fix it up overnight; we will not fix it in six weeks or over a few months. But fix it we will, and we will work towards that. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Family Services. If $4,000 is the average annual nursing home capital fee that must be paid, can the minister explain what options will be available for elderly Australians whose only asset is their home and who are unable to find tenants and are also unable to obtain a reverse mortgage?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Forshaw for the question. Based on preliminary information, the average payment would be of the order of $4,000, with providers in low cost regions charging somewhat less and providers in high cost regions charging somewhat more. Senator Forshaw will be aware that the government will be retaining the arrangement for exempting an estimated 27 per cent of people entering residential care from making capital payments because of hardship or financial disadvantage. As before, the government will continue to pay up to an extra $12 a day to the provider on their behalf.

ANSWER.PARA: Having answered Senator Forshaw's question in that context, I should add that the detail will be worked out and that they are arrangements that have been voluntarily entered into between the people going into nursing homes, their relatives and the providers of nursing home care. The detail will be available after it has been determined in consultation with the respective groups.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is obvious, Minister, that you really do not have much of an idea. The question that I asked related to people who are obliged to pay the $4,000 fee. It did not relate to people who are not obliged to. It concerned those who are obliged to pay it but are not in the position to either obtain tenants or a reverse mortgage. If you are going to get back to me on that, at least that will be somewhat helpful. But I also ask you this, Minister: can you—will you—give a categorical guarantee that no nursing home resident will be evicted for failure to pay the annual fee? If you can give that commitment, Minister, can you also explain how that will work in situations where people cannot, as I said earlier, pay the $4,000?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, There are hardship provisions. Nobody will be forced, if they have hardship, to pay anything. The reality is that the principle stays. The principle is that those people who can afford to pay should pay. Currently, the taxpayer pays 70 per cent of the cost of nursing home care for 130,000 residents. It is also a fact that the government is approaching it constructively because, over the next 20 years, the number of people over age 65 will grow 2½ times as fast as the general population. The number of people over age 80 will grow nearly three times as fast. So we are taking a constructive approach to it. We are not doing what the previous Labor government did, which was to ignore it. We have to approach it. It is a problem faced by all of us. The alternative is to increase taxation. (Time expired)

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. The minister will be aware that recreational fishing is one of Australia's most popular leisure activities and also a very important industry. For example, in Far North Queensland, recreational fishing is worth some $30 million. Will the minister advise the Senate what measures the government is taking to ensure that the key game fishing species—black and blue marlin—will be protected from commercial fishing?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Resources and Energy

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to thank Senator O'Chee for that question because I know he has taken a long‐term consuming interest in this matter. In fact I suppose it would be accurate to say that he was particularly focused. Madam President, I am pleased to advise the Senate that the government will introduce legislation to protect black and blue marlin from commercial fishing. In the 1996 election campaign we promised we would impose a mandatory ban on the taking of black and blue marlin by commercial operators if the existing voluntary ban proved to be ineffective. A small number of operators ignored the voluntary ban. Apart from inflaming the sports fishermen, the recreational fishermen, in the process it also gave a bad name to the majority of responsible commercial fishermen.

ANSWER.PARA: Accordingly, after discussions that I personally had with both the commercial fishermen and the sports fishermen, we agreed that we would introduce legislation next year to protect black and blue marlin from commercial fishing. Commercial fishing operators that catch black and blue marlin will be required to return them to the sea, dead or alive. This will be a disincentive for them to actually deliberately set out to catch black and blue marlin. The ban will apply to both the domestic industry and the Japanese long‐liners that operate in our waters under the Australian bilateral fishing agreement. Operators who break the law will be subject to fines of up to $12,500.

I am also pleased to say that in the process of these discussions it was found that this problem between the sports fishermen and the commercial fishermen had been going on for the whole period of the previous Labor government, which did nothing whatsoever about it. As was usual with so many of these issues, they put their heads in the sand and pretended that it would go away.

By organising the two groups to get together, I am pleased to say the game fishers, charter boat operators and commercial tuna operators who operate in the Coral Sea have negotiated an innovative agreement that will protect the billfish stocks in the area and enable the two industries to prosper and work together. The six‐point agreement recognises that commercial operators have a legitimate right to fish in the area, but sets a number of agreed restrictions, including the non‐retention of billfish except broadbill swordfish.

Game fishing and commercial fishing are both very important industries in Far North Queensland. The Coral Sea is one of the world's major game fishing areas. It is one of the few places in the world where game fishers can chase the elusive 1,000‐pound black marlin. The game fishing industry's tag and release program means that those magnificent fish are released back into the ocean.But commercial fishing is also an important industry. The majority tuna fishing company in area E, the Great Barrier Reef Tuna, a very responsible commercial fisher, employs directly some 50‐plus people within the Cairns region. The government strongly supports the multiple use of our marine resources. The agreement confirms my very strong view that we do not have to choose between game fishing and commercial fishing. With prudent management both industries can prosper.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can you afford to be a game fisherman?
—No.
—Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —On Thursday, 30 October Senator West asked me a question relating to the sales tax arrangements on adjustable beds. I have now received advice from the Commissioner of Taxation and I seek leave to have this advice incorporated in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

On Thursday 30 October 1997, (Hansard page 8196) Senator West asked me: (i) why the Australian Tax Office recently made a ruling that from 1998 adjustable beds, which are used for the frail elderly and disabled, will lose their sales tax exempt status and be subject to a 12 per cent rate, and (ii) whether up to $300 has been added to the cost of these beds.
The Commissioner of Taxation has provided me with information regarding the sales tax arrangements on adjustable beds, and I now seek leave to have this incorporated in Hansard.

The Commissioner of Taxation has advised me that there has been no change in the law. However, he advised that several private rulings have recently issued on the subject of adjustable beds, stating that the beds are taxable at the rate of 12%. The rulings will remove any confusion about the correct rate applicable to the beds. They do not reflect a change in the law.

The rulings apply to beds which look like a normal mattress and base set, but which have an electronic tilt mechanism. These beds are marketed as a comfortable alternative to the ordinary bed, and are taxed at the same rate as applies to ordinary beds; although of course they may also be used by people who are suffering from sickness or disability.

The beds covered by the ruling can be distinguished from beds which are designed and manufactured expressly for use by people who suffer from sickness, disease or disability, wheeled beds designed for use by disabled persons, or beds which are surgical appliances for use by hospitals. Such beds are exempt and will remain exempt.

It should be noted that always-exempt organisations such as public hospitals and public benevolent institutions will still be able to buy adjustable beds tax-free, even if they would normally be taxed at the rate of 12%.

Senator West also asked me whether there were any plans to change the tax exempt status of items used by sick or disabled persons. In answer to the honourable Senator's question, I confirm there are no plans to change the sales tax exemptions which currently apply to adjustable beds or any other items for use by sick or disabled persons.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —On 30 October, Senator Mackay asked me a question relating to the retrenchment of staff at the Australian Taxation Office. I have sought the comments of the Commissioner of Taxation and I seek leave to have the answer incorporated in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
On Thursday 30 October 1997 (Hansard page 8200) Senator Mackay asked me questions relating to the retrenchment of staff in the Australian Taxation Office (ATO). In particular I was asked:
(a) what criteria the ATO is using to decide which staff are to be determined as excess;
(b) whether the staff to be chosen are those deemed to be least efficient; and
(c) what is the definition of least efficient and how will it be measured.
I have sought the comments of the Commissioner of Taxation and I now seek leave to have the following answer incorporated into Hansard.

The Commissioner of Taxation has advised me that as a result of more efficient work practices and improved technology, the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) had previously identified 305 positions as being excess to requirements. Of these all but 20 have already been dealt with through a combination of redeployment and voluntary redundancy.

The Commissioner of Taxation also advised that in the areas where there are still excess staff numbers relative efficiency is being used as the criteria for determining who will be declared excess. This is consistent with the relevant provisions in the Australian Public Service, General Employment Conditions Award 1995 which state that the method of identifying an employee as excess will have regard to the efficient and economical working of the agency and the relative efficiency of employees.
Assessment of relative efficiency is being made on the basis of the following criteria:
. People Skills;
. Organisational and Administrative Skills;
. Technology;
. Thinking Skills;
. Knowledge;
. Standard of Work Performance; and
. Capacity to be retrained for other ATO work.

The actual assessment process is being undertaken by an independent committee, chaired by a former senior representative of the Merit Protection Review Agency. In making their assessment the committee will consider self assessments by the staff members involved, appraisals by their immediate manager, and an optional assessment by one or more referees nominated by each staff member. Every care is being taken to ensure that the process is, and is seen to be, totally fair and without bias.

The staff identified as excess as a result of this process will be offered voluntary redundancy on the same terms as.any other employee identified as excess. Only if this offer was not accepted and no other redeployment options were identified would those employees be subject to compulsory redundancy.

In the meantime, the ATO is continuing to work with the Public Service and Merit Protection Commission to identify redeployment prospects throughout the Australian Public Service in an effort to reduce the number of excess positions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) today, to a question without notice asked by Senator Faulkner today, relating to nursing homes.

I do not think anybody could have missed the extraordinary spectacle of the last three weeks where the Prime Minister has completely lost his authority in the eyes of the Australian people. Mr Howard has dithered and bumbled his way through selling what in fact are half‐baked nursing home policies and, of course, his efforts have left Australia's elderly both bitterly disappointed and very angry. What Australians have seen in the past couple of weeks has been poor policy driven by weak leadership, of course panicked by opinion polling. This continues the inept decision making processes—the pattern that has developed during the life of the Howard government of ill‐thought‐out policy, changes and backdowns forced upon the government by public opinion, then of course replaced by further ill‐thought‐out policy.

Of course, at the same time Mr Howard has seen fit to shoot the messengers; in the first case, Ms Moylan. She was dumped because she was completely unable to sell the nursing home policy of the Howard government that Mr Howard himself, of course, later completely rejected. Mr Smith was handed the poisoned chalice. Of course he is a factional enemy of Mr Howard. They are just two of the corpses which have littered the first 18 months of the Howard government.

But this particular policy issue has all the hallmarks of how Mr Howard does business. You have got, of course, a situation where, first of all, he is frightened by opinion polling. He gets in the results of the quantitative and qualitative polling and they scare the daylights out of him. There is no formal cabinet process, of course, when he gets those opinion poll results in front of him—no attempt to convene the cabinet, no attempt to convene cabinet committees, no consultation with his colleagues, no attempt to see the cabinet's five‐day and 10‐day rule applied at all. Those sorts of cabinet processes have been jettisoned again and again by Mr Howard, and this is a classic example.

Those sorts of processes are important policy safety valves. They provide a capacity for a Prime Minister to consult with his colleagues and for due process to be followed by any Prime Minister in any government. There was no attempt either to involve properly the Public Service in this country on these sorts of issues. There were no submissions from the relevant departments. There were no papers from the relevant departments for Mr Howard and his colleagues to consult. All that happened is that Mr Howard consulted five of his most panicked backbenchers—those who are in marginal electorates where there are elderly populations. Michael Gordon in the Weekend Australian described the result as self‐inflicted mayhem where those five did not hold back.

Mr Howard again failed to use the bureaucracy to craft policy as he should have. Then when he came to a decision, through that extraordinary process, what did he do? Did he have a full press conference? Did he put out a press release? No, he did an exclusive interview with Ray Martin. He probably thought it would be an easy go for him. But Ray Martin did not buy it. He asked the hard questions about fairness—whether the backflip was poll driven. He asked whether it was policy on the run. He said, `Doesn't this smack of panic, Prime Minister?' What did Mr Howard say? He said, `No.' That is all he could say. We know that the Prime Minister's backflip was off the high board, with a triple somersault, twist and pike, degree of difficulty of 3.6, but the elderly have not copped it. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard the most abject hypocrisy from a former Labor minister. I thought, as I sat here in question time today, that we had former minister after former minister—all of whom were responsible for the mess that the nursing homes of Australia are in—cheerfully and irresponsibly engaged in this campaign to frighten older Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: You should be ashamed of yourselves because you had the opportunity to do what is now having to be done, but you could have done it years ago. Professor Gregory told your government that so much needed to be done, that there were hundreds of millions of dollars to be spent, yet you turned your faces away from the old people of Australia and, just as unfeelingly, you have now turned your back on them by frightening the life out of them. If you cared about older Australians at all you would have done something about them when you had the opportunity in government and you would not be trying to get yourselves back into government by frightening old people.

Of course action needs to be taken; action now needs to be urgently taken because you did not do what had to be done at the time. Ms Macklin, the shadow minister, of all people, had the opportunity as a consultant to several ministers in this field to influence what should have been done during your years in government. She was being bought by the previous government to give advice for policy development. Where were her principles at that time? Where was her concern for older Australians? You should all be ashamed of yourselves.

There is a need for reform. Everybody understands the need for reform. It is no good turning around and looking as though I am not talking about you because the members on the other side are all corporately responsible for the mess that we have inherited and for the poor quality of nursing homes in Australia after 13 years of Labor government.

Do you really object to the principle that those who have the means should contribute to their care to the extent that they are able? The Association of Independent Retirees, after all, are the most likely people to be affected by this. They are the people who have saved and do have some assets, yet they came out in the press—during their national conference in Queensland a couple of weeks ago—saying that this is an overdue measure, it does need to be done, it is a difficult measure, but it is right and proper that a government takes this action. They gave us credit for the courage, for the drive and for the good policy development that you did not take.

You were a policy free zone in this area. You are even more hypocritical than appears on the face of it because you were prepared to do it for hostels. For goodness sake, what difference is there from hostels? I will tell you what the difference is: these days the people going into hostels are at about the level of frailty of people who used to go into nursing homes.

TALK.START.PARA: —What?

—If you do not know that Senator Neal then you are very ill‐informed. Over the last few years, with the ACATs being gatekeepers, if you like, it is quite clear that the people going into nursing homes now are of an even greater degree of frailty, but the people who were going into hostels when you were in government were of the level of frailty that needed—
—This is an interesting new argument.

—You were perfectly prepared to ask them, to the extent that they were able, to contribute to their care. We were a responsible opposition: we supported that move. Unfortunately for the coalition government, we have a populist, irresponsible opposition that will say anything, do anything and use old people at the same time to try to claw their way back. Sadly, that hue and cry that you have created has hidden the fact that nursing home proprietors—whether they are for profit or not for profit—just like the Association of Independent Retirees, well understand the need to deal with the policy vacuum and the results of it that we inherited.

SPEECH.PARA: It is very easy for you to try to hide the fact that the people who are financially disadvantaged—of whom it is estimated there are something like 27 per cent—will not be paying any capital injection into nursing homes. The Commonwealth will be providing $12 per day on top of what they already pay to support those people. Let it not be forgotten, the Commonwealth is paying $2.6 billion per annum into the care of elderly people already and more still is needed. How much more are you asking the taxpayer to provide? Why will you not allow people who have the means to contribute to do just that? You are hypocrites, every single one of you.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Newman, your use of the word `hypocrite' is unparliamentary. Would you withdraw it please?
—I can imagine it is unpleasant.
—An unconditional withdrawal, thank you, Minister.
—I unconditionally withdraw it. It obviously hurts Senator Ray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The previous speaker alludes to the fact that I asked for that to be withdrawn, Madam Deputy President. I have never asked for anything to be withdrawn in this place, and she knows it. It was good to hear Senator Newman come out of the closet and be the last remaining supporter of up-front fees. Well done in defying the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), Senator Newman. After all, this is the same Prime Minister that took responsibility off you in this chamber for health and family services. He thought you were doing such a lousy job at it that he transferred it to Senator Herron. What an insult to you, Senator Newman. The least competent minister in this chamber gets part of your responsibilities because you were not up to answering any questions. But it is good to know you still support up-front fees.

SPEECH.PARA: What we have had in politics in the last few weeks is the Prime Minister going around this country saying, `Look, we're not going to alter on this. I'm going to show you I'm a real leader. I am tough. I am principled. Sorry, no change to this whatsoever.' What happened when the going got tough? He threw one of the Liberal ministers off the sled to the wolves. That was Mrs Moylan. She was thrown off. She was sacrificed and all blamed was attached to her, and that was going to be the end of the story.

Then a few weeks later the Prime Minister goes overseas. What happens next? His colleagues here modify the scheme. The Prime Minister, looking like he was at a grouse hunt at St Andrews, assured everyone that there would be no further changes. But as soon as he gets back to Australia, the real panic starts—the panic Wednesday. Wouldn't you love to be the Prime Minister's dry cleaner on that particular day!

What you have is a total breakdown in government process. It is bad enough that this government adopted a five‐day cabinet rule instead of a 10‐day rule. But we all know that virtually no items in this current coalition government meet the five‐day rule. They are brought up under the line `in cabinet' because they are so paranoid that some details of the submission might leak. Therefore, you do not get detailed submissions with options any more; you get broad principles and `we will fill in the details later'.

That is exactly what happened last Wednesday. There was no cabinet meeting on this particular subject. There were no departmental submissions, no departmental coord comments on those submissions. So there was no detail worked out. The only detail was the political imperative, having read the polls: how do we get out from under?

BREAK.PARA: The Prime Minister took charge. What did he do? He did two things. He rang five marginal seat holders dotted around the country to ask them for their views on this particular subject. He rang two or three members of the Expenditure Review Committee. He did not ring Senator Hill or Senator Alston and ask them for their views. He certainly did not ring Senator Herron.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or Senator Newman.

—Or Senator Newman. Thank you for your assistance. None of those got a say in this. Mr Smith did. Mr Costello did. I doubt he would have bothered with Mr Fahey. Why would you?—but maybe he did. He rang a couple of others—some marginal seat holders. It was then a matter of `OK, we'll dump all this.'

BREAK.PARA: `How are we going to sell this?' They have nothing in writing. They have no submissions. They put out no press release on it. They had no press conference on it. They slide into the A Current Affair program, having given them notice at 10 a.m. Even then he got done over by Ray Martin, not always the most vicious inquisitor of prime ministers. But fancy getting done by Ray Martin on that show. He could not answer the questions. I would have thought that from last Wednesday till today they would have developed some answers—just a few answers of detail. But, no, we get no answers. `What we are going to do is do some consultation next Thursday and fill in the gaps.

We have had the pathetic excuse for a minister, Senator Herron, come in here today completely out of his depth. He had all last night to look at the detail of this. He knows absolutely nothing about these particular issues.

What we see in this is not just a government backflip. Governments do backflip from time to time on issues. What we are seeing is a total breakdown in the process of government. If this government would take detailed submissions with the views of other departments and discuss them around the table, those sorts of panic reactions by a weak Prime Minister would no longer be necessary. What the Prime Minister showed last week is that 24 years of political preparation have left a total muddle. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz, Sen Eric

TALK.START.PARA: —So far in this debate we have heard from two former failed Labor ministers. One thing that they did not tell us about was what their cabinet consideration and ministerial consideration was when Mr Willis introduced funding changes for the hostel system on 8 November 1990. This is what Mr Willis had to say:

SPEECH.PARA: New funding arrangements were introduced in January 1989 which enable hostels to charge residents entry contributions and ongoing fees according to their ability to pay.

Where did you stand on that, Senator Faulkner? Did you stand up and fight in the ministerial room on that one? What is the bet Senator Ray did not either. Yet they have the indecency to come into this chamber and pretend that they are against such a system. Indeed, Mr Willis went on to say:
Under these new arrangements hostels can receive higher fees from non‐financially disadvantaged residents who are better placed to contribute to costs of their care.

The abolition of the subsidy to those not financially disadvantaged will enable Commonwealth funds to be targeted to financially disadvantaged persons needing hostel care and on those needing a higher level of personal care.

That is what ultimately motivated this government's policy in that area. In pursuing that line, we have noted that there has been some community reaction to the basis of the way we intend to implement that general proposal. As a result, we as a government have reacted and acknowledged that we have made a mistake.

But have you ever heard Senator Faulkner or Senator Ray in their contributions in this place acknowledging that, under their previous government, it was a mistake to make the huge prime ministerial promise that `no child shall live in poverty by the year 1990'? Where is their apology? Where is their acknowledgment that that was wrong? Remembering that they were both senior ministers in the previous government, where is their apology for telling us that the budget was in surplus when going to the last election in 1996? We know that was absolutely and utterly wrong—and they knew it. A $10.3 billion deficit was what awaited us. But did they have the decency to apologise for that? No.

So I say to the Australian people—through you, Madam Deputy President—that, when we make mistakes, we as a government are willing to acknowledge having done so and say so to the people of Australia, unlike the former government. Listen to some of these words of wisdom. Do you remember Gary Gray? He was your federal secretary, wasn't he? He said on Four Corners:
If we had on more occasions as a government said that we were sorry and acknowledged where we had got things wrong, then the results in the March election of last year would have been very different.
You failed to acknowledge your mistakes. What about former Senator Loosley? He said:

Mistakes were made and the wrong course was sometimes adopted, and such a concession needs to be stated clearly and bluntly by Kim Beazley and his team. The Labor Party should simply acknowledge that in 13 years in office there were errors of judgment and policy failures.
It is quite clear to Gary Gray and to former Senator Stephen Loosley that mistakes will be made. When they are made, you ought to acknowledge them and get on with the job. That is what we have done.

But what do we hear from the other side? Quite frankly, I could not determine why senators Faulkner and Ray were so upset at us for changing our policy. I thought in the previous three weeks the whole thrust of their argument was that we needed to change the policy. Now that we have changed the policy, they are the ones doing the reverse backflip with a 3.6 rate of difficulty. They are upset that we have made a change to policy because they thought it might have been a leg‐up for them at the next election. Now that that has been taken away from them, they are disappointed—not for the elderly people whom they claimed they were representing, but they are concerned for their own poll driven concerns.

We have changed our policy. We have changed. We have made the response to the community that they were expecting from us. Instead of being congratulated by the other side, what do we hear? More crocodile tears—this time though without any concern for the elderly; only for themselves. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —On the same matter: I think Senator Abetz's contorted logic really does not deserve a response other than to say that, if he is so keen on apologies, I look forward to the government's apology to the dispossessed Aboriginal people which he so rails against on other occasions.

SPEECH.PARA: The answer from Senator Hill today was totally inadequate in terms of any attempt to explain what process was followed in this most lamentable of episodes. The process is important, because it is important to good government. But it is also important that the detail of this final or third decision is made known to the very many Australians who are still concerned and bewildered about the government's position.

It is all very well to say, `We made a mistake.' That is laudable in one sense. But having said that you made a mistake, you have to then say what your policy is now, what you have done to fix up the mistake. What we saw from Senator Herron today in the eight or nine chances he had to have a go at it was that he could not explain that decision. He could not tell us. He said, `We made a mistake.' I am not sure whether that was the first time, the second time or, this occasion, the third go they have had at it.

But what he was not able to say is what the mistake was. He was not able to say, `Well, we've now fixed it, and this is the detail.' There is no detail available, so we have a lamentable process and we still have a policy position where the government cannot explain to elderly Australians what their policy in relation to nursing home fees and charges is. I think that is a disgrace. It is leaving a lot of elderly Australians, as well as a lot of people who care for them, very upset and concerned.

We have seen pretty shoddy government in the past on a range of issues. But perhaps among the worst claims able to be made about government decision making has been that it is government by press release. People say, `All we have is a press release that announces government decision.' On this occasion we did not even get the press release. The Prime Minister, Mr Howard, went on A Current Affair to explain the decision, but he did not have enough grasp of the detail, he did not have enough information available, to put out a press release. They usually are only one‐page long. There usually is not a lot of detail once you get past the rhetoric in them. But he did not have enough detail to put out a press release explaining the position.

What we got from the Minister representing the Minister for Family Service in the Senate today would not fill up a one-page press release in terms of the detail available. We still do not know what the policy position of the government is. There is no information available to us to understand or deal with the implications of this policy.

It is all very well to make a mistake. They did. They made a mistake with the mark 1 proposal, they made a mistake with the mark 2 proposal, and I know that they made a mistake with mark 3 as well. But they do not know what that mistake is yet because they do not know what the policy is. When we find out what that is, we will find out also that they made a further mistake.

What is interesting though is the process that was followed here. It was explained in the Weekend Australian in a fascinating article. Apparently, rather than have a cabinet meeting to deal with the community concern, to address the policy issues, the Prime Minister phoned five backbenchers. He did not have a cabinet meeting, nor did he call for submissions from public servants. He did not look for detailed intricate work about the financial implications. He rang five backbenchers.

Senator Campbell, do you know whom he rang in Western Australia? He rang Richard Evans, the member for Cowan. I am sure that you are as aggrieved as the cabinet members were that they were overlooked in favour of Richard Evans. As we well know, this member is known for two things; he is known for plagiarism and wanting to kill cats. This is the man he rang. Forget the cabinet process; forget the advice of public servants. He rang the member for Cowan, Richard Evans, who, as I say, is famous for two things: plagiarism, and wanting to kill people's cats.

At least when the Prime Minister rang Mr Evans he knew that he would not be arguing his own opinion; he would not be putting forward his own case. That is one thing you could be sure of. Whatever he said to the Prime Minister would not have been his own original proposition. At least, therefore, the Prime Minister was testing a wider market.

But really, some elderly people have only two things left in their lives: their pet—often a cat—and their home. And the Prime Minister rings the bloke who wants to kill their cat to ask him about whether he should protect their home. Leave us alone! This is the advice sought; this is the process—and this is government—under John Howard's prime ministership.
