He rang the bloke who wants to kill your parents' cat to get advice about your parents' home.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. Senator Evans should at least recognise the fact that many old people keep budgerigars and that the member for Cowan clearly cares deeply about budgerigars in his quest to kill cats.
—There is no point of order.

—I am not sure what the member for Cowan is fond of, but certainly he wants to kill cats. As I say, having the same surname as him in Western Australia can be quite dangerous, because a lot of people are very upset about that. This is the sort of quality policy advice that the Prime Minister seeks. This is the basis on which he has made his decision to have a third go at arrangements for nursing home entry in this country. It is a national disgrace; it is policy on the run, and Mr Howard ought to think very seriously about whether he is up to the job of Prime Minister. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman, Sen Grant

TALK.START.PARA: —What we have just heard from Senator Evans exemplifies what the Labor Party is about on this issue, and that is simply a campaign of scare, scare, scare. There is no substance in the campaign, no alternative to offer. As the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron) said in answering several questions on this issue today in question time, it is simply a case of all scare and no responsibility. This has been run by the opposition for weeks and weeks, and it has simply been repeated today in question time and in this subsequent taking note of answers debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, this is all Labor have to offer these days—it is their modus operandi. Remember the campaign of fear and loathing we were promised by the labour movement on industrial relations and on so many other issues? This is all they can do. They cannot offer anything positive, any alternative; all they do is create a scare campaign on falsely based premises about government initiatives.

It is in that context, therefore, that we ought to look at Labor's record on this issue—what they did when they were in government. After 13 years of neglect under Labor governments—the Hawke and the Keating Labor governments—this government came to office determined to address the poor state of nursing homes that had arisen as a direct result of that 13 years of neglect. And what was the result—

TALK.START.PARA: —And look what you did. Are you embarrassed? You look embarrassed.

—The opposition leader in the Senate interjects with his usual nonsense. What was the result of those 13 years of neglect? The result was: substandard conditions in many nursing homes throughout this country; 40 per cent of residents having to share wards of four people or more; 13 per cent of facilities not meeting fire standards; 75 per cent of nursing homes not meeting all design and building codes; and 15 per cent of nursing homes not meeting health standards.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, that was because, under the Labor government, capital expenditure funding was cut substantially. In 1992‐93, $45 million was available for capital purposes for nursing homes. By 1995‐96, Labor's last year in office, this had dropped to $10.7 million—a 75 per cent reduction in funding under that neglectful previous Labor government. That government completely abrogated its responsi bility to upgrade nursing homes. It is as a consequence of that that this government has to deliver reforms to provide the standard of nursing home accommodation that older Australians are entitled to—to provide improved comfort, improved safety and dignity to older Australians in their later years. So that neglect needs to be put squarely on the record.

My colleague Senator Abetz referred a few moments ago to the comments of Mr Willis when he introduced the changes to hostel accommodation by the previous Labor government, the principle of which is being applied by this government to nursing homes. So the principle is exactly the same.

Let us hear what another Labor icon has said about this issue. Let us hear what a former senator, the much venerated former Minister for Finance, former Senator Walsh, said about this issue in an article in a March issue of the Financial Review. He suggested that the government should recover from deceased estates the full cost of nursing home care. He said that, `as well as gaining revenue, this will appreciably reduce demand for beds and therefore costs.' That is what Labor icon, former Senator Walsh, said on this issue. There are the views of Labor operatives on this matter.

In contrast to that, the present government is addressing the issue. We have acknowledged that, in the detail of the administration of our policy, mistakes have been made—and that is something else about Labor: it never admits mistakes—and we are putting in place a policy that will benefit older Australians. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Logging and Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
For permanent protection of old‐growth forests and all other areas of high conservation value, and for the implementation of tree plantation strategies.

This petition from the undersigned respectfully points out that: there is an increasing and urgent demand from the people, to protect all remaining high conservation value forests which support flora and fauna unique to Australia, thus complying with the United Nations Biodiversity Convention to which Australia is a signatory. We have a responsibility to future and present generations, and the necessary reasons, knowledge and technology to act now on the following achievable solutions.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate legislate to:

PARA.TAB: immediately stop all logging and woodchipping activities in high conservation value native forests;

ensure intergenerational equity by planning for the rights of future generations, and protecting in perpetuity all biologically diverse old‐growth forests, wilderness, rainforests and critical habitats of endangered species;

facilitate rapid transition of the timber industry from harvesting high conservation value native forests, to establishing mixed‐species farm forestry on existing cleared and degraded lands, using non‐toxic methods to protect ecological sustainability;

maximise use of readily‐available plantation timber for industry needs, using appropriate forestry techniques and progressive minimal‐waste processing methods, such as radial sawing, and wherever possible, reuse and recycle wood and paper products;

support incentives for nationwide employment in composting, soil remineralisation programs, and the planting programs of trees and annual fibre crops, inter‐grown with appropriate fruit and nut trees and medicinal plants;

encourage sensitively‐managed, environmental education tourism in appropriate forest areas, with full respect for natural ecosystems, Aboriginal cultural heritage, sacred sites and other sites of significance; and

progressively utilise technological expertise and resources transferred from the military sector, to help implement these tree planting solutions; and to motivate the international community to follow this example.

PETITION.PARA: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Native Title
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned showeth:
That the proposed amendments to the Native Title Act 1993 are an unacceptable violation of the human rights of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander People.
Your petitioners therefor pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should call on the Federal Government:
To reject in their entirety the Native Title Act (Amendments) Bill 1997.

The statements read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: PUBLIC EMPLOYMENT (CONSEQUENTIAL AND TRANSITIONAL) AMENDMENT BILL 1997

SPEECH.PARA: The Public Service Bill 1997 provides for the establishment and management of the Australian Public Service (APS) and is to replace the Public Service Act 1922 and the Merit Protection (Australian Government Employees) Act 1984.

The Public Employment (Consequential and Transitional) Amendment Bill 1997 deals with consequential and transitional matters arising from the repeal of the Public Service Act 1922 and the enactment of the Public Service Act 1997. The bill is a necessary companion to the Public Service Bill 1997.

The bills were introduced into the House of Representatives on 26 June 1997 and referred immediately to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts (JCPA) for consideration and report by 4 September 1997. The JCPA subsequently sought and was granted an extension of its reporting time and its report was subsequently tabled on 29 September 1997.

The Second Reading debate on the bills was then scheduled to be resumed in the week commencing 13 October 1997. However it was decided that the bills should proceed in cognate debate together with the Parliamentary Service Bill 1997 and the Parliamentary Service (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1997. Accordingly debate on the Public Service Bill 1997 and the Public Employment (Consequential and Transitional) Amendment Bill 1997 was delayed until the week commencing 27 October 1997. The bills passed through the House of Representatives on 30 October 1997.

The bills are regarded as an essential element of the Government's micro-economic reform strategy and failure to pass them in the 1997 Spring sittings would frustrate the introduction of efficiencies and economies to the Australian Public Service which were to be facilitated by the bills. It would create uncertainty among managers and staff in APS agencies who have been involved in a significant consultation process over the last twelve months and have been anticipating the commencement of the legislation on 1 January 1998.
This statement is circulated with the authority of the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

The Parliamentary Service Bill 1997 provides for the establishment and management of a parliamentary service separate from the Australian Public Service, and is to replace the Public Service Act 1922. The Parliamentary Service (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1997 deals with consequential and transitional matters arising from the repeal of the Public Service Act 1922.

The bills were introduced in the House of Representatives on 23 October 1997 and were passed by the House on 30 October 1997, together with the Public Service Bill 1997 and the Public Employment (Consequential and Transitional) Amendment Bill 1997.

The Parliamentary Service bills establish a separate employment framework for staff in the parliamentary departments on the basis that their allegiance is to the Houses of the Parliament rather than the government of the day. The separate framework established by the bills reflects changes proposed in the Public Service bills except where differences are necessary to reflect the different obligations and conditions of parliamentary service.

It is highly desirable that the Parliamentary Service bills be considered by the Senate at the same time as the Public Service bills so that the new parliamentary service can come into being at the same time as new arrangements come into being for the Public Service. Delay in passage of the bills would result in parliamentary staff continuing to come under the provisions of the Public Service Act 1922 while their counterparts in the public service would be moving to the new arrangements set out in the Public Service bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The Prime Minister's poor handling of the appointment of the Chairperson of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation, in particular, the failure to consult as required under the terms of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation Act 1991.

The issue we are debating today is quite specific: it is not about whether Pat Dodson or Evelyn Scott, or any other person, should be appointed as Chairperson of the Council of Aboriginal Reconciliation; it is about whether or not our Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has any respect for the law. I believe that the events surrounding the CAR controversy shows that he does not, and for that he should be condemned by the Senate today.

For those senators who are still yet to decide how, or whether, to vote on my motion, it is important that I restate the facts which back up my charge. The Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation Act 1991 requires the minister to consult with ATSIC, the Leader of the Opposition and the Leader of the Australian Democrats on appointments to the council. Last Monday, the Acting Leader of the Democrats (Senator Lees) received a letter from the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron) which outlined the process of, and timetable for, consultation under the law—the CAR act 1991. I quote in part from this letter:
I have attached a list of persons being considered for possible appointment for the third term of Council . . .

Following my consultations as specified by the Act, the process of appointment requires that I write to the Prime Minister requesting his approval or consideration by Cabinet of the recommended appointments before forwarding the names to the Governor-General, who is responsible for appointing the Chairman, and other members referred to . . .
I would appreciate your considering the attached list of names and replying to me in writing by 12 November 1997, in order that I can complete the process in the available timeframe.
In passing, I should say that the attached list was marked confidential, and we have respected that.

Last Friday, however, we found out from the Prime Minister's own mouth at a press conference here in Canberra that the deal was already done—prior to the Australian Democrats receiving the minister's letter and apparently without the minister being involved. On the possible reappointment of Pat Dodson to the position of chairman, the Prime Minister said:

It's too late. Nobody has the right to bargain indefinitely with the Government on anything. I bent over backwards to secure this man's reappointment, but his opportunity to accept reappointment was last Sunday night.
I bent over backwards; I tried; I wanted him in but he said no last Sunday night and naturally I had to go ahead and make alternative arrangements.
I'm sorry he knocked me back last Sunday night, but he did.

So now we know. According to the Prime Minister he had no need to consult under the CAR Act 1991. It was his to offer, and his to offer on Sunday night a week ago—before the formal consultation process, as required by law, had even commenced.

In short, this is a very clear-cut case of contempt for the law by the Prime Minister, and he should be condemned accordingly. I do not blame the minister at all. I have no evidence, yet, that he knew what his leader was doing. I know only of his letter which proposed a quite reasonable process.

But whilst the minister was prepared to follow the law, the Prime Minister was not. The law says `consult first' and `decide second'; the Prime Minister acted to `decide first' and `consult last'. I suspect we have already heard the government's defence on this motion in the minister's answer to a question from Senator Bolkus today, when he said in effect, `Well, when you were in government you did it this way too!' That is just not good enough. The law should be observed, no matter who is in government. I refer government senators to an earlier answer given by the minister to Senator Ferris, where he said:
It is important to consider that the Council was established with unanimous cross party support.

It was. It is a tragedy that the Prime Minister has not listened to his own minister on this issue. If he had, perhaps he would not have flouted both the letter of the law and the spirit of the CAR model, by taking the law unto himself on that Sunday night. This is not good enough.

The Democrats are pursuing this issue because we believe that reconciliation is at a crossroads in this country. I wonder whether this government has any vision at all for reconciliation. I believe that the government has divided the Aboriginal people, it has divided city and country, and it has divided the nation. I, like the Governor-General, am fearful for our nation and for its spirit. I weep for our nation if reconciliation falls apart completely. I only hope that we do not end up weeping tears of blood.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very disappointed with this urgency motion on the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation. I suspect that the motion has arisen because Senator Woodley is not aware of the sequence of events nor of the requirements of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation Act 1991. For Senator Woodley and for the record I will read the requirements of the act. Under section 14, it says:

BREAK.PARA: (2) The Chairperson, Deputy Chairperson and the members referred to in paragraph (1) (h) above are to be appointed by the Governor‐General.
(3) Any advice to the Governor‐General regarding such appointments is only to be given after the Minister has consulted:
(a) the Leader of the Opposition in the House of Representatives; and
(b) the leader of any non‐Government party in the Parliament of at least 5 members that is not part of the Opposition; and
(c) the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission.
It saddens me that Senator Woodley seeks to politicise this very important issue. I ask that he listen carefully to what I have to say.

Reconciliation is far too precious to be damaged in this way. I repeat what I said on Friday in a statement released to the media: as a nation, we simply cannot afford to have reconciliation damaged in the political arena. I ask those who have been politicising this issue to stop and to think seriously about the implications of their actions.

As all senators would know, the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation Act requires the minister to consult the Leader of the Opposition, the Leader of the Democrats and ATSIC before advising the Governor‐General regarding appointments to the council. The terms of the current council members expire next month, and it is therefore appropriate that this consultation process be concluded soon.

I commenced the process on 25 September 1997, when I wrote to the chairman of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission inviting suggestions from the commission for possible appointments to the third council. The ATSIC chairman replied to my letter on 9 October 1997 with a list of possible nominees for my consideration.

During September I also asked the Office of Indigenous Affairs to inquire informally of the current council members who would be willing to continue or interested in continuing to serve during the third term. Although not strictly necessary, the purpose of this exercise was to determine the minimum number of new members who would be required.

It was always my view that in order to maintain some continuity in the council we should seek to reappoint some members, but that it would be desirable to also identify some new members who would bring freshness and new energy to the process. This appears to have also been the view of the previous government which appointed nine new people out of the 20 possible appointments for the second term.

I note that Senator Woodley is not here to listen to this, but I trust that one of his advisers will listen and will convey the information to him. I table the letter received from my predecessor in relation to this. You will see from that letter that I followed the same sequence as did Mr Robert Tickner, my predecessor.

That letter was sent on 4 October 1994, and I understand that it was received on 5 October 1994. The letter proposed both the chair and the deputy chair, just as my letter did. The proposed deputy chair was also a proposed new appointment. The letter asked for a reply from the nominees by 10 October, nine days after it was received. As I indicated, there was no real consultation, because the minister at the time nominated the number of names required to fill the council. So there was no consultation. In contrast, I issued a list—

TALK.START.PARA: —Untrue!

—I am tabling the letter. It is underwritten by Mr Tickner. In contrast, I issued a list of 50 or so names, seeking comment and suggestions from the opposition. The process I have undertaken is much more open, fair and consultative than that undertaken by the previous government, and it is in complete accord with the act. To suggest otherwise is hypocrisy of the worst kind and brands those opposite as people who are trying to score cheap political points off the reconciliation process. I think it is too important to be a political football.

BREAK.PARA: To come back to the appointments, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and I met with Mr Dodson and Mr Viner on 27 August to discuss the outcomes of the Australian reconciliation convention and the council's work in its final term. After that meeting, I invited Mr Dodson to provide me with suggestions for membership of the new council.

On 23 September 1997, I also wrote to Mr Dodson as chairman of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation, seeking his input regarding the composition of the third council, and again inviting him to provide me with a list of people he considered suitable and worthy of consideration by the government for appointment.

Although I met with Mr Dodson on 15 October and again on 27 October—and despite his undertaking to me to do so—I still have not received a list of proposed appointees from Mr Dodson. At our meeting on 27 October, he gave no indication that he did not intend to continue as chairman of the council. Three days later, however, on Thursday, 30 October, I received letters by fax from both Mr Dodson and Mr Viner advising that they did not wish to be considered for reappointment to the third council.

I replied to Mr Dodson and Mr Viner on the evening of Thursday, 30 October acknowledging their letter and thanking them both for their dedicated efforts. I do not think anybody would not agree that they have been dedicated and that their efforts have been to great effect.

At subsequent meetings with me and with the Prime Minister on 2 November, Mr Dodson confirmed his decision and indicated that he would not reconsider. In other words, Mr Dodson was given two opportunities—one in a meeting with me on the Friday after I received his letter, and another with the Prime Minister on the Sunday—to reconsider his decision, and he decided against doing so.

In the light of that, and because of the tight time frame in which we were working, I made contact with Ms Evelyn Scott and Sir Gustav Nossal to inquire whether, if asked, they would be willing for the government to nominate them for the positions of chair and deputy respectively. As I have mentioned, that was the same sequence as with the letter that went from Mr Robert Tickner to the Leader of the Opposition at the time when both the chairman of the reconciliation council and the deputy chairman were named in that list. The total number was the number of people to be nominated.

On 3 November, following the Prime Minister's meeting the previous evening with Mr Dodson, I wrote to the leaders of the opposition and of the Australian Democrats about the proposed appointments and, as I mentioned, I enclosed a list of over 50 names for consideration, including the government's nominated chair and deputy. I invited any comments they may have regarding the list of proposed members and any further names they would like to have considered.

On Friday 7 November, over a week after Mr Dodson's letter saying no to reappointment, the Prime Minister received another letter by fax, dated 6 November, from Mr Dodson, indicating that he had reconsidered and would be prepared to accept reappointment on a number of terms and preconditions. Bear in mind that this was after Ms Scott and Sir Gustav Nossal had been contacted.

As the Prime Minister explained during his press conference last Friday evening, it was too late to bargain over those positions as the government had already spoken to Ms Scott and Sir Gustav Nossal and they are the nominated chair and deputy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you asked Evelyn Scott what she thinks about that, if Pat Dodson was prepared to stay on? I bet you haven't.
—Order! Senator Collins, I notice that you will have a chance to contribute to this debate at a later stage. I would ask you to please refrain from interjecting.

—Despite claims to the contrary, the government is undertaking a far greater level of consultation with the opposition parties than occurred during the previous government. We have sought to engage the other political leaders much earlier in the process as well. Once we have considered the views of the leaders of the Democrats and the opposition, the government will finalise its proposed list of appointees and will discuss this with the other parties before finalising the appointments. As the act says, the appointments are made by the Governor‐General on the recommendations. That is the process we are following.

BREAK.PARA: The process that has been followed complies completely with requirements of the act and the handling of this matter by the government has been completely correct and proper. I can understand Senator Woodley not being aware of this as he has just been given the portfolio by the lady who went to another party and who had filled that previously.

TALK.START.PARA: —Your consultations took about two days to run.

—Our consultations were a lot better than what you did with the Democrats when you took their leader from them. I wrote to the Democrats and the Labor Party on Monday afternoon, 3 November. On Tuesday morning, who should pop up in the ABC news to criticise some of the proposed amendments but Senator Woodley! Not only that, the same ABC news item included the names of the proposed chair, Evelyn Scott, and the proposed deputy chair, Sir Gustav Nossal.

BREAK.PARA: My office contacted Senator Woodley's office expressing concern at this breach of protocol and received an assurance that it had not come from the Democrats. Considering that Mr Beazley's office had not even opened the letter containing the names until close to noon that day and that only the Democrats and Mr Beazley had copies of the list, we can only ponder on where the ABC got its information from.

This leads me back to the point I made earlier. It saddens me that this very important issue has been politicised. Again, I would ask those who have been politicising this issue to stop and think seriously about the implications of their actions. Reconciliation is far too important to be damaged in this way. I have stated my views, and I would be happy to provide copies to those opposite of a very important publication that was put out, `Reconciliation: is it possible?' (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard a pathetic response from the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron), a minister who misses the point. I am pleased today to be able to support Senator Woodley's motion and to be able to speak to it. I think the point that we should all be addressing here today is not the legal niceties that Senator Herron tries to skate over in respect of this motion. They had a legal responsibility, but we in this place have more than just a legal responsibility. I would contend that they have not met that legal responsibility. I would also contend that Senator Herron today has actually embroiled himself in a bit of an inconsistency, which I will get to later. We have a responsibility here, one which we do not always realise we have. When we do not fulfil it, we are failing our obligation to show leadership in the national interest.

SPEECH.PARA: I was quite depressed last Friday night. I was watching television and, as I watched the news, I saw the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) talking about having a double dissolution based on the Wik legislation. I have to say to anyone who is really concerned about this society that that is not the way we have to go. It was depressing because we really should be putting ourselves above the playing of politics with a race card, which we seem to be well on the road to doing in this country. We—all of us, wherever we come from—have responsibilities to act for the Australian people and to try to build cohesiveness in this society. The Prime Minister's response to the bad week of Aboriginal politics—a week when we saw the Wik legislation once again unravelling, a week when we saw the incompetent handling of the reconciliation council issue—was to unnecessarily lead us down a road which would be quite destructive to this society.

Playing the race issue is explosive. We do not have to do it. I have always thought that in trouble this Prime Minister would be too tempted not to resort to it, but I always hoped that he would not and I always hoped that this government would pull back from it. I think it is going to be very depressing for our nation if we do embark upon a race campaign, particularly as we lead up to the centenary of Federation, the Sydney Olympics and the new millennium, and particularly given the diversity of our society with one in four people coming from a non‐English speaking background.

Unfortunately, this government plough on, insensitive to community concern, insensitive to constitutional requirements, and insensitive to the requirements of decency and honesty in the conduct of government and the handling of people. They plough on regardless of national or international opinion. As they go down that road, the infrastructure that is necessary for decency in our society disintegrates.

If you look at the events of the last few weeks with the reconciliation council—and these are the events that Senator Herron did not discuss—you see what has led to the falling apart, the disintegration, of the process and the people. You only have to go back to the letters of 30 October from Mr Dodson and Mr Viner to see what was really happening and why they were concerned—not about the process in itself but also about what was happening in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —You said you didn't have them. You lied.
—Pat Dodson wrote to Minister Herron on 30 October informing him, and I quote—
—You lied during question time. You said you didn't have them. You lied.
—Order!
—He didn't hear me.
—I heard it but I ignored it.
—Order! Senator Herron, I think you should withdraw that.
—I withdraw.

—Pat Dodson wrote on 30 October, `It has been extremely worrying to have watched the present government actively pulling apart the delicate threads of reconciliation that many Australians have been weaving into a beautiful garment. The attempt to diminish the status and rights of Aboriginal people in this country will not see history record great praise of this period.'

SPEECH.PARA: Ian Viner went on with a very succinct exposition of the problems at hand. He wrote to Minister Herron saying, `I feel, and I know that Mr Dodson feels, that the government will lose a wonderful opportunity for good in Australia if it continues on its present path. There must be a change of heart, a change of understanding and a change of direction by the government on Hansonism, the stolen generations, native title, indigenous disadvantage and the acceptance of the cultural identity of ATSI peoples within our democratic and constitutional structures if the government is to give leadership to all Australians.' We are not just talking here of a process which did not just follow the procedures laid down by the law. We are talking here of a deeper and greater concern that these responsible people had—concern at the way this government was handling a very important and sensitive area.

There is concern, I think, that reflects the fact that indigenous Australians have been treated as second‐class citizens by this government. When you look at the whole debate on Wik, for instance, sure, they had meetings with them, they visited with them and sat in the same room with them, but they were not listening, they were not tuned in. As a result, not one substantive concern of indigenous people in respect of the Wik legislation was picked up by the government.

They are still not listening. Last week we had the Prime Minister on TV saying, `Wik is not a racial issue; it is a land management and investment‐security‐welfare of Australia issue.' If it is not a race issue, why are you legislating under the race power of the constitution? Could you give us an answer to that? It is very much an issue of race. It is an issue through which legislation introduced by this parliament discriminates against one racial group, takes away their property, does not provide just terms, does it retrospectively and does it in breach of international covenants that we are responsible for through breaches of non‐discriminatory obligations. Of course it is a race issue, but either the Prime Minister does not understand or does not want to understand. As I say, they went through the motions.

The defenders of black people are vilified, whether they be opposition or independent senators, community organisations, the Australian Law Reform Commission and other arms of government, or religious leaders in this country. But the opponents of indigenous Australians are protected, even if the voices of the opponents are the voices of people such as Pauline Hanson, the voice of prejudice and hatred.

To this government, Pauline Hanson's voice is protected whilst religious leaders of this country are attacked. The voices of decency really carry no weight in this debate, and that, I think, should be of concern to all of us in this place and to the broader community. No wonder the rest of the world is starting to look at Australia, and that it is starting to look at us with concern.

Let us be clear about what is happening here. The wider context is the one I mentioned of Aboriginal Australians not being treated as equal citizens. Secondly, let us look at the damage we are doing here. Pat Dodson is an important, eminent, well‐respected Australian. He is also representative of a whole range of people like him, whether it be the Dodsons, the O'Donoghues, Pat Turner, Tracker Tilmouth, Peter Yu, Mick Dodson and, of course, Noel Pearson—and I could go down the list. These people are part of a leadership of indigenous Australians which has been keen to work with government for a co‐existence outcome and for a consensual outcome. These are leaders who have been under immense pressure—and the pressure goes on.

These people have been delivering to this nation for a long time, but what do they get for it? They get vilified and abused. And when Noel Pearson bells the cat he gets even more abuse. We are losing an opportunity to build this society into a cohesive society when we ditch the talents of the Dodsons, all the others that I mentioned, and the emerging group of young indigenous leaders. We cannot deliver a consensual outcome without them. Your government is burning them. You are not listening to them; you only respond to them with closed ears. You tune into another network, and you vilify them when they get too loud.

The other concern is that this government does not like people criticising it. I think it was an amazing performance last week when we had church leader after church leader on record expressing their concern about how indigenous affairs are treated in this country. And what is the Prime Minister's response? The Prime Minister says, `At the end of the day nobody owns the moral conscience of this nation.' He says, `Let us just denigrate them on the way through. Let us tell religious leaders they have really no monopoly over the moral conscience of this nation.' I would suggest that they do not claim to have a monopoly over the moral conscience of the nation, but what a message for the Prime Minister of Australia to send to young people of this country—that religious leaders have no real insight into the moral conscience of this nation.

It is a dereliction and a failure of leadership. Why does he do it? He does it because, at the start of the week, we had religious leader after religious leader—for instance, Reverend Tim Costello—expressing concern at the divisive, destructive racial conflicts that we are seeing in the current debate. We had the Catholic church, the Archbishop of Perth, the Australian Catholic Bishops Congress all speaking, as if with one voice, and saying, `Hold on and pause; this is very destructive stuff.' But what is the Prime Minister's response—`Don't listen to them because they have no rights over the moral conscience of the nation.' A bit of respect for the archbishops, the bishops, the preachers and so on by the Prime Minister would also be useful in terms of the society we are trying to build together here.

We maintain that we do not need a double dissolution. We maintain that Australia will be the loser if we go down that road. If anyone wants any evidence at all about the way we are being seen in the rest of the world, one only has to read a Hong Kong newspaper editorial of just a couple of days ago. It is worth putting this on the record because I think it is important for all of us to have it in our minds as we vote on this motion this afternoon, and also as we progress the issue before us. Of a proposal by former Prime Minister Hawke to have a united voice of prime ministers against Pauline Hanson, the Hong Kong Standard editorial says:
If these former Australian leaders have joined the fight against bigotry, it must surely worry Asian people that Prime Minister John Howard has refused to join it . . .
It goes on to say:

What Asia wants is assurances from Australian leaders of today that they condemn the Hanson platform and that it will never become official policy. "When today's prime minister refuses to join his political elders, we need to ask why. Is it because he privately shares the views of Ms Hanson and is reluctant to publicly condemn them?

It does not matter what the truth or the reality is, what we are doing is sending mixed messages and mixed signals on the question of race to our region and to the rest of the world at a critical time in our development.

We have some real problems here. There are problems in that the government did not go through the forms of the legislation, problems that the government is not responding to real concerns, and problems that even go to an expression of concern by the Governor‐General, the person holding the highest office within this country. It was said in the Melbourne Age on 8 November:

There are of those who believe that the Queen's representative should not be involved in controversial issues. Certainly, governors‐general should not become involved in party political matters. But if they cannot speak out about matters like reconciliation, what then is the role of the governor‐general?
Sir William
is convinced that the reconciliation process is under threat: in our view, he would not be properly performing his duties if he remained silent about his concerns on this issue.

Can I put it to the Senate that we also would not be fulfilling our duties properly if we remained silent on the mess that this government has got us into with respect to the reconciliation council and also with respect to native title.

This is a critical period for us. The lead has been shown by the Leader of the Opposition, Kim Beazley, over the last couple of weeks: talking to Pat Dodson, trying to get a constructive outcome, acting in many ways for the betterment of the nation but also, on the way through, for the government. That lead should have been taken up. But, unfortunately, we have two people responsible in this area who really cannot fill the requirements of the job.

Senator Herron really, I think, should just pause for a moment and perhaps reconsider what he has done here. He acted with undue haste and overrode the processes of legislation. Why did he do it? He said to us today that he wrote to Mr Beazley on 3 November. That was after he put out a press statement on 31 October, three days earlier, saying that he, as minister, had written a letter to the leaders of the opposition and of the Australian Democrats as part of the consultation process on the make‐up of a new Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation. He put out the press statement. He said he signed the letter. But the letter was not sent from his office for three critical days.

This is the way this minister tackles consultation: write someone a letter, do not deliver it to them for three or four critical days and, even before they have had a chance to respond, go out with a press statement saying, `We are going to make all these changes,' then announce who the successor is going to be. You had an obligation for decent, in‐depth consultation and what did you do? You sat on the letter for three days, and you acknowledged it in here this afternoon. We need better leadership. Unfortunately, Senator Herron, you cannot provide it. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling, Sen Grant

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I remember when the legislation to create the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation was presented for the consideration of the Senate in August 1991. Unlike the pious rhetoric today, there was then a genuine consideration of that legislation and a proper focus on achieving true reconciliation. I spoke to that bill, as did the newest member of the Labor Party now, then Senator Cheryl Kernot, in her former capacity as the Democrat spokesman on Aboriginal affairs. Not surprisingly, that legislation received very strong support from this chamber with Senator Kernot herself declaring:

SPEECH.PARA: I am very pleased to be able to add the support of the Australian Democrats for this Bill to that of the Opposition and the Government in a multipartisan way.

Senator Woodley's motion today is only the second motion by Senator Woodley in his time in this place on this issue. Senator Bolkus has just referred to the process that has been put forward by the minister today for the consideration of members. Compare that with Mr Tickner in 1994 when he presented as a fait accompli a list of names. The failure to consult was that of Tickner; he just delivered a list of names. The politics that is being played certainly goes to that extent. I would commend the work of the two past councils in what they have done. I would certainly hope that the next council will again respond as positively as the last two have done.

The Liberal and National parties supported the establishment of the reconciliation council on the basis that there must be wider consultation with the wider Australian community and not just sectional interests. This was always a particular concern of mine, coming from the Northern Territory, because we had witnessed a federal Labor government pander to interests of a select few to the detriment of the interests of the wider community. I had concerns that the Labor Party would again fail to consult the Australian community and threaten the success of reconciliation.

It is interesting to remember that in 1991 there was another piece of legislation also before the parliament. That was the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill 1991 which enjoyed the support of the Democrats but not the then coalition opposition. I did not support that bill because it proposed to totally ban political advertising on both radio and television, thus effectively excluding most of the regional community of my electorate of the Northern Territory from an essential part of the political process. Most of the people who would have been politically disenfranchised were the Aboriginal people living in rural and remote areas of the Northern Territory—parts of Australia that rely almost totally on radio and television, with the print media initially non‐existent.

The coalition parties supported the establishment of Aboriginal reconciliation on the understanding that there would be agreed goals and benchmarks for progress in education, health, housing and infrastructure; in general, an overall improvement in Aboriginal wellbeing. If you go to the 1993‐94 report of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation and look at the issues that were then flagged as achievements and performance indicators, it is very important to look at how they matched up with the record of the then government of the day. Labor's legacy in this whole area of Aboriginal affairs was disgraceful and dreadful, despite their spending over $16 billion on their specific indigenous programs, without any commitments to outcomes.

If you look at their record it is interesting to note that infectious diseases did not improve. Infant mortality was higher. Life expectancy was appalling. There were incomplete schooling processes. Water, sewerage, electricity and sealed roads did not improve. The unemployment rate for indigenous people was ghastly and their income share of the community did not improve. Labor made a mess of the Native Title Act, and that is what we in this parliament are currently proceeding to fix up. Despite all of the rhetoric and the expenditure that they put into reducing deaths in custody, the number of deaths actually continued to rise.

If you compare that with the most recent report of the Council For Aboriginal Reconciliation, the annual report of 1996‐97, and then you go to the performance indicators of that report, it is fascinating to see that they are now being met and are able to be measured by way of outcomes. We will spend almost $400 million more in real terms on indigenous specific programs in our first four years in office than were spent in the last four years of the previous government.

Accountability of Aboriginal organisations is being addressed and properly looked at despite the fact that for 13 years Labor did nothing. Business incentive programs are now being concentrated on to encourage indigenous business enterprises. The army is cooperating with infrastructure projects, such as roads, airstrips and housing, in remote communities. Primary health care programs are seeing injections of important and additional funding. If you look at the special area of deaths in custody you find that the criminal justice system is being addressed. Specifically, the recommendations are being picked up. This government is responding to those recommendations. Those are the issues that are commented on in the annual report of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation.

There are reviews under way in the area of CDEP which will impact on employment for Aboriginal people. A review is being undertaken of Abstudy, which is vitally important to the training and educational opportunities of young people, many of whom are desperate to participate in the wider community. They are responding to the very issues, the performance indicators, that the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation for the last few years has put down. It is so easy to see when the government responds to issues such as reforming the Heritage Protection Act that you will not get a similar debacle as happened with Hindmarsh Island.

This government is putting a commitment very solidly into economic independence for indigenous Australians. We are proud of that record and so we should be. It is interesting to go back to the reports of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation and judge them against the spending and policy priorities of the government in the respective years. There have been six reports since 1991. Read the report for each of the years of Labor administration and there is no marrying up in those important areas. Read the one for the last year and every one of the programs is currently being addressed across each and every portfolio of this government.

BREAK.PARA: Too often in the area of Aboriginal affairs we engage in public relations sessions and talkfests. The Labor Party did that for years rather than looking for desperate and necessary practical solutions. We must address the areas of drug and alcohol dependence. We must address the areas of children's health measures, nutrition and parent support. We must address basic literacy. We must address the issue of employment opportunities for youth.

The Liberal‐National Party government in 18 months in office has done more than 13 years of Labor in each and every one of these areas. For $16 billion we saw no measured outcomes. Instead it was just the Labor Party continuing with its political control and manipulation of Aboriginal communities for political reasons rather than trying to instil and importantly build up the independence, the dignity and the involvement in the wider community and giving special recognition to those things that are inherent to Aboriginal culture itself. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —Aboriginal Australians essentially lost their voice in the Commonwealth government with the election of the Howard administration last year. The Howard government has not simply disenfranchised Aboriginal people, it has been deliberately antagonistic to their interests. That policy has been pursued from the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) down. The public record clearly demonstrates this. This government has been engaged in a non‐stop policy of assault and battery in Aboriginal affairs since March last year. That assault began within a month of this government taking office, and I will recall the events to you.

SPEECH.PARA: John Howard called his first press conference as Prime Minister in Canberra to announce that he was putting a special auditor into ATSIC and freezing their funds. He also announced that the government would seek legislative change—which they did—to give them power to sack the entire ATSIC board and install an administrator. That was the Prime Minister's first press conference after the election, in Canberra.

BREAK.PARA: The appointment of the special auditor was later found by the Federal Court to be unlawful and this Senate blocked the attempt by the government to impose an administrator on ATSIC, if the government so desired. The point is that all of this was done by the Howard government without a single word of prior consultation with ATSIC or, indeed, any Aboriginal people in Australia. That government has charged, under its own legislation, ATSIC as the principal policy adviser in indigenous affairs to this government.

The battery came in last year's budget with more than $400 million ripped out of the forward estimates for ATSIC. In terms of the cant we have heard again here today, about nothing done in 13 years under a Labor administration, I would refer all honourable senators to the proceedings of the last estimates—that is, the last Senate estimates that canvassed the area of Aboriginal affairs—where ATSIC officers put that nonsense to rest, well and truly.

The cuts tore the heart out of ATSIC's discretionary programs—that is, their social and cultural programs—which to the shame of this government were described by this government as `political programs'. A no‐growth policy imposed on the community development employment program raised the prospect—again confirmed at Senate estimates—of Aboriginal unemployment going to in excess of 40 per cent by the year 2000.

The situation worsened considerably with the Prime Minister's appearance at the national reconciliation convention, and who could ever forget that. Who could ever forget the television images of the Prime Minister screaming abuse at the delegates from the podium and looking anything but relaxed and comfortable. It was only later, during estimates hearings again, that we found out that he had gone to that convention without seeking one word of advice from his key advisory body in Prime Minister and Cabinet—that is, the Office of Indigenous Affairs—or ATSIC as to how the government might respond to the stolen generations report.

The Prime Minister had not bothered to seek anything other than a formal legal brief on its contents before going to the reconciliation convention, despite the fact that the report had been with the government for more than two months. This was a report which the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Senator Herron, told the Senate he considered would be one of the most important he would ever receive as minister. Mind you, he then told Senate estimates that he carried it around for weeks before reading it because he only had a photocopy and was waiting for a printed copy of the document. You can understand my astonishment when I learned that ATSIC did not receive a copy of the report until the day it was released.

The Prime Minister clearly has no understanding about how important consultation is to Aboriginal people. In this context, I noticed a report in today's Australian headed, `Talk to black people, says Ray.' The report says that the host of A Current Affair, Ray Martin—who is a member of the National Reconciliation Council—has been told by John Howard that he is keen to tour Aboriginal settlements in the outback to hear their concerns first‐hand. As a number of senators have recently noted from their visit to Maningrida, nothing is a substitute for actually going there and hearing it first‐hand.

TALK.START.PARA: —Absolutely.

—I am glad that the minister for Aboriginal affairs has said absolutely. I wish you would tell that to the Prime Minister, Minister Herron. I know how many you have been to, Minister. I also know how many Aboriginal communities the Prime Minister has been to—none. The Prime Minister apparently told Ray Martin that he would visit communities very soon. This is in today's press. He is going to do it privately, Martin said. He continued:

BREAK.PARA: "He doesn't want to take a mob of journos along but he would like to do it with his family and certainly with his children.
"I think it would be an extraordinary and enlightening process not just for the Prime Minister but for most Australians if they actually stopped and talked to black people . . . "

I do not know when Ray Martin last talked to the Prime Minister, but I can inform the Senate that there are a lot of Aboriginal people around Australia wondering when the Prime Minister is going to take time to visit them. He said last year he would do so. That is why I want to make this point. As far as I can gather, apart from a highly publicised visit to the Torres Strait, he has not done so.

At a press conference in Parliament House on 13 December last year, Mr Howard told journalists that the new board of ATSIC and the new chairman, Gatjil Djerrkura, had expressed the wish to work in a very positive way with the government. He was then asked by a journalist when he would visit Aboriginal communities himself. He replied:

I have had some discussions already with some people regarding that, including the chairman of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation, and when I am in a position to indicate when I will be doing that I will let you know, but I have spent some time over the past few months—
this is last year—

constructing the broad outline of my diary for next year and it will involve a great deal of travel around Australia. I do not want to visit Aboriginal communities in settlements in any kind of tokenistic sense but I do want to visit them.

Clearly, every journalist in the room was left with the impression that John Howard intended to visit those communities at least at some stage during this year. He has not done so. As far as I am aware, as I said, he has made one well publicised trip to the Torres Strait to discuss their autonomy and that is it. Given that we are a month and a half away from the end of the year, I can only assume he will not be visiting any Aboriginal communities before the end of 1997. Given the intensity of public debate currently over Wik, the stolen generation report and Aboriginal health and education, to name just a few of the issues surrounding indigenous affairs, one does wonder why the Prime Minister has not found time this year to fulfil his promise.

I might also say that I personally think that the quote of the debate so far was the statement just issued by Senator Nick Bolkus. The Prime Minister has gone on the front foot and said, `Oh, no debate in Australia over the native title bill would be a race debate. It is just a debate over land management.' What nonsense that is in real life. But, as Senator Bolkus pointed out, how can the government say that with a straight face when it has told this Senate again and again that it is relying for the very constitutional validity of that bill on the race power of the constitution? In fact, it has gone one step further than that. It has said that not only does it rely on the race power, it relies on legislation even being detrimental to the interests of Aboriginal people still being supported by the race power under the constitution. Indeed, the minister for Aboriginal affairs has told us that on a number of occasions here in this Senate.

Ray Martin was quite right when he was quoted in the paper today as saying that the reconciliation process is like dragging the Queen Mary through treacle. Indeed, it is a difficult exercise and was always going to be. The reason Ray Martin said that was that it is such a difficult proposition, and it is, that some degree of continuity in terms of the leadership of that reconciliation process is absolutely essential. No-one could doubt the effectiveness that both Pat Dodson and Ian Viner as a team have brought to the leadership of that council. Having attended a number of extremely hostile meetings on Aboriginal issues at which Pat Dodson has been a speaker, he certainly has a lot more patience and forbearance than I have. I think he has done an outstanding job. You would have thought there would have been some interest in the government going that one step further and retaining his services.

What are these three conditions that the government is carrying on about?—`Oh, you can't negotiate with people forever; you have to make a decision.' What are these three impossible conditions that Pat Dodson has laid down for the final term of this council, and that is what it is? Not only should he retain his position on the council but that his deputy should as well and that the government give a commitment to some document of reconciliation. They are the three conditions. I would have thought that, if they cannot achieve three out of three, they are not particularly interested in reconciliation. There is a view about in the government that it was probably a good idea to get rid of this troublesome ex‐priest on the way through.

I know the minister has been gazumped on this. We all know that—it is public property. The minister, and I am not criticising him, has undergone proper process. I would point out that that proper process, and the minister offered no defence of it, still has two days to run. The advice that was sent out to the Leader of the Opposition and the Australian Democrats clearly stated that they still have 48 hours to respond. But what is the point of responding? The act requires this to be done only with the chairman and deputy chairman in terms of these particularly important appointments. The Prime Minister has gazumped the process entirely and announced that those appointments have already been determined 48 hours before the process laid down by Minister Herron has been exhausted. Everybody would know that consensus is essential. The government has destroyed it. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferris, Sen Jeannie

TALK.START.PARA: —When the bill to establish the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation was debated in the parliament in 1991, former minister Robert Tickner said that one of his objectives was to remove unnecessary point scoring from Aboriginal affairs. In fact, what he said was:

SPEECH.PARA: One of my objectives as Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has been to remove unnecessary political point scoring from Aboriginal affairs to enable the nation to move forward over the coming decade . . .
That is something that seems to have been forgotten by those colleagues of former minister Tickner who are now sitting opposite.

Like the former minister, the coalition government is strongly committed to the reconciliation process. It is well known now, and well documented this afternoon, just how hard the government tried to persuade Mr Dodson to remain as chair of this council. But the first paragraph of his letter says it very clearly:
After serious consideration, I find that I am unwilling to seek reappointment as the chairman of the council for reconciliation.
That is hardly ambiguous—not a whim and not without thought. He says that he finds that he is unwilling, after serious consideration, to continue as chair.

Very clearly, Mr Dodson had thought about his position long and hard, and he wrote a 2½ page letter expressing the view that he did not wish to be reappointed. It is also now well known and clearly documented that the government tried very hard to dissuade Mr Dodson from that view. But he declined, despite further invitations on several occasions.

It is instructive to have a look at the consultation process adopted by those opposite, despite receiving and requesting—as former minister Tickner said—support on the establishment of the council from this party, the now government. It is very clear that, when the Labor Party was in government, that consultative process did not exist. The previous government did not seem to consider that reconciliation and consultation was even an issue. It did not even consult the opposition when they made their appointments to the council. Labor's minister, Mr Tickner, only wrote to the leaders of the opposition after the final appointees had been proposed—very clearly, a different proposition to that put by Senator Bob Collins a few minutes ago.

This government believes that the reconciliation process must grow from the community level. Also, we must not lose sight of this important principle: the community must be involved. Reconciliation is not a top down process. Equally, it does not resolve itself by resting on the shoulders of any one person. It is bigger than that. It affects all of us. To suggest that reconciliation has now in some way ended, failed, been buried, because an individual—albeit a very talented and hard working man—has chosen of his own free will and, as he said, after careful consideration, not to be reappointed is highly irresponsible and reckless. This man considered his position very carefully.

I personally was very disappointed to see the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) and his new bridesmaid, Mrs Kernot, in this morning's newspapers proclaiming the end of reconciliation in our time, as we know it. Senator Woodley's former colleague says that the council is now only `a token body' and that there is no point in continuing with the council's reconciliation process. Senator Woodley, I hope that Mrs Kernot's defection from your group does not mean you now are an empty shell; I am sure that you are not.

For those people who proclaim themselves to be for reconciliation, how much more damaging could Mrs Kernot's comments have been intended to be? They are a tragedy for Aboriginal people and the reconciliation process which is important to all of us. That process is too important to be abused or politically used by any individual. Patrick Dodson himself has made note of that. He did not see that his resignation would amount to the end of reconciliation—not a bit of it. In fact, his final words in his letter of 30 October to Senator Herron are worth repeating here. He said:
My personal commitment to the reconciliation process remains strong and I wish the new Council and its Chairman my very best wishes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —Today's urgency debate on Aboriginal reconciliation has been marked by political point scoring, such as, `This government has failed to properly consult' and `When you were in government, you failed to properly consult.' That sort of political point scoring does absolutely nothing to advance the cause of genuine reconciliation.

SPEECH.PARA: The last thing we want to do in this place is to fuel the fires of mistrust. I do not suggest for one moment that the mover of this motion intended that at all or, to be quite frank, even intended to see how some of the debate went. He must have been disappointed. In part, the motion states:

. . . the Prime Minister's poor handling of the appointment of the Chairperson of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation, in particular, the failure to consult as required under the terms of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation Act 1991.

The evidence for that is tenuous. I was not impressed, for example, with the defence of that motion by the opposition spokesperson, Senator Bolkus. I was, however, impressed with what Senator Herron said about the matter, the detail that he listed of what has taken place. I propose to vote against the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron) said that `reconciliation is far too precious to be politicised'. Isn't that what the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has done? What is more political than threatening to call an election on the issue of the government's Wik 10‐point plan? I would indicate that, if there is any doubt about the support of the Senate for this motion, I will call a division.

SPEECH.PARA: The minister said that the government has followed the law. If that is true, then the minister is saying that it is not too late to reconsider Pat Dodson. That is the test of the minister's defence. Is it too late, Minister? I predicted the minister's defence—that is, he would say that they have consulted in the same way as the ALP. I am not here to defend the ALP. But I note the minister has quoted the act, and that is what I am concerned about. The law says `consult, then decide'; the Prime Minister has said `decide, then consult'. The minister says that this is not so. The test for the minister's claim is simple: is it too late? After 12 November, we will know—as will the whole nation—whether it is too late for reconciliation.

I have read the minister's speech entitled `Reconciliation: is it possible?' It is a very good speech. I found it moving. I think what he should do now is make sure his Prime Minister reads that speech. I think perhaps that would perform a conversion in his heart that we are all looking for.
I hope that the Senate will support my motion. The act has not been followed. I believe that we cannot have a Prime Minister flouting the law and thumbing his nose at what the law requires.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to standing order 166, on behalf of the President I present the annual report for 1996‐97 of the Inspector‐General in Bankruptcy. This document was presented to the President on 6 November 1997. In accordance with the terms of the standing orders, publication of the document was authorised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I thank the Senate for giving me this time to speak. I wish to speak, particularly with ministers present, on the matter of bankruptcy because of the events surrounding Alan Bond and his desire, in my view, to evade justice. The close of the 1980s witnessed a surge in the number of bankrupts in Australia and the years that followed demonstrated that the Bankruptcy Act and related legislation needed reforming. The whole community has watched with amazement the drawn‐out court cases and legal action in pursuit of failed tycoons such as Mr Alan Bond and Mr Christopher Skase and the inability of the bankruptcy legislation to effectively pursue white‐collar criminals.

I note in passing the diligent efforts of the government in trying to pursue this matter and I also note in passing the frustration it must inevitably experience as a result of the difficulties it has had in trying to collar Mr Bond's friends overseas.

Alan Bond's prolonged and contrived attempts to stave off the Australian Federal Police investigations into his financial dealings with Swiss banker Jurg Bollag has once again drawn attention to the ineffectiveness of our revised bankruptcy laws and the ineffectiveness of their interaction with our international counterparts. The ability of the AFP to question people associated with a bankrupt clearly must be strengthened under the Bankruptcy Act.

During Alan Bond's bankruptcy hearings creditors felt that they were forced to settle for 0.05c in the dollar. Authorities must be allowed to verify whether millions of other people's dollars, which Alan Bond had in his care, have been secreted away in Swiss banks administered by Jurg Bollag. Constraints in calling witnesses to give evidence and the high onus of proof thresholds have frustrated the AFP efforts and have contributed to the loss of millions of dollars in public funds.

The burden on public funds could, we hope, be minimised if the legislation was further reformed. I cannot say to those of you who are ministers here just how you should reform it, but I do think I express the feelings of the Australian public when I say they really do want much more action in this area. The legal system has found it much easier to indict small business and small participants in our system for far lesser sins than have been committed by the Bonds and Skases. Big business and their big advisers seem still to be adept at manipulating the legal and bankruptcy systems. Reforms must be made to minimise the use of delay tactics and avoidance. Bankruptcy laws should be strengthened to ensure that wilful fraud is capable of being exposed, and the AFP must have the opportunity to properly investigate all avenues and all allegations of fraud.

Australians have a right to expect that the corporate excesses of the 1980s not only will be punished but will never be repeated. The Australian Democrats, and I personally, have long been concerned about the adequacies of Australia's laws and resources for policing corporate criminals. It seems odd to me that the government has laws in its possession which attempt to prevent farmers, for instance, as it did recently, from exercising the right to silence under the customs laws and yet it is able under bankruptcy laws to allow situations in which people contrive to conceal their true state of affairs.

If Australians are to have confidence to invest in Australian companies, the legislation must protect small shareholders and large shareholders and must unequivocally punish and pursue white‐collar crime. We have welcomed substantial reforms that have occurred in the Bankruptcy Act area, but the effectiveness of these laws will only be proven to the people as a whole when some very large fish are caught in the net. I urge the government to relook at this area. If the government does relook at this area, it will have our full support in improving the law in this respect.
