Australia owes a significant debt to the men and women who have served in defence of Australia. The purpose of this bill is to protect and preserve one of their long‐standing compensatory benefits, a subsidised housing loan under the Defence Service Homes Act 1918.

This Government has been very pleased with the reduction in interest rates. This is continuing good news for the economy in general. However, the reduction in the market rates for housing loans has significantly reduced the value of the beneficial interest rates that have traditionally been available to borrowers under the Defence Service Homes Loan Scheme.

This bill introduces a guaranteed minimum subsidy that will ensure Defence Service Homes borrowers retain an interest rate advantage of at least 1.5 per cent lower than the Benchmark rate, regardless of future changes in the market interest rates. These changes will take effect from 5 January 1998.

The Benchmark rate is the average unregulated standard annual rates of interest applied to the largest number of owner‐occupied housing loans provided by the five largest banking group providers of housing finance in Australia.
This guaranteed minimum subsidy provides a simple means for responding to and accommodating future fluctuations in interest rates.

This bill also introduces a single rate of interest for those many borrowers whose loans may comprise two, or even three, different rates linked to different levels of borrowings. Each of these multi‐tiered loan rates will be collapsed to a single interest rate. The effective new interest rate will depend on the current mix of interest rates on a particular loan. This arrangement will benefit many borrowers, and means the abolition of the 10 per cent interest rate which has been an issue of some concern to the veteran community. Until now, they have been prevented from repaying their 10 per cent tier faster than the lower tiers. Its introduction is part of this Government's continuing commitment to providing and improving justly deserved compensation measures to veterans and war widows.

Continuing this rationalisation of the Defence Service Homes interest rates, this bill will reduce the interest rate on additional advances and on advances made for essential repairs. In reducing the interest rate on these advances, the Government completes its reform of these rates which it began during the 1996‐97 Budget, when a lower interest rate was introduced for certain new additional advances. All advances will now have an interest rate of 6.85 per cent or less.

The Defence Service Homes Scheme is administered jointly by the Commonwealth and the Westpac Banking Corporation. The administrative arrangements are set by agreement between the Commonwealth and Westpac. Following any legislative change some consequent amendments need to be made to the agreement.

In addition to those implementing lower interest rates, these amendments will reflect changes in business and banking practice since the original agreement in 1988 and the need to simplify administrative procedures.

In conclusion, this bill once again demonstrates the determination of this Government to preserve and protect the benefits of veterans and their families. The bill not only benefits many people by direct interest reductions, but the guaranteed minimum subsidy provides an important, continuing protection of the benefits under the Defence Service Homes Scheme.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Capital gains tax roll‐over relief for small businesses

SPEECH.PARA: The bill proposes amendments to the income tax law in relation to capital gains tax roll‐over relief for small business. These amendments were announced by the Prime Minister on 24 March 1997 as part of the Government's response to the report of the Small Business Deregulation Taskforce.

Specifically, the bill will extend the capital gains tax small business roll‐over relief to the disposal of certain shares in companies and units in unit trusts. The roll‐over relief measures currently allow capital gains on the disposal of active assets of a small business, where replacement active assets are acquired. These amendments will allow a capital gain on the sale of a business to be rolled over where this is done through the sale of shares or units. In addition, certain shares and units will be able to be nominated as replacement assets for the purposes of the provisions.
Minor technical changes will also be made to the roll‐over relief provisions to ensure they operate as originally intended.

The extension of the roll‐over relief to shares and units will apply to disposals of assets from 1 July 1997, which is also the date of effect for Division 17A. The technical amendments have various application dates.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Amendment of the Sales Tax Assessment Act 1992

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments made to the Sales Tax Assessment Act 1992 by Schedule 2 of the bill will establish a new sales tax regime for suppliers of computers and related goods to combat sales tax fraud involving personal computers and related goods. The amendments have been developed following a successful period of consultation with the industry, sales tax practitioners and other interested parties.

The Government and the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) have received numerous representations from business about the adverse effects that sales tax evasion is having in the industry. The impact is especially disadvantaging smaller legitimate operators who are often much less able to absorb the competitive disadvantage. A particularly worrying consequence of the fraud is that a large number of legitimate operators who claim their business survival is at risk are reluctantly being drawn into dealing with the fraudulent operators. In doing so they not only contribute to sustaining the fraud but also put themselves at serious risk of being a party to an offence. It is also apparent that a number of industry operators, while not directly involved in the commission of the fraud, are taking commercial advantage of the cheap source of supply.

It is estimated that such fraudulent activity is costing the Government approximately $80 million per annum. Whilst that threat to the revenue is of concern to the Government, the major concern is that fraudulent operators should not continue to enjoy a competitive advantage from failure to comply with the sales tax laws. The amendments contained in this bill will remove this competitive advantage and place all operators in an even position. Operators who can only compete on a fraudulent basis may be driven out of the industry. This is a result which the Government would welcome.

Given the entrenched nature of this fraudulent activity and that normal administrative action is not effective, it is considered that the most effective approach is to remove the opportunity for the fraud to be committed rather than rely on after the event enforcement action. The central feature of the new scheme is that access to tax‐free personal computers and related goods (defined as Part 7A goods) will be denied to taxpayers who have not established, to the Commissioner's satisfaction, that they are likely to fulfil their obligations under the tax law.

People who have established, by satisfying certain criteria, that they are likely to fulfil their taxation obligations will be accredited. Generally, only accredited people will be able to quote effectively, a procedure which allows them to purchase personal computer and related goods tax‐free. The quote will also have to be authorised, a process designed to guard against the fraudulent use of accreditation numbers.

If a person is accredited, that person will be able to carry on trading in much the same way as he or she has done in the past, and the person's sales tax obligations will remain the same, except for the extra requirement that the quote must be authorised and there will be some extra record‐keeping and payment requirements. It is intended that authorisation will be available over the phone, so that it will not hinder trade unduly. Existing entitlements to end user exemptions will not be disturbed.

However, accredited people will take on extra obligations when they buy goods from unaccredited people. As a safeguard against attempts to frustrate these measures, there will be a requirement on accredited purchasers who purchase tax‐paid from unaccredited persons to withhold an amount, equivalent to the tax owing on the sale, from the purchase price and remit that amount to the Commissioner. Certain entities, such as public benevolent institutions will be exempted from the requirement for accreditation.

If necessary, the withholding requirement will be extended to retailers who purchase goods from unaccredited wholesalers. This extension of the withholding arrangements to retailers will only come into effect if a review of the operation of the new regime indicates that such an extension is necessary.

This is not the first occasion on which serious sales tax fraud has occurred. In the past similar problems have arisen in relation to other goods including motor vehicles, video cassette recorders, amusement machines, and stereo equipment. The amendments have been developed to provide a general strengthening of the law to counter evasion. The scheme is designed to be flexible enough to apply to other goods if serious evasion is uncovered in other industries.
Another measure in the bill contains the legislative rules for the new infrastructure borrowings tax rebate that was foreshadowed in the last Budget.

Resident lenders to new public road and rail infrastructure projects which are approved by the Minister for Transport and Regional Development against specified criteria may qualify for a tax rebate on their interest income at the general company rate of tax. To the extent that the lender's interest is rebateable, the project borrower will be denied a deduction in respect of interest payable on the borrowing. The rebate applies only for the first 5 years of an eligible project's borrowings.

As a transitional measure, the rebate scheme is also open to infrastructure projects which were eligible under the infrastructure borrowings tax concession which terminated on 14 February 1997. Projects which had applied to the Development Allowance Authority by 14 February 1997, and extensions of projects which had received certification, may qualify under the transitional rule. In addition, projects certified after the cessation of the previous concession may apply for approval.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Removal of exemption of the Commonwealth Rebate for Apprenticeships Full‐Time Training (CRAFT) Scheme payment

SPEECH.PARA: The bill removes the tax exemption of amounts payable to employers under the Commonwealth Rebate for Apprenticeships Full‐Time Training (CRAFT) scheme in respect of apprentices who commence their training on or after 1 January 1998. The tax exemption is being replaced with a budget outlay to support employers of new Australian Qualification Framework level 3 and level 4 apprentices.

Finally, Madam President, Schedules 5 to 11 contain a range of minor technical and drafting corrections and presentational improvements arising from the rewrite of the income tax laws under the Tax Law Improvement Project.
[Schedules 5 to 9 propose technical corrections to income tax and other legislation. The amendments will:

. make corrections to the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997 so that it more clearly restates the effect of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 and ensure that changes incorporated in the 1997 act have their full intended operation;
. include additional consequential amendments required because of the rewritten income tax laws; and
. contain amendments which facilitate the transition from the 1936 act to the 1997 act.

Schedule 10 contains update amendments required because after a TLIP Bill had rewritten provisions of the 1936 act a later non‐TLIP Bill inadvertently amended the original provisions; or a TLIP Bill did not take into account changes that were in course in a non‐TLIP Bill.

Schedule 10 also contains amendments to give effect to the Government's decision to align tracing rules for companies under the loss provisions in the 1997 act with recently enacted amendments to the capital gains tax related tracing rules in the 1936 act.
Schedule 11 contains minor amendments which refine the drafting style of the 1997 act.]
Note: the material in square brackets could be omitted in interests of brevity.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

PARLIAMENTARY SERVICE BILL 1997

The bill I have just presented is a historic development for the parliament. It provides, for the first time, for the establishment and administration of a separate Parliamentary Service to support the operations of the houses of the Australian Parliament. The staff at present providing the parliament with its support services operate under administrative and staffing structures established by the Public Service Act 1922; however, it has been decided that the parliamentary administration should have its own legislation which recognises and mandates that the primary obligation of Parliamentary Service staff is to serve the parliament as a whole.

The Parliamentary Service Bill follows as much as possible the philosophy, content and structure of the Public Service Bill 1997, which changes significantly the structure of public service employment, with certain modifications necessary to ensure the independence of the parliament from executive government. It establishes an employment framework which mirrors that proposed for the Australian Public Service generally and provides specifically for the reciprocal mobility of staff between the two services without loss of accrued entitlements. Arrangements will also be put in place to ensure mobility for staff currently engaged under the Members of Parliament (Staff) Act.

There are significant differences between the Parliamentary and Public Service Bills which recognise that staff in parliamentary departments serve the houses of the parliament. That distinction is reflected in the first object of the bill which is to establish an apolitical Parliamentary Service that is efficient and effective in serving the parliament. The Parliamentary Service Bill contains a statement of Parliamentary Service values and a Code of Conduct, provides for the appointment of a Parliamentary Service Commissioner, makes specific reference to the offices of Clerk of the Senate and of the House of Representatives, and provides for appointments to those offices. Tenure as clerk of either house will be for one 10-year period. The bill also stipulates conditions for earlier termination of those appointments. Occupants of the office may retire earlier once they attain the age of 55 years. Secretaries, other than clerks, are to be appointed by the Speaker and the President for five-year terms with termination arrangements similar to those applying to secretaries of executive departments. There are transitional arrangements to ensure the continuation in office of current heads of parliamentary departments.

The bill also creates the new office of Parliamentary Service Commissioner with a role similar to that of the Public Service Commissioner. The Parliamentary Service Commissioner will have the task of advising the Presiding Officers with respect to the management practices and policies of the Parliamentary Service and, if requested by the relevant Presiding Officer, of investigating and reporting on specific issues.

In broad terms, the Presiding Officers will have the same employment powers as ministers under the Public Service Bill with advice from the Parliamentary Service Commissioner. Consistent with the need to preserve the independence of the clerks as impartial advisers, the Clerks of the House of Representatives and the Senate are not to be subject to direction from the Presiding Officers in relation to the nature of their advice provided with respect to either house, to members or to committees. Secretaries of parliamentary departments, including the clerks, cannot be directed in relation to the exercise of their powers in respect of specific individuals. The Presiding Officers will have the power to give secretaries of parliamentary departments, including the clerks, general directions relating to the management and leadership of the Parliamentary Service.

While the bill provides specifically that the Parliamentary Service Commissioner is to be appointed separately and independently by the Presiding Officers, it is expected that normally the same person would fill both of these offices. This would assist in ensuring overall compatibility and consistency between the two services. However, the bill specifically provides that the commissioner cannot be subject to direction by executive government in relation to the Parliamentary Service.
Secretaries of parliamentary departments, including the two clerks, are to have the same employment powers as those proposed for departmental secretaries in the Australian Public Service.

As mentioned earlier, the bill incorporates a legally enforceable Code of Conduct and a statement of Parliamentary Service values. These values reflect the fact that staff serve the houses but in other respects mirror those of the Public Service Bill, with a parallel reference to the requirement that employment decisions in the Parliamentary Service be based on merit.

In summary, this bill gives legislative effect to the decision that the parliamentary administration should not continue to be covered by the standard Australian Public Service Act. It establishes a statutory framework and administrative arrangements broadly consistent with those for the Public Service while incorporating the changes necessary to accommodate the unique circumstances of serving the houses. It provides the houses with a set of arrangements which will allow them to continue to attract and provide a career for those staff who will be equipped to deliver the high level of service the houses currently enjoy.

The government accepted recommendations made by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts in its advisory report on the Public Service Bill 1997, and the Bill was amended accordingly by the House of Representatives. Parallel amendments were made in the relevant instances to the Parliamentary Service Bill in order to preserve the parallel nature of employment conditions and to ensure the unfettered operation of mobility between the two services. I present the revised explanatory memorandum and commend the bill to the Senate.
PARLIAMENTARY SERVICE (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1997

The Parliamentary Service (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1997 deals with the consequential legislative amendments arising from the provisions of the Parliamentary Service Bill 1997. The Parliamentary Service (Consequential Amendments) Bill refers specifically to the following acts:
Archives Act 1983;
Audit Act 1901;
Long Service Leave (Commonwealth Employees) Act 1976;
Maternity Leave (Commonwealth Employees) Act 1973; and
the Public Employment (Consequential and Transitional) Amendment Act 1997.

The consequential amendments insert references in the relevant acts to the parliamentary departments established under the provisions of part 6 of the Parliamentary Service Bill 1997, or to the clerks and secretaries of those parliamentary departments, so as to continue the application of those acts to the parliamentary departments.

This bill will come into effect at the same time as the Parliamentary Service Act 1997 commences. The proposed amendments have no financial impact. Transitional arrangements pursuant to the enactment of the Parliamentary Service Bill are covered in part 8 of that bill and deal with employment matters relating to the staff of the Parliamentary Service in a manner equivalent to the transitional provisions of the Public Employment (Consequential and Transitional) Amendment Bill.
I commend the bill to the Senate and note that the explanatory memorandum is incorporated in that to the Parliamentary Service Bill 1997.
Ordered that further consideration of the second reading of these bills be adjourned until the first sitting day in 1998, in accordance with standing order 111.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Finance and Public Administration References Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy, Sen Shayne

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Finance and Public Administration References Committee on the necessity for public accountability of all government services provided by government contractors.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move a motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

This is the first report on contracting out of government services. I do note that the report is supported by a majority of members of the committee but that Senator Watson, Senator Ferris and Senator Lightfoot have dissented from it. The committee's report favours a cautious approach to outsourcing—and perhaps that is an understatement of our view. Outsourcing is just one option available to agencies seeking to improve the quality of their IT services. However, it is not a panacea for agencies seeking to save money or revamp their services.

Experience and research literature from within Australia and around the world provide a wide range of outcomes—from total success to abject failure. However, the range of outcomes does support the theme of the report: getting outsourcing right can be a long and difficult process and agencies require the time, resources and supportive policy environment in which to operate—something this government appears not prepared to do. Indeed, outside of the government's ideological position, it appears not to even know what it is doing with regard to IT outsourcing. The government is doing so much of it on the run that even this report will probably appear a little out of date in some areas.

Of particular note is the most recent announcement that OGIT will be transferred to the Office of Asset Sales. I am not quite sure where that will leave a lot of people within the industry. It clearly raises more questions than it answers in an area that really needs stability, requires caution and careful consideration. It would be very interesting for the committee to go back to the various agencies now and address that question of management of IT outsourcing. We may have to do this as part of our program of looking at the wider issues of competitive tendering and contracting out.

The committee believes that the decision to outsource should be carefully considered on an agency by agency basis, that it requires a high degree of efficiency within the area considered for outsourcing prior to any decision so that the agency has a thorough grasp of costs and service requirements, and that the development of a business case and the conduct of market testing should allow the genuine option of not proceeding if the projected outcomes cannot be met. The current ad hoc approach will not allow due process to take place.

The committee is also of the view that the government's position that savings targets must be met, irrespective of success or otherwise of outsourcing, will simply require agencies to deliver up the savings from other areas of their operations which could—and more than likely will—result in poorer service and less efficiency. The government's cluster process appears to be in tatters and must have the IT industry wondering just how it will assist the development and growth of the Australian industry.

Witnesses to the inquiry were concerned that this approach would favour a few large multinationals at the expense of small and medium sized enterprises: that is, it would limit the freedom of individual agencies within clusters to seek best outcomes for their specific requirements, that it would inhibit innovation and flexibility in IT development and that it could limit the ability of government to make significant policy changes and restructure administrative arrangements. In my view, all of these concerns are justified and the confusion surrounding the composition of cluster 3 only adds more weight to them.

The government's recent announcement on employment transition seeks to encourage the transfer of agency staff to the contractor. This is to be commended. However, the concern over jobs is not just in the public sector; there is grave concern in the private sector, especially in the small to medium enterprise area—the very section of industry that this government said its approach would provide so much benefit to. I think the end result will be much different. There are already signs appearing that not only will the government's IT outsourcing program not assist the development of new industry but it will more than likely lead to the demise of the existing industry already involved in the provision of IT services.

Privacy and public accountability were two other areas of key concern. They received a large degree of airing. In terms of the outsourcing program, they will be very important also. The government's decision to ensure that no offshore processing of information is undertaken and that the Privacy Act will be amended to cover Commonwealth information held by contractors is welcomed but falls far short of what is really needed. The committee is of the view that no further outsourcing contracts should be let until satisfactory privacy measures are in place. Frankly, I do not know how the government can proceed to finalise contracts without such measures in place.

Likewise, on the accountability front, the committee believes that outsourcing should not in any way diminish the level of accountability for the expenditure of public money and the exercise of public conferred authority. The responsibility to parliament for outsourced services must lie with the relevant minister in exactly the same way as it would for a service provided directly by the Public Service. The Auditor-General must have the necessary access and resources to examine outsourced services, and the jurisdiction of agencies such as the Ombudsman must extend to cover those services.

The committee is particularly concerned about the practice of limiting the scrutiny of outsourcing contracts by making claims of commercial-in-confidence and believes that matters which directly and genuinely threaten the commercial interests of a company or agency should be covered by such claims. Evidence to the committee suggested that, in reality, justifiable claims would relate only to a relatively small part of most contracts. Therefore, the committee supports the publication of contracts with the minimum of excisions for reasons of confidentiality.

Many of the issues dealt with in this report have much wider relevance than the outsourcing of IT, and the committee will deal with them in greater detail in its second report. Finally, I again stress that the government's IT outsourcing program should be put on hold to enable a proper plan to be developed to ensure that there is a process that will achieve benefits for everyone, especially the Australian public. I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The Report on the necessity for public ac countability for all government services provided by government contractors is a very important report, and I commend the Senate Finance and Public Administration References Committee on its preparation. It does show that the government's IT outsourcing program has been very rushed, ill-advised, inadequately planned and is very unlikely to deliver anywhere near the savings that the government has promised. I think it vindicates our concerns about the whole process.

SPEECH.PARA: As the Senate will be aware, the Australian Democrats initiated this inquiry because it was fairly obvious to us that the government was not only wasting a unique opportunity to build up a thriving local IT industry but also rushing into a tendering process with a half-baked cost analysis and against the advice of most government agencies. We think the savings from IT outsourcing that the government has already deducted from agency operating budgets are not at all certain. Last week's resignation by Dr Macdonald from the Office of Government Information Technology highlights the fact that the government has not thought this issue through. It has mostly been about outsourcing for outsourcing's sake. Because we are now well into the process, OGIT, the body that is supposed to shepherd in those changes, is being overhauled at just a moment's notice.

I would like to highlight a couple of points which can be found in the report. The government failed to build in the true cost of redundancy packages or other termination methods into its budget predictions of massive savings. The cluster effect effectively locked out Australian small and medium enterprises because it was typified by very large contracts and, of course, overseas interest. There are very few provisions for safeguarding client privacy.

One of the more important findings of the report was that this commercial‐in‐confidence notion—that contracts must be kept secret from the public—was essentially blown out of the water by experiences from overseas and in particular from the United States. We found that agencies were not given any genuine say in whether or not they should outsource. I make the point that the Office of Government Information Technology seemed rather complacent in the belief that `the Commonwealth would succeed where others had not'.

Clearly, if IT outsourcing is to be effective, it should be judged on an agency‐by‐agency basis. However, the clustering of agencies makes this extremely difficult. The Democrats are saying, like the opposition, that the government should halt its outsourcing program. We think it ought to stop until there is an opportunity for a thorough reassessment of the potential risks and benefits—something we have not heard much of to date. We have seen from the submissions to the inquiry that there is an inverse relationship between the time spent preparing contracts to the time spent later in litigation. A time frame of just two years means that there will probably be very many hasty and muddled decisions taken down the line and that that will cost taxpayers very dearly.

The IT outsourcing program of this government reminds me quite a lot of what is going on in Victoria with local government—where competitive tendering has been made compulsory and where councils are forced into this process when there are very good reasons, both local and service wise, which would indicate that this should not go ahead. We are seeing much the same thing happen in regard to IT at the federal level.

I once again commend this report as being very important and urge senators to read the material which is contained in it. We look forward to the balance of the inquiry into the contracting out of government services generally. I thank the committee for their work on this inquiry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not surprisingly, this report entitled Report on the necessity for public accountability for all government services provided by government contractors is a highly‐charged political document. The majority report by the opposition members and the Democrats' member of the Senate Finance and Public Administration References Committee failed to acknowledge the fact that outsourcing was a policy of the previous government. It is typical of the now opposition that it is taking a completely different position when in opposition from the position it took in government. It is a highly‐charged political document. It is not surprising that the Liberal-National Party coalition senators have issued a very strong dissenting report.

BREAK.PARA: We believe this majority report is flawed not only in relation to its approach to the subject but also in the evidence that was solicited. It used stolen evidence and relied far too heavily on that stolen evidence. Let me remind the Senate that the evidence was stolen from a cabinet submission and that that submission was only the start of the decision making process.

The report is flawed because the committee appeared not to be open‐minded about the terms of reference. The fundamental mind‐set of this approach is one of the major flaws of this particular document. It also fails to recognise that outsourcing is a worldwide trend. It has been pursued not only by the previous government but by governments around the world, and also by state governments and the private sector. It is not new.

We are dealing with information technology. Where information technology is not core business—and it is not core business of governments—it is a service that is properly performed by specialists. I remind you that outsourcing of information technology has been adopted fully or partially by a number of state governments, including the South Australian, Victorian and Western Australian governments. It has also been pursued by some of Australia's largest companies that regard information technology as not being part of their core business—companies such as the Commonwealth Bank, Telstra, Qantas, MMI, Integral Energy and the Macquarie Bank.

What concerns me is the manner in which evidence in this report has been quoted, even where favourable evidence was given to the committee. I refer to the Industry Commission evidence which said that, when done well, CTC can lead to significant improvements in accountability, quality and cost‐effectiveness, providing benefits to clients, taxpayers and the broader community. What did Senator Murphy and his members do? They took that positive comment and turned it around by highlighting the phrase `when done well'. That is a pretty infantile approach. We expect more than child's play and debating techniques on such a significant issue.

The other area of concern to me, which I previously drew attention to, was the extensive use of an illegally obtained government submission and the use of that information in the conduct of the inquiry. It sets a very dangerous precedent, encouraging theft and the leaking of documents from Commonwealth departments.

TALK.START.PARA: —And public accountability! Goodness me!

—It does not matter whether you thieve or where you get it from, Senator Lundy, so long as you can make a political point—and a pretty poor one at that. The ability of governments to formulate and use confidential information underpins the fabric on which our democracy is built. I reject the argument of your interjection.

BREAK.PARA: We condemn the majority report's apparent disregard of evidence obtained from Commonwealth officers at the committee hearings in favour of your coordinated comments, together with illegally obtained information. The extensive use of stolen material can undermine the workings of parliamentary committees and the action is to be condemned.

I remind you again that submissions from government departments are but the first of a long process in terms of the evolution of program or policy development to be pursued by government. It is selective use of that information. How are government officers going to react to this sort of behaviour—to the stealing of documents containing comments and submissions they have made to government through submissions to cabinet?

This is a retrograde step which does no credit to the opposition and Democrat members of this committee who so extensively used that information and embodied it in this report. It brings shame on the Senate and, particularly, on those members who used it so extensively.

The opposition seems to have been unaware of a report it wrote when it was in government called Clients first. This government has built extensively on that report in terms of information technology. We have a commit ment to run government in an efficient manner to the benefit of taxpayers, and that requires businesses to focus on their core responsibilities.

As a government, we recognise that there is a shortage of personnel within the Australian Public Service. In order to make best use of these limited and scarce resources, a centralised approach is deemed to be the most efficient. What worried members of the government was the failure of the Labor Party and the Democrats to use any evidence from the state governments or from elements of the private sector which have outsourced. I believe that that failure must have accounted for a great deal of what I term the misinformation that was in Senator Murphy's report.
Senator Murphy is not really across a lot of these areas. At the committee hearing he made the following statement:
I would assume that the private sector has less conditions, lower wages and fewer jobs.
Mr Roche responded:
I certainly do not think that the first two are the case.

The private sector, as Senator Murphy obviously does not realise, usually pays very good wages, probably a lot better than those in the public sector. For him to come out with that remark shows a misunderstanding of this matter.

There are great opportunities for Australian participation in the SME. If your report was to be useful in any regard, you would have raised issues in relation to the setting of quotas, such as at what level. I remind you that the government is very sympathetic to privacy issues, but your government paid no regard at all to privacy issues in relation to the Department of Veterans' Affairs in 1991.

We have ensured extensively that the privacy issues are foremost. The property that does go out to outsourcing remains the property of the government. Although it may be in the hands of contractors, it is still the property of government and we have all the resources of the Crimes Act, the Privacy Act and other acts to ensure that the privacy of individuals is protected.

In short, this majority report is a political document and fails to recognise the policy of the previous government. This government has looked after the superannuation of the employees who have moved across to the private sector. I would like to take this opportunity of commending Mr Fahey on a successful program. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise to speak on Contracting out of government services—first report: information technology . In the first instance, I would like to address a number of comments made by Senator Watson. The first point I would like to make is in respect of Senator Watson's comments about the federal Labor government and Clients first . There is no doubt that, when your government announced the IT outsourcing process, it fundamentally changed the principles and premise upon which Clients first was based. Clients first specifically identifies, just as one example, a genuine competitive process to achieve some efficiencies with IT outsourcing.

SPEECH.PARA: We know, through the piggybacking of the DOF contract on the Department of Veterans' Affairs contract, that this government is not about achieving efficiencies through any competitive tendering process. It is about an ideological commitment to ditching the core provision of services by governments. That is what is driving it. For you to stand up here and pitifully claim that this is an ideological report ignores the report's substance. In fact, I would contend quite specifically that it is your quite insubstantial dissenting report that has the ideological spin on it, not our approach to the issues that we have systematically addressed on outsourcing throughout the body of the majority report.

I would like to turn to some of those main issues, and I would put to Senator Watson and to this government that there are a series of absolutely fundamental flaws in the approach to outsourcing. The first one is denying Australian businesses the opportunity to access government contracts. This is a funda mental flaw, in that you are not recognising the role of Australian industry in the IT sector. You are quite deliberately denying indigenous IT businesses the opportunity to build for themselves an innovative base so that they can grow and expand. You are relegating them to the position of being second best at the service, the whim and the beck and call of the multinational corporations.

I do not want to focus on that particular issue because I know that there is a balance that must be struck between the participation of multinational corporations and indigenous companies, but this proposal excludes them quite specifically and compromises their position in Australian industry. We have heard it from them and we have even heard it from the larger corporations which are now saying from the other end of the argument, `We don't want to be hamstrung by a government which is trying to force us into these flawed partnership arrangements with local companies.' This is just one example of the flaws involved in your IT outsourcing process.

Let us turn to another one: the privacy of the Australian citizen. If the management of information services and data is not a core competency or a core role of governments, then what is? What is our taxation system based on? It is based on the ability of the government to make assessments and measure. That requires the holding of incredibly sensitive and personal information. What about our health system? What about social security? Health and Social Security have an information database upon which they base their services provided to both the government and the citizens.

You have not provided adequate privacy guarantees. Your minister has said that he will enact privacy legislation to govern data held by companies on behalf of the Commonwealth. Have we seen this legislation? No, we have not. We have not seen even a bill proposing what is to be put in place. So this government is asking companies to tender for the outsourcing of government IT without even knowing the legislative parameters upon which their tender should be based. If that is not risking, denying and putting aside a sensible and practical degree of public accountability, what can you call it?

BREAK.PARA: Let us look at another issue: the actual competitive tendering process. I raised this in my opening remarks. Throughout this whole process and throughout every contracting out argument I have heard from this government, governments in other states and the Industry Commission itself, it has been said that the principle of achieving efficiencies is based on a competitive tendering process. You need only to look at the whole argument and debate around the original privatisation of Telstra and so forth to see what priority your government places on competitive tendering. Yet in this case with IT outsourcing we do not have one example on the table of this government being prepared to engage in such a process. As for the one opportunity that existed, this government chose to specifically bypass competitive tendering and utilise quite an obscure clause within the interim procurement guidelines of DAS to hang a contract on. That issue has not even been delved into, I believe, with the degree necessary to ensure probity.

That particular tender, the extension of the Department of Finance on to the DVA contract, raises all sorts of questions about the credibility of the program. Credibility affects public accountability, and if public credibility is not there how can taxpayers be assured of the process having some sort of validity and having some sort of safeguard mechanism to know that their money is being well spent?

One thing that this government fails to recognise is that you cannot treat information services as just a commodity, as just a service. It is more than that. It is an enabling technology. Information technology is not just the hardware. You cannot delineate the hardware from the software or the strategy controlling how information technology is managed within a given agency. To do that fundamentally ignores what IT is all about. It is enabling technology, it is a way of achieving efficiencies and it is a way of progressing innovation within a given organisation. So you are denying the agencies from doing that and actually progressing and improving the services that they provide and, in turn, doing a better job for government in achieving savings.

Finally, I would like to say with respect to this public accountability that the savings are not there. You say that you have cited evidence that the savings are there. We have not based our report on those savings because it depends on which study you read. But I will say this: the studies that show there are savings in outsourcing are not primarily focused on IT; they are focused on municipal functions. If you look at the studies based on IT outsourcing, you will find that barely 50 per cent are successful in delivering savings. A high proportion of those that do deliver savings have nominated and identified a specific dropping or lowering of services to the client. So you cannot base your argument on the reports.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for this committee report debate has concluded.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Herron, at the request of Senator Ian Campbell) proposed:

That the provisions of paragraphs (5) to (7) of standing order 111 not apply to the Child Care Payments (Consequential Amendments and Transitional Provisions) Bill 1997 allowing it to be considered during this period of sittings, and that this bill and the Child Care Payments Bill 1997 may be taken together for their remaining stages.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some concerns about the exemption being provided to the Child Care Payments (Consequential Amendments and Transitional Provisions) Bill 1997. I have attempted to have some discussions about this matter with the minister's office. However, despite expressions of concern, there does not seem to be any real, forthright feedback coming back from the office. Essentially, the difficulty is the period of disclosure of this bill prior to the attempted debate and, in particular, the period of disclosure for the disallowable instruments and other subordinate legislation referred to which are fundamentally part of the way this bill is going to be implemented.

SPEECH.PARA: These pieces of subordinate legislation were first requested when the bill was introduced some approximately six weeks ago. I have to say that I understand there was some rush and that the department was under some pressure to produce these documents. I suppose the length of time they took is understandable. I do not have any great difficulty with that. The difficulty I have is that there is an attempt to debate this bill when we really have had no time to examine these pieces of subordinate legislation. To put it on the record, I have to say that these pieces of subordinate legislation were provided to us in three lots. I received the last group of subordinate legislation on Thursday last week. I do not think this is a very reasonable time to allow an examination and real scrutiny of these pieces of subordinate legislation.

My particular concern is not just that I do not have proper time to examine them but that those involved in the industry, such as in the child-care centres, both community based and private, and in before‐ and after‐school care have also not had an opportunity to properly look at this subordinate legislation, make comments and get feedback. Those members of the child‐care industry have expressed a very strong desire to me. Parents are concerned about exactly how this bill will be implemented and what is contained in this legislation.

There are not just one or two pieces of subordinate legislation; I want to make this very clear. If that were the case, these problems could have been overcome in a few days. There are 28 pieces of quite lengthy subordinate legislation. Just to give you an idea of how much that is, this large folder contains those pieces of subordinate legislation. They deal with a huge range of issues, some of which are, I suppose, reasonably trivial in that they only apply to a small group of people. However, others are quite fundamental to the way that this bill will operate and how the changes to the child-care industry will be brought about.

They deal with things such as the definition of `inhabitants of Australia' for the purposes of child-care assistance and the child-care rebate. They deal with what the work train ing‐Austudy test is. This is a limitation that will be imposed on parents who are not working or who are in training or studying. They will be allowed to have access to only 20 hours of child care per week. So that test is of fundamental importance to a whole raft of parents who are affected by this legislation. To not have that subordinate legislation available for examination and comment well before the debate of the bill makes it extraordinarily difficult for that group of people and the industry as a whole.

I might mention for the benefit of Senator Herron that that aspect is of huge importance to the child-care industry in Queensland. A lot of members involved there, particularly in the private sector, are very concerned about that definition and how it will be imposed. So it is not something that is airy‐fairy or only involving people here in the Senate. It has very strong and important ramifications for those involved in the child-care industry at the grassroots level.

It also defines, pursuant to section 18 within the subordinate legislation, what a session of care is. Those people who are involved in the child-care industry or who have had a long interest in the area may be aware of the long debate about what is actually a session of care. For some time, we have retained a session of care, which is essentially a whole day. But there have been very clear indications from this government that there is a movement to reduce the session of care to perhaps half a day or less. In some cases, there is a feeling that this government may be looking at reducing it to an hour. That may not be the case, but certainly those involved in the industry would very much like to see what the intentions of this government are in relation to defining `session of care' when debating this bill. They want to see how it will be implemented out in the real world in the child-care industry and what effect it will have on the type of care that is being provided by the child-care industry for children whom parents choose to place in child-care centres. There are also subordinate regulations related to the assets test. The date of effect of determination is not yet very clear to anyone. It relates to how child-care assistance and the child-care rebate are paid.

BREAK.PARA: There are guidelines in relation to defining emergency care, again an issue of quite some controversy within the child‐care industry. There are conditions that should be taken into account in determining whether a child‐care centre has breached eligibility rules, again obviously something of major importance to child‐care centres. There are guidelines relating to the allocation of child‐care assistance hours. That means determining how many children each child‐care centre can get and what are the guidelines to determine that. Obviously, for a child‐care centre that is presently operating, it is fundamentally important to know how many child‐care assistance hours they will provided with. For centres that may be considering opening up in the future, again it may determine whether or not they will be viable. I could go on at some length. As I said, there are 28 of them: some of them of quite major importance; some of them of lesser importance.

Certainly, we need more than two working days in order to properly examine them and liaise with the industry. I would not mind actually receiving from the minister some indication as to whether these pieces of subordinate legislation have been distributed to the industry and, if so, to whom, and what their comments have been to date. Certainly, I do not believe that two days is adequate. Bearing that in mind, the opposition will not be agreeing to the cut‐off.

We do acknowledge that the government has deferred the implementation of the bill from 1 January to 27 April and we congratulate you for doing that. Hopefully, to some extent that will reduce the chaos that may have been brought about by the attempted implementation on 1 January. But I still believe that it is being unnecessarily rushed and that it would be proper for the government to take a bit more time to allow a bit more discussion and liaison on these issues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Neal for her comments. My understanding is that the legislation has been distributed to the industry.
—The subordinate legislation.

—And the subordinate legislation as well, Senator Neal, has been. In any case the reason for seeking the exemption, of course, is that these bills need to be passed in the current sittings if the new arrangements are to commence by April 1998. If the bills are not passed in the current sittings, given that the next sittings will not commence until March 1998 the new arrangements could not commence until June 1998 at the earliest.

BREAK.PARA: This delay would have a number of detrimental effects. It would generate uncertainty in the child‐care industry and it would further defer important policy changes including the reform of outside school hours care support arrangements to provide greater assistance to lower income families. It would defer policy changes to limit child‐care assistance for non‐work related purposes to 20 hours per week, the aim of which is to free up places for other children not currently able to obtain care. It would also defer the policy changes that implement planning arrangements for new private sector services, which are strongly supported by the industry, and link child‐care payments to the immunisation of children, which I think Senator Neal would agree is of fundamental importance. Of course, it would also reduce the savings available from the implementation of the new policy, so I take the points made by Senator Neal.
We believe that there will be time for discussion on the instruments as well as the legislation and seek the exemptions so that the bills can be passed in the current sittings.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Herron's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Consideration of House of Representatives Message

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —When this debate was interrupted a second or two before question time commenced at 2 o'clock today, the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp, was replying to a question I had asked him. I am not sure whether he has completed his reply. I seek some indication whether he has or not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a few other words that I will add. Senator Cook, as you would be aware, the clock was ticking and question time was coming on and I had to retrieve some folders. In the light of that, I had to summarise the answer.

SPEECH.PARA: The issue relates now to the unannounced policies which would be permitted under the amendments moved by the Labor Party. Requests could be made for a range of alternative policy options to be costed. We consider that this risks placing the departments of Treasury and Finance in the position of developing policies for the opposition in a way which we believe is inconsistent with the usual conventions. Apart from that, it would certainly add substantially to the workload of departments which could be required to cost a myriad of alternative policies.

This was never the intention of the charter of budget honesty which, as I have said, acts as a restriction on government because it makes sure that there is transparency, particularly in relation to fiscal accounts. We therefore are not able to accept the amendments which have been moved by the Labor Party.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —Those amendments have been accepted by the Senate. The motion now is that the Senate not insist upon the amendments to the Charter of Budget Honesty Bill which it had previously adopted. I have looked at the schedule—at least the points made by the House of Representatives in disagreeing with the Senate amendments—and for the life of me I cannot see any substance, with due respect, in those reasons.

SPEECH.PARA: We had this debate before question time. I must say that I have not changed my mind. The reasons are not such that I would change my mind on this matter. I hope that the government takes this with good grace and accepts the amendments so that ultimately we do have charter of budget honesty legislation.

I must say that it is unfortunate that sometimes there is a focus on the negative in this chamber. This was a positive initiative by the government. We all congratulate the government on this positive initiative. Overall, I think the Charter of Budget Honesty Bill was a very meritorious piece of legislation and something that should have been done some years ago. It has taken this government to bite the bullet, as it were. I do not want the government to feel that we are unduly negative in insisting upon these amendments.

I do not want it to be thought by anyone that we in any way are attempting to denigrate what the government has decided to do—that is, to propose and pursue a charter of budget honesty. It is not going to be easy for them; it is going to be more difficult for them. Of course it is going to make difficulties for the Public Service, but things will be far more transparent, we hope, as a result of this measure. I do believe that the amendments by the Senate have, to some extent, improved the bill. I hope that, ultimately, the government might see its way clear to accepting them.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
