PUBLIC SERVICE BILL 1997

The Australian Public Service is a great institution. It is a vital part of our system of democratic governance. It plays a crucial role in providing advice to government on the development of its policies. It lies at the heart of accountability for the way in which the decisions of government are implemented.

But, like many of our national institutions, the APS is showing signs of age. This is no reflection on the calibre or commitment of individual public servants. Far too often the creativity and innovation of those who work within the Service are being undermined by inflexible work systems and process-driven procedures. The Public Service Act, enacted in 1922 and amended on a piecemeal basis more than a hundred times since, is a key reason for that. It looks to a bygone age rather than forward to the next century. The Act—together with regulations, awards and agreements preserves a rule-bound culture that emphasises control of inputs rather than effectiveness of outcomes.

The previous government, to its credit, recognised that truth. Our Government, hopefully with bipartisan support, intends to address it. If we do not, then taxpayers will pay the costs through inefficient and expensive work practices and the public will have less access to the services they need when they need them. Equally important, the APS will provide a less rewarding environment for those who work within it.
I acknowledge that over the last decade the APS has already undergone significant change. Yet more, much more, needs to be done.

The Government is committed to achieving significant micro-economic reform. That involves removing unnecessary red-tape from business, providing greater workplace flexibility, encouraging a direct relationship between employers and employees and providing the incentives necessary to encourage improved industry performance.

Reform of public administration is a key part of that process. Until recently the APS had a monopoly in the provision of government services. Effectively it enjoyed a protective barrier from more efficient competitors. Now, as the provision of public services becomes contestable, the pressures for structural adjustment in public administration are great.

There are, of course, some fundamental distinctions between the public and private sectors. The private sector is responsive to the market. It delivers goods and services to customers. The public sector is, within the framework of ministerial responsibility, accountable to the public. It provides services, often entitlements, to citizens. The high ethical standards required of public servants reflect those differences.

But recognition of this essential truth should not blind us to the fact that the manner in which APS workplaces are organised and people are managed is subject to the same economic, social and technological pressures that face other Australian businesses.

Maintaining and revitalising a career public service is a key part of our Government's strategy to improve Australia's governance and prepare it for the future. That, in particular, is why our Government has sought to give a priority to the process of public service reform as an integral element of its broader industrial reform agenda.

Our commitment to reform is reflected in the passage of new financial management legislation, the introduction of Government Service Charters and the promotion of more flexible employment arrangements under the Workplace Relations Act.
The modernisation of the principal legislation regulating the Australian Public Service, the Public Service Act 1922, is a vital element of this public service reform agenda.

On 26 June 1997, Minister Reith introduced into Parliament a Bill to replace the current legislative framework for the establishment and management of the Australian Public Service. This Bill proposes a modern Act, embodying a new approach to protecting the public interest of citizens, while providing a far more flexible framework for the management of employees. It seeks to replace an Act which is generally accepted to be out-dated, excessively complex, overly prescriptive and unnecessarily centralist in its perspective.

The new Bill will provide a legislative basis for APS employment which will allow the APS to provide better policy advice to the Government and higher quality, more accessible services to the community. It will encourage the APS to seek maximum value for public funds rather than minimise risk.

The Bill emphasises the distinctive ethos of Australia's public administration and Parliament's expectations of the public service. The Bill will maintain the Service's integrity and professionalism by setting statutory values and a code of conduct that must be upheld by all public servants. This will strengthen the traditional ethos of public service and remedy the manifest shortcomings of the current legislation. The 1997 Bill establishes a framework for an apolitical and non-partisan public service. In contrast the 1922 Act is silent on such fundamental matters.

The new Bill provides a fair balance between enhanced accountability and devolved management responsibility. It establishes that employment powers within APS agencies rest with their chief executives and vests in them greater authority to meet the distinctive needs of their own organisations.

Agency Heads will be given the power, on behalf of the Commonwealth, to engage persons as employees. Within the law, it is they who will determine many of the conditions which attach to employment. It is they who will assign duties or terminate employment. This will provide Secretaries and Agency Heads with the flexibility needed to provide more rewarding jobs for their staff and to develop employment arrangements tailored to the expectations of the clients they serve.

There will be those who seek to characterise these changes as diminishing the fairness with which employees are treated in the APS. This is, of course, a nonsense. The new Act will not erode the position of employees in terms of dealing with their employer. They will have access to the same protections in dealing with their employer as apply to the rest of the Australian workforce under the Workplace Relations Act. In addition they will be managed under an umbrella of APS values which guard their rights.

The vast majority of provisions in the current Public Service Act will no longer be required. Detailed control over matters such as transfer, promotion, advancement, suspension, leave of absence, mobility and re-integration will be removed. So, too, will most of the provisions relating to the management of misconduct, discipline and performance. These are matters that are best resolved at the workplace level.

Indeed the devolution of employment powers will provide public servants with far greater freedom than they have ever enjoyed before. The conditions of their employment will be tailored to the particu lar circumstances of their own workplace without unnecessary legislative restriction or central regulation.
Devolving employment decisions will provide a firm foundation for co-operative workplace relations based on genuine consultation and direct communication.

The Prime Minister and Public Service Minister will continue to have appropriate powers to ensure that the interests of the Service as a whole are protected. The Public Service Minister, for example, may, subject to the application of awards, determine the remuneration and other conditions of service where it is desirable because of special circumstances. The Minister may also make rules about the classification of APS employees. These powers will ensure that an effective balance can be struck between devolution to agencies and Service-wide cohesion.

At the same time as it devolves management responsibility, the Bill ensures that the powers vested in Agency Heads are exercised appropriately. The Bill provides for enhanced Parliamentary scrutiny and greater public accountability. It requires Agency Heads to uphold and promote the values of the APS.

The Bill sets out the public interest. It also provides new mechanisms for its protection. To this end, the Bill, together with the subordinate legislation, provides the Public Service Commissioner with far greater powers of review, investigation and report than are provided by the current Act.

The Commissioner will be required to uphold the traditional ethos of public service, ensure appropriate standards of behaviour for public servants and maintain public confidence in the way they do their business. The Bill provides the Commissioner with considerable powers to review, evaluate and make recommendations on APS employment policies or practices, either at the Minister's request or at her or his own instigation.

Under the Bill, the Commissioner will issue Directions in relation to the APS Values to ensure that the APS incorporates the Values. Agency Heads and APS employees will be required to comply with these Directions, as well as with the APS Values and Code of Conduct.

The Commissioner will also be required to report to Parliament each year on the state of the Australian Public Service. She or he will be able to report at any other time on particular matters that are deemed to warrant it.

The Bill makes provision for the creation of bodies to be known as executive agencies. This will provide a more satisfactory arrangement than the present use of section 67 of the Constitution where the Government wishes to establish an organisation with a degree of separateness from a minister's department and where no statutory powers are required to be exercised.

The Public Service Bill has undergone extensive scrutiny by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. I am pleased that the Committee supported the need for the present Act to be replaced and favoured the simplification, modernisation and more accessible format of the new Bill.

The report of the JCPA made a number of unanimous recommendations. The Government proposes to adopt, in whole or in part, the twenty recommendations made by the Committee. The Government has also given close consideration to the substantive comments contained in the report but which were not expressed formally as recommendations and, in one crucial matter, intends to accept the Committee's views.

In the House of Representatives, the Government moved sixteen amendments to the original Public Service Bill and five amendments to the Public Employment (Consequential and Transitional) Bill in order to pick up a number of the recommendations of the JCPA. Those amendments were accepted without dissent by the House of Representatives. Let me now indicate how the Bill has been amended.

The Government has been persuaded that the APS Values can be further strengthened. In particular, the Bill now recognises explicitly the need for Secretaries to provide advice to Government which is "frank, honest, comprehensive and accurate" as well as "timely". It also places accountability in the context of Ministerial responsibility.
The JCPA also asked that clauses 13 and 15 of the Bill, which relate to the APS Code of Conduct, be further considered. Changes have been made to the Bill as a result.

Much of the evidence given before the JCPA related to the status of Secretaries. This is somewhat perplexing since, as the Committee noted, the tenure of Secretaries will not be changed by the new Act. The Public Service Act was amended during the Opposition's term of office to allow a Secretary's appointment to be terminated. It was during those years, too, that the policy was introduced that all future appointments of Secretaries would be fixed term.

The JCPA supported the continuation of the current arrangements. I agree with this conclusion. In the experience of the Government, Secretaries are as frank and fearless in their advice today as they were in the 1970s.

The Public Service Bill proposes that the Prime Minister set the remuneration of Secretaries, and that agency Ministers set the remuneration of the Heads of Executive Agencies, usually after seeking the advice of the Remuneration Tribunal. On the recommendation of the JCPA, the remuneration set for Agency Heads will be made public in the annual financial statements of Commonwealth agencies.

The JCPA also proposed, and the Government agrees, that Secretaries and Heads of Executive Agencies must prepare annual reports in accordance with the general requirements of the JCPA. The Explanatory Memorandum to the Bill has been amended to indicate this requirement.

The Bill retains the concept of the Senior Executive Service (SES) and includes for the first time a clear statement of the Service-wide role of the SES. While Agency Heads will have enhanced responsibilities in relation to the SES, the Public Service Commissioner will be required to issue Directions about employment matters relating to SES employees. These will cover appropriate selection processes, in order to ensure that decisions are made on the basis of merit, and termination processes, including a requirement to certify that a termination is in the best interests of the Service. This will address JCPA concerns that SES employees should be free from any apprehension that they may be dismissed for providing robust advice to their Agency Head. I emphasise that the Directions, just as the regulations, are legislative instruments which Parliament can disallow.

The Bill introduces a streamlined approach to the review of employment actions. The JCPA concluded that there is a clear need for a revision, of the current grievance and appeal mechanisms. The present review system contains too many avenues of appeal, resulting in complicated and convoluted processes. The responsibility to afford public servants a right of review of employment decisions needs to be balanced against the need to reduce the costs associated with a grievance-based workplace culture.

However, I emphasise that the Bill does not propose—and has never sought—the abolition of external review. It explicitly provides public servants with a right to seek review of any APS action that relates to their employment and allows for independent external review from outside their own agency. The detail of the review processes and the particular rights afforded to staff will be set out in the new Public Service Regulations. With due regard to the recommendation of the JCPA, these provisions have been made simpler, clearer and more concise than the draft they considered.

Although the JCPA made no recommendation on the matter, it expressed a view that it was appropriate for the Public Service Commissioner to set standards and review Service-wide performance. However, to address any perception of a conflict of interest, it suggested that in addition there should be a Merit Protection Commissioner, with separate statutory powers, to review individual employment actions. The Government has agreed to take up this suggestion, and the Bill has been amended accordingly. It reflects a significant amendment to the original Bill and has been made only after the most careful consideration.

The Merit Protection Commissioner will be able to investigate a complaint and, much like the Commonwealth Ombudsman, make recommendations to an Agency Head on how it should be addressed. If not satisfied with the response the Merit Protection Commissioner will report that conclusion to the Public Service Commissioner who will have the power to report to the Minister and, if necessary, to Parliament. These represent very substantial powers of review and scrutiny.

It is clear from my remarks that merit selection will remain a fundamental principle in selection decisions under the Bill. Indeed the Bill specifically prohibits patronage or favouritism in staffing, and prevents Ministers from involving themselves in staffing decisions relating to particular individuals. The JCPA recommended that the definition of merit should be included in the Bill rather than, as originally proposed, in the subordinate legislation. That recommendation has been accepted and the Bill was amended in the House to include a definition of merit which is based upon suggestions made by the Womens' Electoral Lobby and supported by the JCPA.

Another important element of the Bill is the protection that it provides for the first time to public interest whistleblowers. Until now public interest whistleblowers in the APS have not had an established mechanism to hear allegations of misconduct within the Service. To remedy that defect, the Bill provides that those public servants who believe they have evidence of fraud or misconduct will now be able to make reports to their Agency Head or the Public Service Commissioner, an approach which—unlike the leaking of confidential information on government business—will serve to protect the public interest. The Bill also provides whistleblowers with legislative protection against victimisation or discrimination.

The JCPA recommended that the Government should consider widening this whistleblowers' legislation beyond the APS. The Government has agreed to this recommendation and has referred the matter to the Attorney-General for his consideration.

An important new initiative of this Bill is the requirement that each Agency Head must establish a workplace diversity program. While these programs will operate to ensure that workplaces are free from discrimination, they will go further than the arrangements in the current legislation for Equal Employment Opportunity.

The programs will recognise that a Service which values and uses the diverse backgrounds and perspectives of its employees is likely to be more productive and creative. The need to better balance work and family responsibilities through the development of appropriate workplace systems and structures will be an important aspect of a workplace diversity program.

It is important for Parliament to be able to assess the effectiveness of these programs. The JCPA recommended that the Public Service Commissioner's Directions should require Agency Heads to evaluate the outcomes of their workplace diversity programs and to provide the Commissioner with all the information necessary to carry out comparisons of the programs on an agency-by-agency basis. The Government accepts that these proposals will strengthen public scrutiny of the programs, and they are now included in the Direction on Diversity in Employment.

The current Public Service Act gives various rights of return to those who leave the APS to work with other Commonwealth bodies. These mobility provisions are lengthy and complex. They represent a considerable liability for public service agencies. The Government's intention is to provide agencies with the discretion to determine arrangements that best meet their needs.

The mobility rights of those people who are covered by the current provisions will be preserved for a transitional period. The JCPA has recommended that the transitional period should be extended from one year to three. The Government has agreed to this proposal, and the transitional regulations made under the Public Employment (Consequential and Transitional) Amendment Bill will include a transitional period of three years.

It should be noted that mobility of staff between agencies is specifically provided for in the Bill. Employees will still be able to move from one APS agency to another on promotion or transfer without having to resign or be re-engaged. The Classification Rules, by grouping similar classification levels, will facilitate mobility across the Service. The Bill also continues in a simplified form the current provisions for the movement of APS employees where the Government has made machinery of government changes or administrative rearrangements. Similarly, the Public Service Commissioner will retain the power to compulsorily transfer employees between agencies where they are excess.
The importance of the role of Parliament in scrutinising the administration of the APS is acknowledged in this Bill. It requires the independence of Parliament and those who work for it.

The Parliamentary Departments are not covered by the Public Service Bill. Instead, it is proposed that they will operate under their own Parliamentary Service Act. It is the Government's view that the independence of the Parliament and its employees can best be recognised by establishing a separate statutory regime for those who work in the Parliamentary Departments and, for that reason, it supports the Bill brought to the Senate by its Presiding Officer. I am pleased that the Parliamentary Service Bill reflects the new approach set out in the Public Service Bill.

The establishment of a separate Parliamentary Service also has the support of the JCPA. However the Committee recommended that reciprocal mobility arrangements between the two Services be introduced. The Government agrees. Senators will find that the Parliamentary Service Bill provides for such mobility.
Let me conclude.

The Government, like its predecessor, recognises the urgent need to overhaul the legislation under which public servants work. The Government is committed to broadening and accelerating the process of public service reform begun in the 1980s.

The task is daunting. It requires us to change the workplace systems, structures and most importantly—culture of the APS. It means building on the finest traditions of Australian public service, its non-partisan professionalism and high ethical standards, in order to meet better the demands of the Australian public, and provide more rewarding jobs for its employees.

Every institution—including the APS—needs to be reviewed periodically, to have dismantled the accretion of unnecessary rules and regulations which emphasise process, and to be invigorated by the rearticulation of its purpose.

That is what the Government intends with the legislation before the Senate today. It sets a firm foundation for an APS of high performance organisations, able to contribute policy advice, implement legislation and oversight the delivery of government programs in an efficient, effective and ethical manner.
It is my strong view that the Public Service Bill, complemented by the Parliamentary Service Bill will provide the opportunity for the APS to renew itself for the benefit of Australia.
I commend the Bills to the Senate.
PUBLIC EMPLOYMENT (CONSEQUENTIAL AND TRANSITIONAL) AMENDMENT BILL 1997

The Public Employment (Consequential and Transitional) Amendment Bill 1997 deals with the consequential and transitional matters arising from the proposed repeal of the Public Service Act 1922 and its replacement by the legislation set out in the Public Service Bill 1997. With the establishment of the new legal framework for APS employees set out in the Public Service Bill, certain provisions will be necessary:
. to enable the transition from the old to the new employment framework;
. to validate actions and decisions taken under the former legislation; and
. to make consequential amendments to the extensive range of legislation which incorporates references to the Public Service Act 1922.
The transitional provisions fall into three broad areas.

First, it is necessary to set in place conversion arrangements for those who work in the APS . With the removal of the concept of office for APS staff and the creation of a single employment category officers and employees covered by the existing Act are converted to employees in their corresponding agencies with their corresponding classifications. Fixed-term Secretaries to Departments under the old Act will become Secretaries of their corresponding Departments under the new Act. Similarly the person holding office as the Public Service Commissioner under the existing Act will become the Public Service Commissioner under the new Act as if he had been appointed under the new Act.

Second, as the Public Service Bill 1997 is primarily principles-based, there are some conditions covered by the Public Service Act 1922 that require transitional arrangements because they will no longer be regulated in the same way.

The most important of these are the arrangements governing the rights of return of staff who have left the APS to take up non-APS public employment. The current, very complex, legislative conditions represent a considerable liability for APS agencies. They will be replaced, subject to appropriate transitional arrangements, with a simpler model under which Agency Heads will agree to extend unpaid leave to employees to take up such employment where this is in the interest of the APS.

The Parliamentary Service Bill 1997 which sets in place a framework for the Parliamentary Departments will also be before the Senate at this time and in the event that Bill does not secure passage, appropriate transitional arrangements for the Parliamentary Departments are provided in this legislation.

Third, there is a need to provide for the continuation of processes already set in train. Action may have commenced under the Public Service Act 1922 or the Merit Protection (Australian Government Employees) Act 1984 that will not be completed by the time the new Public Service Act is proclaimed.

I refer to matters such as appointments, promotions, suspensions, transfers and advancements, as well as to appeals, grievances and other reviews of employment decisions. To enable action to be completed, regulations will be made to ensure the continuation of those processes after the new Act is proclaimed.
The validation of actions and decisions taken under the former legislation will be largely dealt with in regulations.

With respect to the consequential amendments, the Acts specified in Schedule 1 to this Bill will be amended or repealed as set out in that Schedule. The amendments can be divided into the following categories:
. changes in the current provisions relating to staffing to reflect the new employment framework;
. removal of obsolete references to the Public Service Board;
. consequential amendments to the superannuation legislation, but without any changes in the operation of the schemes;
. changes to the role of the Remuneration Tribunal in relation to the remuneration and allowances for Secretaries and statutory officers;
. removal of cross-references to reciprocal mobility which will now be dealt with by directions by the Public Service Commissioner;
. removal of references to the old mobility arrangements set out in Part IV of the Public Service Act 1922;
. standard translations for common terms in the old Act; and
. other miscellaneous amendments to ensure appropriate links to the new APS employment framework.

The Bill also deals with the consequences of devolving the arrangements for setting the salaries of the Senior Executive Service (SES). The link of the remuneration of Members of Parliament with the SES Band 2 minimum salary will be replaced by a link to the classification structure created by the Remuneration Tribunal for certain statutory offices. It is not intended to increase the level of remuneration.

Subject to any special requirements in relation to particular consequential amendments, this Bill will commence on the same day as the Public Service Act 1997. Where this Bill amends an Act which has not yet commenced, the amending provision in the Schedule to this Bill will commence immediately after the commencement of that other Act. Where this Bill amends a section in another Act and the section has not yet commenced, the amending provision in the Schedule to this Bill will commence immediately after the commencement of that amended section.
The proposed amendments have no financial impact.

Collectively the arrangements proposed in this Bill will provide the necessary certainty and continuity of administrative and management arrangements for the Australian Public Service. They will enable an orderly devolution of employment powers in the APS and a transition to a less regulated workplace.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset may I convey my congratulations to Senator Troeth on her recent appointment as a parliamentary secretary. This legislation, the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill 1997, enacts transitional arrangements as part of the process of restructuring the Australian Wheat Board and the marketing and pooling arrangements in the wheat industry.

SPEECH.PARA: This process started under the previous Labor government and therefore it is a process that we support. The objectives of this process and particularly of the legislation are to remove the restrictions of government control and regulation and to give the wheat growers greater ownership and control of wheat marketing.

The history of this process of restructuring of the Australian Wheat Board and the marketing of wheat, particularly for export, is outlined in the second reading speech of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) and is also detailed in the Senate rural and regional affairs committee report. I particularly refer to chapter 1 of that Senate committee report, which gives a detailed analysis of the history, a history—I repeat, for Senator McGauran's benefit—that commenced with decisions made by the Australian Labor Party when in government to bring about much needed long‐term change for the wheat industry.

So we support the thrust, the purpose of the changes that are envisaged in this legislation. As I said, that process began under an ALP government. It actually began in 1984 and, more particularly, with legislation enacted in 1989. But having reached this point where we are almost on the threshold of finality of the changes, there is a major problem with this legislation. I wish to go to the problems of this legislation, because there are major concerns in the industry that, if this legislation is enacted without some of the key problems being resolved, then growers are fearful of the future of their industry.

The first point to make is that the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill 1997 that is before us tonight is the first tranche of legislation. It is intended—and indeed it has been announced by the minister in his speech and also in evidence before the committee—that further legislation is to be brought before the parliament next year to complete the process of restructuring.

Evidence has been given to the Senate committee that it would be better if the entire package of legislation—that is, this legislation and the legislation that it is intended to introduce next year—were put before the parliament as one complete package rather than be dealt with in the two‐step process that the government has proposed. After consideration of the evidence put before the Senate committee and concerns expressed by the industry, that is also the view of the opposition.

As I said at the outset, we support the thrust of the legislation and we support the process that is involved, but we do believe that it would be far better if this legislation were postponed, deferred, even withdrawn, and brought back as a complete package of legislation when the second tranche of legislation is due to be brought before the parliament next year.

I would like to refer to, firstly, comments made by the minister in his second reading speech and, secondly, some of the evidence put before the Senate committee. In his second reading speech the minister stated:

The restructure of the Australian Wheat Board brings to fruition a process dating back to 1989 aimed at putting ownership and control of wheat marketing firmly in growers' hands. This will enable industry to control its own future without the restrictions of government control and regulation.
He goes on to say:
I am pleased to acknowledge that the restructure of the Australian Wheat Board has been driven by the grains industry.

The problem with the minister's glowing statements at that time about bringing to fruition this process of deregulation and enhancing grower control is that that is not what this legislation does at all. As I said, there is further legislation to come.

Secondly, and more importantly, his statement that the restructure of the Australian Wheat Board has been driven by the grains industry is not borne out by the evidence presented to the Senate committee. Further, it is not borne out by the most recent communications that I have received—I am sure other senators and members of the government have received them as well—from the major grower organisations in this country calling on the parliament to defer finalisation of this bill.

In the explanatory memorandum, set out in the general outline, is an analysis of the impact of this bill. Time does not permit me to read that out in detail, but honourable senators no doubt perused it when considering this legislation. What is the current situation? The current situation is that the major grower organisations representing wheat growers in this country, namely, the Western Australian Farmers Federation and the New South Wales Farmers Association, are calling on this government, calling on this parliament, to defer this bill.

What are their reasons? As I said, this is but part one of two tranches of legislation. The industry is apprehensive and concerned that, without having before them the entire package of legislation which will set out in full detail the way in which the industry will ultimately be restructured, they may be buying a pig in a poke; they may be putting their signature on the line to a structure that ultimately may not be in their best interests. Clearly it is not open to the government to submit, as it has done, that this bill and this process come with the support of the industry. It may come with the support of the Wheat Board, but it certainly does not come with the support of the major organisations.

This is particularly important because at least two major issues are unresolved. Firstly, the question of taxation and, secondly, the question of the future of the single desk. In relation to the future of the single desk, the government continues to give assurances that that is not at risk. But there are serious questions about the company, the corporation, that will replace the Wheat Board and the wheat industry fund once the process of restructuring is completed. The corporation may well run into significant problems with its listing on the Australian Stock Exchange. I know my colleague Senator O'Brien is going to deal with that in a little more detail later.

Another concern overlays all this. There is to be a review of that monopoly export power in the year 2000 by virtue of the national competition policy process. We have a situation where growers, whilst generally supportive of deregulation and greater ownership and control of wheat marketing in this country, are apprehensive that at the moment this process is only half complete. There are serious questions still to be resolved, and growers have not yet seen the full package of legislation that the government ultimately intends to submit to the parliament.

I will quickly summarise the technical details of the legislation. The legislation provides for the establishment of a holding company and two subsidiaries which will be wholly owned by the Australian Wheat Board and be responsible for wheat marketing and financing. The holding company will be known as company A, and it will be structured with both A and B‐class shares. A‐class shares will be issued to growers. B‐class shares will be issued to those holding equity in the current wheat industry fund, and that equity will form the capital base of the company. It is intended ultimately in these next few years to use that company and its capital base to drive the financing of the eventual marketing body.

Those holding A‐class shares, that is, the wheat growers, will have the voting rights to elect the majority of the directors of the holding company. Those holding B‐class shares will have the right to elect the minority of directors. During the period of transitional arrangements, which lasts until 30 June 1999, the Australian Wheat Board will still have responsibility for the export monopoly, that is, the single desk will continue. However, there is grave concern that, once that date is reached and the government's underwriting ceases to exist and as a result of the national competition policy process, the single desk facility may be at risk.

There is a range of other technical aspects to this bill, but again time does not permit me to go through them in detail. However, I direct the attention of senators to the report of the Senate committee. I will quote a couple of examples of the evidence that was given by a substantial number of witnesses or organisations to the committee. Firstly, I will quote Mr Wilson Tuckey, a Western Australian member who represents a large number of wheat growers. He said:

What I am really saying to you is that, even then, I do not think that is a good deal for wheat growers. I think it is a lousy deal, because I do not think those votes have got any value in this structure. I am really saying that the whole thing should be packaged together. You can chuck this piece of legislation out and nothing changes until we have got a complete package that is given proper scrutiny in the parliament and deals with all these other aspects.
Wilson Tuckey went on to give quite extensive evidence detailing his concerns, particularly about the issues related to future listing of the company on the Stock Exchange.
Mr Moffet, the Grain Section President of the Western Australian Farmers Federation, also gave detailed evidence. He said:

At the last working group meeting—and, for those senators who may not be aware, the working group is a body of the Australian Wheat Board, DPIE and the Grains Council of Australia—where we as an industry were trying to ensure that the period between 1997 and 1999 was a period in which the new structures will start to be reflected in the management systems of the Australian Wheat Board, it was made very clear that a conflict occurs between what is called the interim operational plan of the AWB for this period and the expectation of both government and industry for the post-1999 period.

Our concern is that, if management systems are not set in place and made operational within the AWB in this two-year period, where at least there is some government overseeing of the operations of the AWB, then it is almost impossible post-1999 to change that inherent management system, because it will be a board answerable only to its shareholders.
He goes on to detail extensive concern. I must remind senators that Western Australia is our major wheat exporting state. Some 66 per cent of the total wheat exported comes out of that state.

A key issue is this question of taxation. I will try to quickly summarise it for senators. As I said earlier, the equity that wheat growers hold in the wheat industry fund will be converted to shares in the holding company. They will then, of course, become tradeable on the Stock Exchange if and when the company is so listed.

A major concern of the growers who belong to those funds is that the tax liability that they may be subject to in the future has still not been resolved. I understand there have been assurances given on a number of occasions that that would be resolved, but it has not been resolved yet. The Treasurer (Mr Costello), the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, and the government have given assurances about what ultimately will happen to the tax liability of the growers' own funds, which currently make up the wheat industry fund.
I have received correspondence in the last two days. I received a letter from the Western Australian Farmers Federation, which wrote:
Dear Senator,
I refer to my correspondence of 29 October seeking your support in deferring the above Bill. You will recall there were two major unresolved issues that I identified, they being:
1. tax liabilities that wheat growers Australia wide may be exposed to have still not been clarified by the Federal Treasurer,

2. it appears that listing on the Australian Stock Exchange (ASX), something this Bill will facilitate, will only be possible if growers' control of the AWB is relinquished. This fundamental objective (that is, control) is the key to wheat growers' support for this legislation.

They go on to say that in light of this they are seeking that the bill be deferred. I have similar correspondence from the New South Wales Farmers Federation. They wrote today asking for our urgent support for deferral of the bill for the very same reasons.

So what we actually have are growers not supporting this legislation, even though the government says it is an integral part of the process; that is, that this reform has been led by growers and supported by growers. A key feature of that is still not resolved, and that is because the growers' organisations are saying, firstly, major issues about taxation liability for their own funds that currently exist in the wheat industry fund have still not been resolved and, secondly, significant issues about ultimately listing the company on the Stock Exchange have still also not been resolved to their satisfaction.

So if, as the minister said in his second reading speech, this legislation is grower sponsored and grower supported, I have to say it is clear that that is not the case. Therefore, the government should have serious regard to the views of those organisations. We believe the government should be prepared to adjourn this legislation or defer it or even look at withdrawing it and bringing it back as an entire package next year when it has resolved these issues. Therefore, I move:
Omit all words after "That", substitute "the Senate:

PARA.TAB: (i) the unresolved taxation arrangements to apply following the restructuring of the Australian Wheat Board and the Wheat Industry Fund, and their impact on the industry, and
(ii) that further legislation is proposed to be introduced next year to complete the restructuring process; and

SPEECH.PARA: (b) resolves that further consideration of the bill be postponed until:

PARA.TAB: (i) the issues of serious concern raised by the industry have been resolved,
(ii) the legislation necessary to complete the restructuring has been introduced, and

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —Like other senators, I, too, have been lobbied by one of the major farming groups concerned with the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill 1997 —and I refer to the Western Australian Farmers Federation. The Western Australian Farmers Federation together with the New South Wales Farmers Association claim that those two states together count for approximately 75 per cent of Australia's wheat production. We all know that those two organisations do not represent every farmer in their two states and may not necessarily represent every member of their organisation. However, in these matters they are very serious players indeed and their views must be taken very seriously into account.

SPEECH.PARA: They have said to me that there are two major unresolved issues from their point of view. One is the tax liabilities that wheat growers Australia wide may be exposed to have still not been clarified by the federal Treasurer (Mr Costello). I must say that, in respect of tax liabilities, they join with lots of members of the Australian community. They also say that listing on the Australian Stock Exchange, which is something the bill will facilitate, will be possible only if growers' control of the Australian Wheat Board is relinquished. This fundamental objective—that is, control—is the key to wheat growers' support for this legislation.

The federal government has not yet addressed the tax issue and no suitable corporate structure has yet been developed that will suit the Australian Stock Exchange. They have asked that the bill be delayed until autumn 1998. Quite frankly, I would not know whether it is a reasonable proposition to delay until autumn 1998, but it does appear that there is a strong feeling from these major organisations that delays should occur and that, if possible, the two bills—this one and the one to follow—should be dealt with cognately.

The government, particularly the coalition partner, the National Party, presumably are very close to the Western Australian Farmers Federation and the New South Wales Farmers Association, so I should think they are right on top of those issues. It will be interesting to hear how they view it. That is the first thing I must put on the table, as it were; that, as a Western Australian senator, a substantial constituency is suggesting that the time is not yet right for this bill to be considered.

My second interest in the bill is to do with matters of accountability. Senators present would know that rural affairs is not my portfolio but accountability is. Individual farmers and groups of farmers over time, together with other constituencies at various times, have expressed to me the fear of dominance or capture by partisan or particular interests when governments have a hand in any kind of board, authority or organisation where people are appointed to manage it. That fear is regardless of which government is in power.

My party, the Australian Democrats, are opposed to appointments based on mateship. We are opposed to a politically partisan appointment structure. I have previously brought to the Senate's attention the matter of the Nolan committee in the United Kingdom. Finally, even that class-rigid society got sick of the ministerial patronage that went on there and through the Nolan committee it recom mended a wholesale review and overhaul of the system of ministerial patronage and advanced a transparent, accountable and open appointment system.

You would have noted before you the circulation of amendments by me which address the matter of appointments of ordinary members to the wheat marketing board and set out the general principles whereby those persons should be appointed. Frankly, we should not have to do that in legislation, but the history of this country is no different to the history of any other country where people have the power to appoint others on either a nepotistic basis, the basis of mateship or the basis of conferring a benefit. Whatever happens, that is a partisan way to approach things.

It is my belief and the belief of my party that it is in the interests of all Australians of any political colour to accept that a system where transparent appointment on principles of merit, independent scrutiny, probity, openness and transparency would be to the benefit of any organisation. I will be attending to that area of interest when the bill does come up for debate.

I must say in closing with regard to the second reading amendment moved by the Labor Party that, unless the government is able to indicate clear reasons why a delay should not be countenanced at this time, it is our inclination at this time to look upon such an amendment favourably. I would need to consult with my colleague Senator Woodley, who has carriage in these matters, but I must say the pressure, particularly from the two major industry groups involved, is such that the concerns need to be addressed.

Having said that, I have not picked up that anyone is necessarily opposed to the bill's intention, but they are opposed to proceeding with it until they get the answers they need. Accordingly, I reserve our position on the matter of the second reading amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose I, too, should explain why I am speaking on the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill 1997. There are not too many bills of this nature that I have spoken on in the past. I suppose that in itself is an indication of the importance of this particular piece of legislation. Like my colleague Senator Forshaw, who spoke earlier, I am not speaking in opposition to the contents of the bill. In actual fact, we support the bill and the way it is structured. It is the timing that we have great difficulties with.

SPEECH.PARA: The whole motivation behind what the bill seeks to do arises out of the work of previous governments, not just the previous government. The work was started by the former Minister for Primary Industry, John Kerin, and carried on by his successor, Simon Crean, and later Senator Bob Collins. So the coalition government's proposal is something that the Labor opposition agrees with.

Why are we rising to our feet this evening to speak on this matter? The reason is simple: it is the timing of the legislation. We are, in part, echoing the words of the Chairman of the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee—my Western Australian Liberal Party colleague, Senator Crane—who said this in a question during the hearings on the bill:
It is against the law to put up half a prospectus; you have to put one up that is signed off by the Australian Stock Exchange.

What the government is seeking to do with this legislation is to put up half a prospectus. It is just not good enough. It is certainly not satisfying the industry, particularly those grain growers in Western Australia.

It is worth noting that Western Australia is Australia's largest wheat growing region. Over the five years to 1994-95, Western Australia accounted for an average of 42 per cent of the national output of wheat from this country. It is likely that, given the growth in value adding—mainly in the feedlot industry in the eastern states—and given an increase in the population of the eastern states, within 10 years only Western Australia and South Australia will be exporting any quantity of wheat. Already, Western Australia alone grows over 42 per cent of the national output of wheat, accounting for almost 70 per cent of Australia's wheat exports.

This bill imposes a regime on Western Australian growers, who distrust the contents of the bill. That is the reason why the West ern Australian Farmers Federation are writing to express their anxiety to senators of all political parties. When the bill was listed for debate on 29 October, the WAFF sent letters to all Labor Party, Australian Democrat and Independent senators asking for `a deferment of the bill until commitments given by government to this organisation'—that is, the Western Australian Farmers Federation—`and the grain industry as a whole are honoured'. Over a week has passed since that fax was received by every senator in this place.

A similar facsimile message dated 9 November then came across today from Kevin McMenemy, the General President of the Western Australian Farmers Federation. I will only quote this letter in part because I will later seek leave to incorporate both letters. I have already passed them over to the government spokesperson. I refer to my correspondence of 29 October seeking your support in deferring the above Bill. You will recall there were two major unresolved issues that I identified, they being:

The Federal Government has not yet addressed the tax issue and no suitable corporate structure has yet been developed that will suit the ASX.
It is appropriate for me to seek leave to have these letters dated 29 October and 9 November incorporated in Hansard .

TALK.START.PARA: —There is very great concern on the bill in my home state of Western Australia. So great is the concern that we have seen a government member of parliament standing up and expressing their view in opposition to the timing of the legis lation. Having very recently been in Geraldton, I believe that, on this occasion, Mr Wilson Tuckey MP is expressing the views of at least part of his electorate on this particular bill. In his submission to the Senate committee that examined the bill, which is quoted at page 19 of the report, Mr Tuckey said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the existing legislation is premature and unnecessary, and we should be confronting the parliament with a single package that addresses all issues in one package. I find it ludicrous to suggest that we need this interim legislation so some people can go and get some practice in the commercial market. I think that this is just not true. The second fact is that I am deeply concerned for the future of the AWB and the whole marketing arrangements. I think they will fall in a great heap. I think if wheat growers want a guarantee that there is no single desk arrangement within 10 years, they will continue down the road they are going. I think they are going to get into awful strife, because their proposal is not commercial. Unless you take the Wheat Board out and make it a marketer and give it the freedom to invest in whatever it wishes over time, and give it a board of directors that have only one interest, that is, the shareholders, and the Australian Stock Exchange knows that, I don't think it will work.
That was said by Mr Wilson Tuckey, the member for O'Connor—a Western Australian member with a large number of wheat growers in his electorate.

TALK.START.PARA: —What party is he a member of?

—He is a longstanding member of the Liberal Party, and it is quite rare for such a member to stand up publicly and express what would appear to be an alternative view to that of the government and his party. I am sure, having been in Geraldton as recently as last Friday, that Mr Tuckey is indeed reflecting the views of his electorate, and reflecting them in a way that has already been reflected in the letters from the Western Australian Farmers Federation. WAFF, as it is colloquially called, followed Mr Tuckey in giving evidence to the committee and its representative, Mr Moffet, said very publicly:

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to say, having listened to Mr Tuckey, that the industry in the state does not support, and has not supported the general thrust of what is going on with the restructure of the Australian Wheat Board.
That is repeated in the rest of the report, so I will not labour it further here.

Western Australian growers are very disillusioned about what the government is seeking to do with the bill. They have no real understanding, and a great distrust, of what might be contained in the second bill when it is delivered to the parliament next year. They cannot understand why there is such a great rush to have half a pig in a poke at the moment. They cannot understand it at all, and no satisfactory explanation has been given to them to date to alleviate their grave concerns.

The government is asking that the Senate vote on this bill which commits the national wheat industry to a course of action that the Senate cannot clearly define until such time as the second phase of legislation is finalised. So not only are the farmers of Western Australia and the growers throughout Australia being asked to buy a pig in a poke, but the Senate is also being asked to buy a pig in a poke by passing this particular piece of legislation at this time. Is that fair? I will listen with great interest to what the chair of the Senate Rural and Regional Legislation Committee, Senator Crane, who also—

TALK.START.PARA: —Bring on Winnie!

—I missed that one, Senator Conroy. But I will wait with great interest to hear what Senator Crane of the Western Australian Liberal Party has to say on this bill. Will he be in a position to explain what his government is seeking to do to the wheat growers of Western Australia?

SPEECH.PARA: Before we commit Western Australian and other Australian wheat growers to this radical change to a system which has served growers and the nation well since 1947, we ought to be able to properly address the issues which have caused Western Australian growers to be wary of the changes. For example, this bill facilitates the eventual listing of the corporate identity of the Australian Wheat Board on the Australian Stock Exchange.What guarantee can we give to the wheat growers that their company will not fall into the hands of foreign competitors? Will any guarantees be given that that will not happen? Giant international grain trading companies, like Dreyfus or Cargills, have the means and the motive to purchase a controlling interest in the company. Will this bill allow them to do that? Will this bill prevent companies like that from undertaking such a course of action?

If the company falls into the hands of institutional investors, be they foreign or domestic, to whom do its directors owe allegiance? Are they bound to direct their efforts towards the benefit of the wheat growers, or is it to be directed to the shareholders? At least the answer to that question is clear. Company law requires them to maximise the return to shareholders. To attempt to benefit wheat growers in isolation of shareholders would be a direct conflict of interest and an offence against the act.

Wheat growers have been told that the memorandums and articles of the proposed new corporation will be so structured as to protect the interests of wheat growers in the event of such a conflict of interest. If that is so, has the Australian Stock Exchange given its approval to these memorandums and articles? If so, to what extent have they needed to be altered from those originally proposed and on which this proposition has been sold to wheat growers? Has this issue been the subject of the Senate committee's deliberation, and in what depth and detail did the committee deliberate upon it?

Chapter 3 of the committee's report—and I commend my opposition colleagues on the quality of the report—deals with some of the issues that have been raised by wheat growers concerning the proposed corporate structure and it quite properly calls for these concerns to be taken into account. I differ from the committee's report where it recommends that we proceed to pass the bill unamended and then deal with these issues in the drafting of the second tranche bill. That is simply unacceptable. I am not surprised that wheat growers in Western Australia feel angry and let down by the coalition—by government senators—and the attitude that they have taken in rushing this legislation forward when neither they nor we have a clear picture of the consequences. I concur with my colleagues who were members of the committee and who insisted that further consideration of this bill be deferred until the whole package of legisla tion is available and has been discussed by the industry and by the Senate committee—if that is appropriate at the time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Protecting Collins Street farmers—that is what it is doing.

—It is probably about protecting some Collins Street farmers, but if their interests are sold off to form multinationals they will not be protected either. I want to deal very briefly with the wheat industry fund, which now holds some $550 million of growers' funds. Most of those funds would be the property of WA farmers. It is these funds which will be converted to equity stock in the proposed company and will form the basis of the company's initial capital in the form of the B‐class shares. Growers have contributed to the wheat industry fund on a compulsory levy basis since 1989 and each wheat industry fund unit has appreciated in value during that period. Had the WIF been used, as originally intended, as a capital base for the Australian Wheat Board to launch a self‐funded trading operation from, the capital growth would only have been assessable for capital gains tax if, for some reason, the grower realised his or her equity in the fund. The question that seems to be unanswered is whether, in the process of conversion from the WIF units to the AWB incorporated B‐class shares, a capital gains tax liability will be triggered. Again, that is part of the concerns that the Western Australian Farmers Federation have written to honourable senators about.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened closely to the opposition speakers, Senator Forshaw and Senator McKiernan, which I do not often do. I had hoped to be somewhat convinced tonight. You then mentioned another primary industry minister, Simon Crean, as if he had something to do with today's legislation in any small way. He did not have a clue about primary industry, and I think he would concede that himself. What was he doing there? He had been shunted to one side because he was a danger to the then Prime Minister—that is why he was there. He did not have a clue and, what is more, he did not have any interest in the matter. As for Senator Bob Collins, he was part of it. He came in at the tail end of a decaying government and could not get anything done. He had bought his way into cabinet anyway; he had sold his soul, I think he told us once. Paul Keating wanted his soul, and he got it. Senator Collins went into cabinet as primary industry minister and he could not achieve anything because the government was already locked up by then. It is a case of absolutely rewriting history.

Make no mistake about it: this is a major reform for the wheat industry. It is probably the most significant reform. Unlike the wool industry, which faced fundamental changes to the floor price scheme, the sale of the wool stockpile and the future sale of marketing arrangements during a climate of severe downturn, if not despair, the wheat industry has the advantage right now, not a year or two down the track, of undertaking a major reform in a climate of good crops, particularly for 1996-97. TALKER.NAME: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Jacinta Collins)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McGauran, return to the subject, please.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I was provoked. I will now return to my script. I will return to the general principle of the legislation and exaggerate the point for the sake of clarity. The existing Wheat Board, a government underpinned body, is, in effect, being privatised. Though of late it has always acted as a corporate body, effectively and efficiently representing the wheat growers, it is now cutting the last link with government in two stages. The second stage is to be legislated in late 1998. The government, in agreement with the industry, is removing in June 1999 the government guarantee to underwrite Wheat Board borrowings for the pool system. With the removal of the underwriting, a whole new structure for the Australian Wheat Board will be put in place. The restructure will see the Wheat Board move from a statutory marketing authority to a grower owned company from July 1999.

SPEECH.PARA: In all these momentous changes, it is necessary to highlight that the bill provides for the Wheat Board to retain export control powers and to continue to manage the wheat industry fund, which will become the capital base for the post 1999 grower owned company. The wheat industry fund is being built up by means of a compulsory levy on wheat sales to be terminated at 30 June 1999. In detail, it is worth referring to the minister's second reading speech to explain the new company structures for the Australian Wheat Board. I will quote from the minister's speech:

From 1 July 1999, wheat marketing will be undertaken not by the current statutory Australian Wheat Board but by a grower owned and controlled company operating under Corporations Law. The company will assume responsibility for all commercial aspects of the wheat marketing, including financing and operation of wheat pools.
The new organisation will comprise a holding company with two subsidiaries: that is, a pooling subsidiary and a domestic trading subsidiary.

Shares in the holding company will be issued in two classes: one A‐class share will be issued to each grower and the Wheat Industry Fund will be converted to B‐class shares. B‐class shares will be issued to Wheat Industry Fund equity holders on the basis of one share for every unit in the Wheat Industry Fund and will provide the company's capital base.

In conclusion I make two points. First of all, again to respond to the opposition's speakers on why the government is not pushing on with this bill, as I have said, we have industry support in this matter. But, if they like to refer to the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee in regard to this bill, they will find that there are two reasons advanced in this report. The first is that it is a clear indication that reform is on track; that we are moving along the path of reform. The second is that the bill provides the Australian Wheat Board with the ability to move into the financial markets with the new structure properly underpinned by legislation in preparation. It is having this time to prepare for its move to a commercial structure.

It is worth reinforcing that the export monopoly power of the Wheat Board stays; the tenet has been and still is fundamental to the success of the wheat industry and its ability to trade internationally, particularly given the fiercely competitive market that Australia is up against. So often we must compete against generously subsidised United States grain in our traditional markets and I cannot envisage the day that the Wheat Board's power to be a sole exporter will ever be lost. To that end I support the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald, Sen Sandy

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly tonight on the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill 1997 , a significant bill for thousands of Australians involved in the production and sale of wheat. I would like to say that it is legislation that has industry support. It is a pleasure to follow my colleague Senator McGauran in his comments because he does have an extensive knowledge of wheat and wheat production. I know he is highly regarded in the Mallee and Wimmera districts of Victoria where he meets and speaks with wheat farmers and industry representatives. I also see in the chamber tonight my colleague Senator Heffernan, a wheat grower from Junee. Of course, the member of the executive who has the carriage of this bill is Senator Troeth, and she has a wide experience in wheat matters as well.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1996‐97 Australian farmers produced over 20 million tonnes of wheat, which is about three per cent of the total world market, but we are a substantial world player because most of our wheat is exported because we do not have a large domestic population. According to the most recent Australian farm survey report, an estimated 14,500 Australian farmers grow wheat. It is a very widely grown crop and, along with the sheep industry, is very much the basis of the family farm. If you add those involved in improving wheat varieties, the selling, the marketing, the transporting and the exporting of wheat, it is clear that this legislation is important to many people in many country towns.

This bill begins the structural transformation of the Australian Wheat Board from a statutory authority into a grower owned company, a process that began I guess in 1989 with the formation of the wheat industry fund. It follows the government's other major structural reforms in wool, and of course in the meat industries, which we will be debating before Christmas—very important legislation.

This government is determined to provide the framework for primary industry and primary industry bodies. Industries are then allowed to get on with the job. I think that is probably the most effective way and the route that we are going to take in determining how our future industries are controlled. The coalition believes in letting primary producers take control of their own industries, in letting those with the most intimate product knowledge and expertise manage the marketing of their products. From July 1999 Australian wheat growers will be in charge of wheat marketing and this bill sets in process a chain of events by putting extensive transitional arrangements in place as well.

The bill allows for the separation of the regulatory and commercial activities currently undertaken by the Wheat Board and it allows commercial activities to be carried out within a corporate framework rather than a statutory one. As a result, most regulatory activities can be abolished in 1999 when the new company is established, except those relating to the all important—as Senator McGauran has said—export monopoly. It is a monopoly which is clearly in the public interest to preserve. If you look at the comments of those that observe the operation of the Australian Wheat Board around the world, they do not like our export monopoly. If they do not like it, it must be a good thing, and it must be in the interests of Australian farmers for it to be preserved.

The bill enables the Wheat Board, with the minister's approval, to establish a wholly owned company with two separate subsidiaries to carry out its commercial activities. The bill provides for the pooling of wheat to be undertaken by a subsidiary company and for other work, such as domestic trading of grains, to be undertaken by another subsidiary company. The holding company and subsidiaries will be established under Corporations Law allowing a clean separation of pooling activities from other commercial work. The government underwriting of borrowings to make advance payments to growers for pool wheat will continue until 1999, although these borrowings will now be undertaken by the holding company. These changes give the new company a chance to establish itself and a chance to develop a commercial track record as well as an identity in capital markets. They will smooth the transition to the new grower owned company in 1999 and will enable it to borrow in its own right for wheat marketing after 1999 at a favourable rate.

The bill also provides transitional arrangements to enable the current board of the Australian Wheat Board to finish its term. It would alter the board structure and amend the selection process for the new board members in keeping with the new requirements. The Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill 1997, and the reform it gives effect to, is a good example of what can be achieved when grower groups and government cooperate. We both have the same goal, which is delivering the best possible outcome to growers. I believe this bill and the legislation that will follow in 1998 to complete the transition deliver the best outcome for wheat growers. They demonstrate this government's commitment to furthering Australian agriculture and supporting its future. The futures of those who work in it are in safe hands. I commend this bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane, Sen Winston

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in the debate on the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill 1997 . It is the first tranche of the changes to the wheat marketing legislation which will occur this year and in the early part of next year. The question has been raised as to why we should continue with this legislation at this particular time and not wait until such time as we have the whole restructuring of the wheat industry in one piece of legislation or in cognate legislation, as I think Senator Murray put it. The answer to that question is very simple and it is this: time is running out for the Wheat Board to restructure itself under a corporate arrangement to deal with the financial arrangements it needs to put in place prior to 1999.

SPEECH.PARA: Why do we require these changes for the Wheat Board? Why can they not continue and switch from one aspect to another? Once again, that answer is very simple. Some years ago the former Labor government made a decision to remove the government guarantee for funding of the Wheat Board. For people to say that the Wheat Board have had experience in handling these particular matters is very wrong. In fact, they have not. They have operated all these years under a government guarantee. As a wheat grower—and I should declare an interest in this; I think most people know my family partnership holds WIFs and we grow wheat—I have never quite understood that arrangement, but nonetheless it did happen. The current reforms which will end at the end of 1999 started back in 1989. That is when the WIF came into being. That is when processes were put in place to allow the wheat industry to become financially independent of the government. Some would argue that that was a good thing. I have always thought it was not necessary, but nonetheless it is going to happen.

It is absolutely crucial, for the future of the wheat industry and the establishment of the corporatised wheat board into an operating company, that in fact we see this legislation progress now. All of the other issues that have been raised in the debate here tonight and the other issues that were raised during our Senate inquiry have nothing whatsoever to do with this piece of legislation.

I have publicly had things to say about tax liabilities. I firmly believe, and I will continue to argue with the Treasurer (Mr Costello) and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson), that there should be no tax liability until such time as conversion occurs, and at that particular time it should start at zero. I think that is only fair and reasonable when you consider that back in 1989 the wheat industry made a decision to finance itself. I will continue to argue that that be the case. I believe that it is an argument that we will win because it is fair and equitable.

The other issue is the listing on the ASX. I will have a bit to say about that in a while. Once again, they are issues that are not dealt with in this piece of legislation. The separation of powers between A and B is not dealt with in this legislation and nor is voting rights, which is one of the very contentious issues. I note Senator McKiernan's comments that he would be interested to see what I had to say on this legislation tonight. I am here and I hope he is listening. The separation of powers was one of the burning issues coming out of Western Australia. That has now been dealt with but, once again, it has nothing to do with this piece of legislation before us tonight.

The memorandums of understanding for the grain industry, which are required up to 1999, have been negotiated and resolved within the working party. A timetable has been set for beyond 1999 for further MOUs, legislation or whatever is to occur at that time when it is fully corporatised. I will deal with some of these issues and refer, in particular, to our report on this legislation. Paragraph 1.4 of the report talks about the purpose of this legislation and states:
The major provisions of the Bill provide for:
. the transfer of AWB's wheat marketing and financing functions to an AWB wholly owned holding company and its subsidiaries;
. for the AWB to retain control over export and marketing of wheat overseas;
. the AWB to retain control of the Wheat Industry Fund (WIF) until the WIF component of the levy on wheat sales is terminated on 30 June 1990; and
. the AWB to be treated as the agent of nominated companies A and B in respect of new season wheat transactions (ie. what of the season that began on or after 1 July 1997).

The history is in paragraph 1.5. I do not have time to deal with all that tonight. I mentioned earlier that this started back in 1989. It is not something that was invented by this government. It is not even something that was invented by the previous government. It is something that came out of the grains industry itself. It is something, up to this point in time, on which there had been a bipartisan approach. All of a sudden the opportunists on the other side started going off on tangents and missing the point. Letters on this have been incorporated in Hansard . I will not incorporate this letter but instead read it. It states:
Dear Senator Crane,
WHEAT MARKETING AMENDMENT BILL 1997

With the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill 1997 due to be considered by the Senate later today, in light of correspondence received by you in the last few days suggesting the delay of the Bill, I thought it would be appropriate that I write to you to put the Grains Council of Australia's position on the passing of the Bill.

As I pointed out in the recent inquiry by the Senate Rural and Regional and Transport Legislation Committee on this subject it is highly desirable that the Bill proceed without delay through the Senate and I commend this action to you.

That is another point of view that has come through the Grains Council. I think they gave very good evidence to the inquiry, particularly with regard to the ASX listing and the importance of the single desk. The President of the Grains Council made absolutely clear the position of the wheat industry—and, I have to say, it is one that I personally support very strongly—when he said that the single desk was absolutely paramount to the future of the Australian wheat industry.

Let us look a little more at the history, because the thoughts of growers and their interpretations are very important. If you spoke to a wheat grower prior to 1989 and asked `What does the AWB mean to you?', they would have said, `Something like FAQ,' which is fair average quality. That has now moved to very refined quality control. One of the things that came out—I am speaking from memory on these figures so I may not have them exactly right—is that Australia had something like 46 segregations. The next best major country had, I think, 24. The US and Canada were around 24 or 22. In terms of developing that side of the industry, Australia has been at the forefront with the Wheat Board.

BREAK.PARA: FAQ then became GMP or the guaranteed minimum price. If you asked growers five or six years ago what the operations of the Australian Wheat Board meant to them, that is the first thing they would have said. Today it has moved to the single desk. During that 10 years, we have seen the deregulation of the domestic market and, as I mentioned earlier, the removal of the government guarantee as far as the wheat industry is concerned.

I wish to make a point about the delaying of the bill. I had a long conversation tonight with Trevor Flugge, the Chairman of the Australian Wheat Board. I know that Mr Flugge has come under some criticism, as have other chairmen of the Australian Wheat Board during the years that I have been involved in the industry. I think Mr Flugge, Clinton Condon and the other chairmen of the Australian Wheat Board we have had over the years have done an incredibly good job. In fact, they have done a fantastic job. In the 1930s, when the Wheat Board was born, and during the Depression I can well remember my father saying to me, `Don't ever let them destroy the Australian Wheat Board.' Before we had the Wheat Board I can tell you that the price one week was 15 pence a bushel. A week later it was nine pence. Two days later it was six pence and three days later it was thruppence. That night, we all went out and slashed the wheat bags. The Australian Wheat Board was born out of what occurred at that time around Australia. It has performed a very important function.

I want to re‐emphasise some of the things that Mr Flugge said to me tonight about the importance of establishing credit lines in their own right without a government guarantee behind them. There is a requirement of a minimum of 12 months to hedge in respect of the massive annual crop which we produce in this country and which we have to sell. We are one of the largest exporters of grain in the world. If this is left until the autumn of next year, time will have run out.
