Mr Flugge said to me tonight—and I asked whether I could repeat this in the Senate—that if this legislation is not passed tonight or in the next week or so, it could well mean that, come 1999, we are going to have to go to the government and say, `We have not got ourselves sufficiently established and it will be necessary for us to ask them to continue the government guarantee for another year or two.'

The wheat industry has been involved in this process for 10 years and there have been many beneficial changes during that time. The wheat industry must move to the next phase that was set out during that process. This legislation is a very important integral part of this. If we could have had all the legislation here before us tonight, I would have said, `Let's deal with it in one go.' But we have not got it here tonight. It will not be here this session because the grain industry has not come to a conclusion on a number of points. Also, the issue of taxation, which has not been resolved, is absolutely crucial to this legislation and, I believe, to the grain industry in terms of fairness.

I have put on the table a number of reasons why I believe the legislation should be dealt with tonight. I want to quickly touch on a couple of other points with regard to the grower corporate model. Let us see what was given to us in evidence. Mr Fisher of the Grains Council said:

There is a little bit more advice than that, too, Senator. Technically, the advice you have received is that the Grains Council has not approached the Australian Stock Exchange to get approval for the grower corporate model. Technically, the information that you have received is correct.
However, Bankers Trust—
which is representing the Wheat Board—

have approached the Stock Exchange on two occasions with the grower corporate model. On both occasions, the Australian Stock Exchange said that they are not in a position to give us approval for our grower corporate model because this will not occur until after 1999. They are aware of dual‐class model structures around the world. They have asked Bankers Trust to provide additional detail to the Australian Stock Exchange on dual‐class models.

And so on. It is clear that the corporate model is a flexible moving operation. I could point to no greater dual‐class model than Wesfarmers, a West Australian company, in terms of how they have handled that situation.

There is provision for the way in which this grower corporate model could be handled. It will be worked through and done in such a way that there will be the maintaining of grower control between now and 1999 whilst at the same time giving the important benefit of having a corporate operation. While saying this, it is very, very important for growers—because we do have growers in this country, many of them in Western Australia, who have holdings now with funds in excess of $$200,000, even up to a $¼ million—to have a fair and equitable way to access that money, when required.

Finally, I refer to some comments made by Mr Mortimer in answer to a question I asked of him during the proceedings. I will not read those comments out, but I asked, if this legislation were to go ahead tonight, whether or not, and if so how, it could or would impact and whether or not the Wheat Board could continue in the situation which exists without the second tranche. He said quite clearly that, in fact, it could; it is there for people to see. So, as far as this is concerned, the current arrangements for the corporatised Wheat Board could continue as they exist.

Nonetheless, I think we all are mature enough in this place to know that that will not be the case because, with the Australian grains industry having come to a situation where the previous government made a decision to remove the government guarantee, the position now is that we do need a fully commercial corporatised operating model. To enable the Wheat Board to place itself in position to be ready and able to carry out its task in 1999, I would urge the Senate very, very strongly to support this piece of legislation and allow it through the Senate as quickly as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not pretend to have any expertise in the growing of grain, and here I would defer to Senator Crane. And most probably—I am not certain, but probably—Senator Troeth knows a lot more about growing wheat than I do. What I want to address is what is proper for this parliament to legislate, what is prudent for this parliament to legislate and what sort of scheme should arise from this legislation. That is the issue before us.

BREAK.PARA: As Senator Crane has mentioned, a number of issues were dealt with when this matter was considered by the committee to which this bill was referred—issues which arise not from this particular bill but from the package of measures which is under discussion within the wheat industry. Included amongst those issues is the tax treatment of wheat industry fund moneys of farmers.

It is important that that be considered now, because part of the arrangement which this bill is predicating to put into place is a company structure which is intended to give some sort of tradeable value for the benefit of those wheat farmers who have money invested in wheat industry funds. Indeed, that is a critical issue for many farmers. They have moneys invested. They want access to those moneys. Senator Crane knows that they want access to those moneys. It has been an issue—and a crucial issue—in the discussions, in the reporting, in the evidence that the committee has received.
On that matter, the position of the Grains Council—and I have been heartened to hear Senator Crane's comments—was put by Mr Stewart, who gave evidence to the committee on its behalf. He said:

One of the disappointments of the process up till now is that we have been waiting for some months for a draft ruling from the government on the taxation arrangements. It has certainly been one of the disappointments at this stage. We have continually progressed the issue with the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Away from his office, I am not sure of the workings or the internal mechanisms of the government in that term, but he assures us that he is continuing to ask for that on a regular basis. We certainly want to see it as soon as possible. It is absolutely crucial to the growers and the growers support for the grower corporate model and the restructured organisation of the Grains Council.
That was from one of the officers of the Grains Council giving evidence to the committee on this bill. The tax issue is absolutely crucial. Have we got an answer on the tax issue?

I was contacted in my office this morning by an officer of the New South Wales Farmers Association. I subsequently spoke to an officer of the Grains Council about this matter, but the officer of the New South Wales Farmers Association was adamant that the issue of the treatment of the wheat industry fund moneys by the Treasury had been resolved—that is, at Treasury or ministerial level—and that the answer was not—I repeat, was not—satisfactory to the New South Wales Farmers Association. I also understand that that is the position which is taken by the Western Australian Farmers Federation; that is, that the response of the government, the minister—and I am not talking about Minister Anderson; I understand it is Minister Costello—on the question of the tax treatment of the wheat industry fund moneys is not satisfactory.

If that is an issue which representatives of the industry say is crucial to this package and it has not been satisfactorily resolved, then do we proceed with this bill which, I might say, abolishes the guarantee as of 1 July 1999—it is this bill that does it—and have a model which, in the absence of the rescission of this legislation, abolishes the guarantee and sets in train a process which will have a system of taxation treatment of the wheat industry fund moneys which is not acceptable to a significant part of the industry?
I received a fax from the New South Wales Farmers Association this morning. In that fax they say:

When the Association initially supported the above Bill we had expected that the taxation position would have been resolved before the Bill went through the Senate. A final resolution on taxation will not be made this week.
I will come back to that.
At this stage our minimum requirements, which have been known since March, have still not been met.

I understand that there is an assurance that Minister Anderson will take the tax issue to cabinet. And he may well do that. There is no assurance as to what the outcome of cabinet's deliberations on that matter will be.

Why should the New South Wales Farmers Association in effect buy a pig in a poke in terms of the package which will be the outcome of this bill? That is what the government is asking the industry to do. On the question of taxation, there are, firstly, no guarantees that they will have a satisfactory outcome and, secondly, there is a current position which is not satisfactory. The Grains Council said that the tax issue was crucial. I have quoted Mr Stewart on that. That is the evidence.

So let us not as legislators put in place a part of a package which at its commencement appears to be unsatisfactory. It may be fair to say that the tax issue is not part of this bill; it is part of the package. And if we put part of the package in place, as is suggested, which includes the abolition of the guarantee on 1 January 1999 and a corporate model for the Australian Wheat Board, how do we go back without rescinding that legislation?

But let us deal with the question of the Wheat Board. There was an article in the Financial Review a couple of weeks ago which talked about the restructuring of the Wheat Board in terms of its officers. New officers were appointed and some were effectively made redundant, because the Wheat Board is restructuring without this legislation in terms of its management structure. And the Wheat Board has a history of borrowing in relation to the operation of the single desk, the export of Australian grain. And that can continue—it has a history. True, it has a government guarantee at the moment. This bill will take it away.

But we step beyond that and we ask, `What else is necessary to give effect to the whole package? What else is necessary in terms of the second tranche of legislation and the other things which need to happen?' The critical questions include: what will happen to the monopoly which is to be provided under the legislation to the Australian Wheat Board operating as the single desk for the sale of export wheat; what provisions will be put in place; what sort of monopoly will it be; how will that monopoly report to the parliament which gives it the monopoly; what controls will there be? This parliament does not know. And we are being asked as law‐makers to put in place a structure which presumes a package of measures without our knowing what the next part of it will be. And one of the critical parts is an export monopoly. That is what we are being asked to effectively pre‐empt.

It may be true that we can have some sort of structure which operates without the second tranche of legislation and without the guarantee, but I have doubts as to how effective that organisation would be without the full support of parliament. Indeed, without the second tranche of legislation which gives it the monopoly on the export market, I do not know whether it would have any significant impact or be a real body for growers in this country. So we have to pass a second tranche of legislation to fulfil the whole package.

Does that mean that the government will then come to this Senate and say that we have to pass the second tranche of legislation or there will be a distorted body—which does not have a monopoly on the export of grain as is intended by the growers, which is proposed and supported by Senator Crane and which we support? I am not sure what we have. In other words, we are going to have the second tranche of legislation come to us, with a gun pointed at our heads, and we will be told, `Pass it or we have nothing.'

Why are we in this position? The problem is that we have, firstly, a desire by the growers that the new company should be controlled by growers and, secondly, we have a desire by the government and the growers to attend to the question of how they recover moneys from the wheat industry fund. So we have a proposed company which will have A and B class shares, and the A class shares will be owned by grain growers. There has been some argument about how the shares will be distributed but that has been resolved.

We have B class shares which are to represent wheat industry fund moneys and which are intended to be traded from 1 July 1999 and thereby allow growers to recoup their wheat industry fund moneys. To do that, it is intended that the company will be registered on the Australian Stock Exchange. Today I was told that there was a question as to whether the Stock Exchange as a requirement of listing would require that the single desk be sunsetted. That is a view which was put to us by the New South Wales Farmers Association. We would like some clarity about that matter—indeed, so would the New South Wales Farmers Association. They may or may not be right in relation to that matter, but it is a matter of concern and one which should be clarified.

What is of greater concern is the issue of how the Stock Exchange will permit the selling of B class shares when it is intended that the A class shareholders will elect directors who have a majority and therefore control the company in the interests of the growers. So the Stock Exchange has to accept that those shares which are able to be sold—that is, the B class shares—may not ever be sold in such numbers as will exercise a control of the company. There is an argument, which has been put to us by a number of witnesses, that that will not be permitted by the Stock Exchange.

An argument was put forward also that those bodies that buy B class shares will insist that the company is run as equally in their interests as it is in the interests of those who hold A class shares—the growers. That is a matter of conflict which may end up being resolved in the courts. No solid satisfactory evidence was put before the committee which resolves that issue. It is not surprising that bodies such as the New South Wales Farmers Association and the Western Australian Farmers Federation, to name just two, have been in contact with the opposition to ask that this legislation not be passed at this stage until the tax issue has been resolved, until there is clarity about the structure of the company, until there is certainty that the structure will be accepted by the Stock Exchange and until there is no question about what will happen to the single desk in the future.

Prudence should indicate that those matters ought to be resolved. We are talking about a significant industry; an industry that gives Australia over $5 billion in export income. In other words, it makes a significant contribution to the national economy. Do they deserve a package of measures which is not before the parliament in one lot? Do they deserve a measure which gives them part of the story but does not resolve critical issues which their representative bodies have raised? Mr Fisher, a representative of the Grains Council, gave evidence to the Senate inquiry. In talking of the advice they had received from Bankers Trust, Mr Fisher said:
They believe that the grower corporate model will be able to list on the Australian Stock Exchange, but they are not prepared to give us a decision at this time.
That is, the Stock Exchange is not prepared.

So, technically, the information received is correct, but we are very confident and the independent financial and legal advisers are very confident that it will list; otherwise there is not much point the industry pursuing this model.
That is the critical phrase: if you cannot be sure, there is no point in pursuing this model. That is what the representative of the Grains Council said.

Why is this government pursuing this model with such determination at a time when it cannot resolve the concerns of many grain growers? Lest it be said, for example, that the Western Australian Farmers Federation is not representative, they were the only body which came to the committee and said, `This is how we have reported to our members on what we have done. We have had meetings of members. We have had 1,450 growers support our stand and one member vote against it.' That is the evidence that they gave the committee. It is on page 67 of the Hansard. That is the position taken by a direct growing representative body—the Western Australian Farmers Federation.

As I understand it, the Grains Council is a peak body. It does not have direct contact with the growers; it has contact through other organisations. It is trying to do the best that it can in the circumstances, but if the best that it can do leads us to a situation of uncertainty then perhaps we should think carefully before we act on this matter. In terms of the department's view, Mr Mortimer gave this evidence, which is on page 142 of Hansard:

Nothing fundamentally changes in terms of the Wheat Board's operations as a result of the first tranche of legislation in terms of how it relates to the external world outside the four walls of the Wheat Board, if you like to call it that. The export monopoly will continue to be provided and indeed operate in exactly the same way.

A statement like that is a two‐edged argument. On the one hand, Mr Mortimer was suggesting that if we make the change noth ing will really change; we will go on as we are. On the other hand, if we go on as we are until we get the second tranche of the legislation, why can't we do that equally as well? The only argument that we have had is that somehow it will affect the borrowing and hedging ability of the Wheat Board because they have to prepare themselves for the withdrawal of government guarantee.

Given that all parties have, as I understand it, expressed in principle support for the package subject to seeing the whole package and, as good legislators should, passing it in the knowledge not of what they expect to happen but what will be the clear package, why can't we wait and put that in place? No detriment to the Wheat Board will arise from not passing this legislation—none at all. If there is any suggestion by the Wheat Board that this is the case, frankly that flies in the face of the evidence they presented to the committee, the evidence of the department and the evidence of the Grains Council.

As to the Grains Council position on whether we should be dealing with this legislation in two tranches or one, they clearly said in evidence before the committee that their preferred position was that we should deal with both tranches together as one package. That is the opposition's position. We think that this matter ought be adjourned until we get both packages. The opposition will be moving an amendment to the motion for the second reading to that effect. In any case, we should wait until cabinet has resolved the matter that Minister Anderson intends to take to it on the advice that we have received.
Debate (on motion by Senator Troeth) adjourned.

BREAK.XREF: CHILD CARE PAYMENTS (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS AND TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 29 October, on motion by Senator Tambling:
That these bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Child Care Payments Bill 1997 and the Child Care Payments (Consequential Amendments and Transitional Provisions) Bill 1997 . The federal government's behaviour towards child care has been in line with two philosophies: firstly, that the funding of social infrastructure should be reduced and, secondly, that women should be encouraged to stay at home and care for their children there. The effect of this approach has been $820 million worth of cuts to child care over the last two budgets.

SPEECH.PARA: The minister must be a very frightened man at this time. He must be very concerned that the present change to child care will result in the community reacting in much the same way as the aged population has by revolting against the changes in aged care. He really has very good reason to be worried because at the last election the government promised:

. . . ensure that all parents have fair and equitable access to affordable, flexible and high quality child care options regardless of whether they choose to participate in the paid work force or to care for their children at home.
By anybody's standards, this promise has now been broken. The annual report of the Department of Health and Family Services acknowledged:
Parents are paying up to $780 a year more for child care because Federal Government relief has not kept pace with costs.
The government are condemned through their own annual report. Families on incomes only just over $27,000 are paying $15 more per week than they did in 1994, which is not a long time ago.

Over the last two budgets, the federal government has brought massive changes to child care. In the 1996 budget, the Howard government abolished block grants to vacation care; froze the child-care assistance ceiling for two years, meaning that any increase in child care has directly flowed on to parents; removed the $30 amount per dependent child disregarded amount when assessing the family income, thereby artificially decreasing parents' entitlements to child-care assistance by inflating their income; capped non-work related care at 20 hours per week per child; capped work related care at 50 hours per week per child; reduced the child-care cash rebate from 30 per cent to 20 per cent; and abolished operational subsidies for community based long day care centres.

The Child Care Payments Bill introduces changes to the hours of care, and the coalition's 1997 budget measures for child care propose another round of significant cuts, which certainly will reduce the way child-care centres operate and will reduce the assistance and rebate available for parents. The child‐care payments legislation will continue the process of fee increases, the use of unlicensed care, the closure of centres and the reduction of women's ability to work. The government has failed to acknowledge the widespread community concern about its changes to child care.

The government members of the Senate Community Affairs Legislation Committee, when they examined the bill, restricted consultation by working to unrealistic guidelines. In fact, they did not allow many organisations which had expressed a wish to appear at the hearing to come forward and express those views and, in particular, not one group of parents was heard by the committee. In my view, that is a very significant oversight.

In the last fortnight of parliament, we have also seen a rather extraordinary move by the government to prevent an inquiry into the changes in child care by refusing to agree to a child-care reference being given to the Community Affairs References Committee. That is a quite extraordinary breach of normal Senate practice when the committee itself had decided to pursue that reference. The minister has instead insisted on proceeding with this bill despite the fact that 28 pieces of subordinate legislation, which are essential to determine how this bill is to take effect, were not made available to the opposition or other interested parties until last Thursday.

The Child Care Payments Bill introduces a number of measures, including immunisation, as the criteria for child-care assistance and the child-care rebate. It also legislates a 20-hour limit for non-work related care and a 50-hour limit for work related care. These measurers were, in fact, announced in the previous budget. The minister will allocate child-care hours to regions in a manner which is not yet specified and will limit places to 7,000 in both 1998 and 1999.

The opposition overwhelmingly supports national immunisation objectives. We support this objective to encourage immunisation, and we recognise that many child-care centres already require children to be immunised. We do have some concern that the criterion of immunisation for child-care assistance and child-care rebate access may, in fact, mean that many families who are worst off and have trouble steering themselves through those requirements for the application will miss out and will not be able to access child care. We have also recognised that in the past there have been temporary shortages of antigen and vaccines. In fact, we will be moving in the committee stage to incorporate an amendment that allows people to access child-care assistance and the rebate despite the fact that they have not yet been able to vaccinate their children because of these temporary shortages.

The Child Care Payments Bill also puts in place a number of planning provisions, including the limitation of hours used and places available, the regional allocation of hours and approval practices for centres accessing child-care assistance or the child-care rebate. We are supportive of these planning provisions which will ensure that the demand and the supply of child-care places are more closely matched, but there is great uncertainty about the method by which this will be done and there is no indication that mechanisms are being put in place which will, in fact, ensure that this occurs. It has not been communicated to the opposition whether there will be particular provision for children aged under two and whether there will be particular provision for areas that need extended periods of care.

When the bill is implemented, the structure will be in place for the government to limit child-care places long after the two-year period. With the mechanisms put in place through this bill the government may be able to, without further reference to parliament, remove places that presently exist. This worries me and it certainly worries a lot of centres and a lot of parents and children who utilise these services. There is no guarantee in this bill that existing services will receive approval to continue and that they will have the same number of places available to them. It is a further concern that nothing contained in this bill actually provides for work based child care—a service that many parents would very much like to access.

The government will allocate hours to regions, but has not specified what those regions are, how it will decide which regions will get what hours or what provisions will be made to increase hours in places when demand has not been met. The bill has no recourse to parliament on the minister's determination for regional allocation of hours. This again is a matter of great concern. The government's decision to limit care to 50 hours per week will also disadvantage women who live in regional and fringe metropolitan areas, women who have to travel long distances to work. In many cases they require much more care than the 50 hours specified in the legislation.

We also have concern about the harsh changes made to emergency child care. The government has said that a child can be at risk for a period of only four weeks in a 12-month period—a position that we find quite unreasonable. Again, we will be seeking to amend that.

But the meanest cut implied as part of this legislation is the abolition of the operational subsidy to outside school hours care. The Child Care Payments Bill 1997 threatens the operation of outside school hours care by removal of this operational subsidy, just as the previous budget's abolition of operational subsidy for community based long day care centres threatened their viability. This change will have a greater effect on the before and after school care than the previous cuts had in relation to community based day care centres. Many centres will close without this subsidy. Small centres and those in rural and regional areas are most at risk. In many cases, services will have to be closed or the number of qualified staff will have to be reduced.

BREAK.PARA: The government has not seen fit to recognise that the removal of this operational subsidy will mean that in many cases costs for a child will increase by an additional $14.50 per week. This increase will be paid in most cases by parents. The government has made much of the fact that it is increasing access to child-care assistance, but in many cases the increased cost brought about by the removal of the operational subsidy will not be offset by the increases in child-care assistance. So a lot of the benefits derived by parents will be taken away by the other hand.

It is only a matter of time in my view before this government also removes the operational subsidy for family day care. As we know, in the 1996 budget the government indicated it would be abolished, but with community outrage it was reinstated. I believe this is only a temporary setback to the plans of this government.

It is also of great concern to me that there has been so little consultation between this government and the child-care centres, the industry generally and, most particularly, parents. I know there have been seminars held in relation to the legislation before its finalisation. But certainly, since this subordinate legislation was finalised and distributed, not only has the child-care industry had little by way of consultation; it has had only since last Thursday to even comment.

A number of areas are of major concern to the industry, such as the future removal of existing child-care places, the lack of provision for baby places and extended hours care, the reductions in the period defined as `session of care' and the potential removal of direct payments to child-care centres of child-care assistance. As you may recall, it was initially announced in the 1997 budget that all payments in future would be made directly to parents. But again this was an indication that was not borne out by this legislation. I am unclear at this stage whether the government intends to continue with this objective. It may well be that, in the next budget, this change will be brought about.

The implementation of these bills is largely by way of subordinate legislation, as I have already stated. These pieces of subordinate legislation will tell us how this bill is affected. I do not believe we have had sufficient time to tell what the real impact is. The big changes that are occurring are in fee increases. The 1996 budget cut of $500 million included the abolition of the operational subsidy in the community sector. You may remember that NACBCS did a survey that said that fees had gone up $18 per week. As I said, this has been found by the department itself.

The government claims that the payment of child-care assistance to centres will make up for operational subsidies but, as I said, it will not be enough to ensure that parents do not pay more. NOSHSA, which is a group that represents before and after school care, has estimated that the administration time in one centre would quadruple because of the implementation of this bill, which would be equal to $169.20 in administrative costs.

Fee increases were also confirmed by the survey on child care carried out by the New South Wales Council of Social Service, which found that 80 per cent of parents complained of fee increases of up to $25 per week. There will also be a reduction in the amount of fees to be paid to parents for family day care from the current $3.05 per hour down to $2.30 per hour. This may well mean that the parents of a child in an average week of care will be paying an additional $40 per week.

The real concerns are with the closure of child‐care centres and also with the decline in the quality of care. In many centres, we have already seen a reduction in qualified carers and the removal of extra services such as hot meals and nappy services. Parents are being asked to assist by fundraising or by doing cleaning and gardening. The hours of care have also been reduced in many cases. This means that, while the parents are paying more for child care, the care being provided to children is not at the high standard it was when this government was first elected just under two years ago.

When we talk about child care, quality is obviously a priority. But if those centres are no longer available and if parents cannot afford access to the centres, then I suppose the issue of priority becomes a moot point. There is a very strong indication that many parents are taking their children out of child care because of the increased cost. When they take their children out of child care, they then put them into backyard care, which is not controlled and which is not accredited. This means that, in some cases, those children may be at risk.

It is a very sad day for the Australian community when this government feels that the dollar is more important than the care and safety of our children. But, very clearly, that is exactly the purpose of this bill: the government is saying that the budget bottom line is more important than how our children are cared for. I believe that this government should be very careful. While many parents who will be affected by this legislation are not fully aware of these child‐care changes, they will be. When those parents do become aware of these changes, they will certainly make their voices heard very strongly.

This government is not helping the battlers; this government is not helping families; this government is slowly eroding the social infrastructure that families rely on. The families of Australia will express their anger at the next opportunity they have because of one thing that is occurring, and that is this government is taking away their child care.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —The Child Care Payments Bill 1997 and the Child Care Payments (Consequential Amendments and Transitional Provisions) Bill 1997 make four basic changes to child care. They introduce a new rate of child-care assistance for school aged care, place a 20-hour per week limit on child-care assistance for non-work-related care, introduce a long overdue planning system for private long day care places, place a limit on the number of new private sector child‐care places eligible for child-care assistance available in 1998 and 1999, and introduce immunisation criteria for eligibility for child-care assistance.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats will be supporting most of the measures contained in these bills today, although I must say that the date which was originally proposed for the commencement of some of these measures has been a major cause of concern among parents and child‐care providers over the past couple of months. Based on our discussions with parents and child‐care providers over this period, it was soon obvious to us that the government had failed to recognise the difficulties which would have been caused by the proposed 1 January 1998 start-up date.

Concern over this start-up date was one of the main reasons the Democrats suggested that these two bills be referred to the Senate Community Affairs Legislation Committee. We are pleased to see that, as a result of this committee hearing, the government has now decided to delay the introduction of these reforms until 27 April 1998. This is a positive outcome for all concerned. I am pleased to see that the committee hearing, which was set up at the Democrats' suggestion, provided such an effective forum for parents and child-care services to make their concerns known to the government.

Before addressing any of the measures contained in these bills, I just want to take a moment to put on the record the fact that the Democrats have been very critical of the way this government has handled the whole area of child care. The government needs to be strongly condemned for a number of the changes that have already been introduced, and the effect that these changes have had on many families. In particular, the government needs to be condemned for the effect that many of these changes have had on the ability of parents—and especially of women—to choose how best to combine their work and family commitments.

I want to make it perfectly clear that the Democrats think that a lot of damage has been done to child care in this country as a result of cuts which were made in last year's budget. Some centres have been forced to close and a number of other centres are predicted to close within the next few months. No-one can afford to ignore the damage which has been done to those parents who have been forced to give up work or to give up study because they can no longer afford to have their children cared for. It is shameful to think that a government which so strongly speaks of its deeply held commitment to families can, at the same time, come up with policies which hurt the very families it claims to represent.

The Democrats have fought hard to prevent many of the changes which were announced in last year's budget from coming into effect. With other parties in the opposition, we voted against the abolition of operational subsidies for community based long day care centres, the capping of child-care assistance at 50 hours per week per child, the abolition of the additional income allowed for additional dependent children when assessing a family's eligibility for child-care assistance and freezing of child-care assistance and the child‐care cash rebate for two years.

Unfortunately, our vote, with that of Labor and the Greens, was not enough to prevent these changes from coming into effect, with these regressive reforms—although I do not know that you can have such a thing as a `regressive reform'—passing in the Senate with the support of Senator Harradine and Senator Colston.

The Democrats believe that policies such as those introduced in last year's budget work against families, and we will continue to take whatever steps are needed to protect the interests of families. What we will not do, however, is to take the hypocritical kind of approach we have seen the opposition take in the area of child care and in a number of other portfolios—most notably and most recently in respect of the government's aged care reforms.

We see nothing positive in using unjustified scare tactics to make a political point. We do not take the kind of blanket condemnation approach we have all too often seen the opposition take. Since the changes we are considering today were first announced, we have seen the opposition condemn the government for—

TALK.START.PARA: —Just because Cheryl left it does not mean you have to completely change your point of view.

—I missed the point of that. I will keep going and I will think about it. I will have to say this bit again! We have seen the opposition condemn the government for proposing measures such as the 20‐ hour cap on non‐work related care, and yet the policy of restricting non‐work related care is one that the ALP has long supported and, indeed, advocated. I found the opposition's condemnation of the government's 20‐hour cap on non‐work related care particularly hard to swallow—
—I didn't say that, Senator Woodley.

—No, wait a minute, it was not you Senator Neal. For months and months the former minister, Senator Crowley, championed a 12‐hour limit on non‐work related care. Not only that, but the opposition championed a 12‐hour limit in isolation from other desperately needed actions such as the introduction of a national planning system. It is interesting to note today that, despite all the fuss, the opposition is not actually planning to move any amendments to this section of the bill.
—But I said we were not opposed to planning. I said we were not opposed to the 20‐hour cap. I have said that all along.

—Right, that is good. I can see you have seen the light, Senator Neal, and that is very good. The Democrats will be supporting, as apparently will Labor, the 20‐hour cap on non‐work related care, although we do express concern—and I am sure Labor does too—about the effect this measure may have on the viability of centres in regions where there is currently an oversupply of child‐care places—south‐east Queensland and some areas of Western Australia in particular.

SPEECH.PARA: As centres in areas such as these depend on a large proportion of non‐work related care, the Democrats urge the government to consider implementing some kind of strategy to minimise the short‐term effect on these services. In the longer term, we hope that the long overdue planning proposal we are considering today will prevent this kind of oversupply occurring in the future.

It is good to see that there is an acknowledgment that we cannot allow wholesale unplanned expansion of child‐care places in any suburb that a developer picks. While we will monitor how the 7,000 places are distributed, and watch carefully to ensure that no rural or regional area suffers from this decision, we congratulate the government for moving towards a more responsible approach to future child‐care development. We believe that the previous government did not do enough on the need for planning, and it is good to see that finally the urgent need for this measure has been recognised and acted upon.

Some child‐care providers have also expressed concern about the heavy reliance on ministerial discretion through the use of disallowable instruments contained in these bills. While the Democrats accept that the use of disallowable instruments is not unusual and is, indeed, a fairly standard procedure, we urge the government to ensure that the industry is given the opportunity to comment on the 27 disallowable instruments which are part of these reforms. We reserve the right to move to disallow any of these which we believe will work against the best interests of families and the quality and affordability of child‐care services.

One aspect of these reforms which greatly concerns me, and which I believe needs to be changed—and I think others agree with me—is the provision of harsh penalties of imprisonment where a person has been convicted of fraud, making untrue statements, making false representation, or obtaining a benefit under false pretences in respect of child‐care payments.

While the Democrats have been comforted to some extent that the bill prevents a person being imprisoned for receiving a child‐care payment simply through an act of failure or omission, we do not believe that using prison penalties to punish offences relating to child‐care payments is either appropriate or desirable.

Let me pay tribute to a former senator in this place who spoke often about these sorts of penalties—I refer to Western Australian Greens senator Christabel Chamarette, who lectured us on many occasions about this. Her words certainly got through to me. I signal our intention—and perhaps other senators and parties in this place have the same intention—to move amendments at this point.

I also must express my deep regret at the government's decision to withdraw operational subsidies for out of school hours care. However, because the withdrawal of operational subsidies for out of school hours care is not something which is subject to legislation, I can only call on the minister to closely monitor and reconsider if necessary the effect this decision has on the viability of these important services.

Another aspect of these reforms which the Democrats would like to see closely monitored is the reduction in the hourly rebatable fee from $2.30 to $1.95 per hour for out of school hours care in long day care centres. While we understand the desirability of standardising the rebatable fee for all out of school hours services, and we applaud the government for greatly increasing the income level cut‐off for this subsidy, we do not believe that any increase in the out‐of‐pocket expenses for families using long day care centres can be justified.
I leave it to my colleague Senator Lees to address at a later point in this debate the reforms relating to the introduction of immunisation criteria for eligibility for child‐care assistance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition's horror budgets have radically changed the child-care sector in this country for the worst. They have moved funds out of the community based sector by slashing the operational and capital assistance provided to non-profit service providers and shifted the balance to greater reliance on private providers of child‐care services. Make no mistake: this has been an ideological move based on undermining the community and driving women out of the work force and back into the kitchen. The main rationale for the withdrawal of the community based centre operational subsidy was that it would:

SPEECH.PARA: encourage community centres to be more efficient and cost competitive with the private sector.

It was argued that any expected increase in fees charged as a result of the cessation of the subsidies would be offset by community centres becoming more `cost efficient'. This is spin doctoring in the extreme. You can read this as lowering child care to the lowest common denominator.

The real reason behind the government's attack is that it slashes $110 million from the child‐care budget, and it did not seem to care very much for the adverse impacts on working women, which are now becoming very apparent. This year we have seen work force participation rates for women suffer their biggest falls since the 1970s. While this may not all be due to the impact of the child‐care changes, they are undoubtedly a major influence. Feedback from community and industry groups reinforces our view that these changes are in fact leading to women being forced out of their jobs simply because they cannot afford child care. That is a situation for which this government should be deeply ashamed.

Figures from a comprehensive study undertaken by the National Association of Community Based Children's Services indicate that these government cuts have caused substantial increases in child‐care costs—in fact, double the usual annual increases. The figures show that 73 per cent of parents exiting care showed increased fees as the reason and that 67 per cent of those leaving are using informal care. The trend towards `backyard care' is a major concern and the social impact of the government forcing what could be second-rate child care on working women could have social impacts that this society will be paying for dearly in the long run. Many centres have been forced to adopt measures which seriously undermine service quality, with more than 25 per cent of centres in each state or territory having reduced staffing levels in an attempt to keep fees down. The biggest cuts to staffing have been in Western Australia.

The community owned child‐care sector has been ravaged by this government. In 1991 child‐care centres owned by the community provided 56 per cent of places; in December 1996 this was down to 27 per cent. The government has completely removed operational subsidies for community based centres and placed in jeopardy a system of high quality, affordable child care in Australia. Adequate funding to support the model of community ownership should be a basic tenet of any socially responsible government, which is probably why we have seen this government do its best to destroy the community owned model for the provision of child care. Community owned long day care centres have taken the lead in establishing the benchmarks for high quality care. This government's policies place those standards of quality in severe danger.

The cost of care is ultimately tied with the use of care. Accordingly, for many parents the rising cost of child care has meant either a complete withdrawal or a reduction in the hours of care utilised by their children in centre based care. The problem is particularly acute in Western Australia where, as I mentioned, the study showed that on average 12 families per centre left formal child care in 1997. Some centres reported over 50 families leaving and 40 families cutting back their hours. This is adversely affecting the very people in our society this government should be targeting for assistance: the women struggling to get a toehold in a work force which is increasingly competitive and in which industry is still failing to pull its weight with regard to child‐care provision.

We should be increasing child care, not reducing it. Governments have an obligation to support parents in their efforts to care for their children. We are also getting evidence that women in the work force with individual workplace contracts are getting the worst end of the stick in wages and conditions. I imagine that would add to the situation of many working women having to withdraw from both work and/or child care. What this government should be doing is listening to the professional, community based child carers in our communities in the same way as it listens to the coal, oil and mining industries. It should consider, firstly, increasing the child‐care assistance ceiling for centre based care to better reflect the actual cost of care; secondly, reinstating the $350 million taken from the children's services program in the budget and redirecting it into assisting affordability; and, thirdly, supporting community owned children's services by providing financial assistance to voluntary committees of management.

The government's other recent progressive changes have included the limiting of child‐care assistance to 50 hours per week per child. Again, this was purely brought in to slash $30 million from the child‐care budget in 1997‐98 and approximately $33 million in 1998‐99. Another area of concern is the cessation of indexation for the next two years with regard to the child‐care assistance fee ceiling and child‐care cash rebate ceilings.
Debate interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALKER.NAME: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Jacinta Collins)

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 9.50 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Payne, Sen Marise

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak tonight about an issue of crucial importance to the upcoming ballot for the Constitutional Convention. It is, of course, imperative for all Australians, but especially those young Australians who may be voting for the first time, to take the opportunity to cast their ballot in determining the remaining 72 delegates to the convention.

SPEECH.PARA: I raise this issue not only because the issue of constitutional change is one that I have long been concerned with but also because the broader issue of voting is very important for a nation which draws strength from its democratic structures. I want to reiterate the importance of the ballot for the Constitutional Convention not only because it is for the election of delegates to the body that will have the biggest single impact on the future of an Australian republic but particularly because it will be the first occasion on which many young Australians will have the opportunity to vote.

This experience of voting for the first time is something many of us may have taken for granted even if at this stage we remember it. But, in the context of the voluntary ballot for the convention, I believe it is very important to encourage all young people to exercise their vote now. They should particularly be encouraged to cast their vote in view of the track record of young voters in other nations where voting is conducted on a voluntary basis. In looking at the record where voluntary voting is the norm, the trends of voting amongst younger people are concerning. In the United States, the voter turnout for elections is often very low, particularly in younger age brackets. Figures for the most recent congressional and presidential elections indicate that as few as 16½ per cent of enrolled voters between the age of 18 and 20 actually took the time to vote. Certainly the impact of a higher profile presidential campaign results in greater numbers of young people voting, but this trend serves only to highlight the point I wish to make tonight.

Only by raising the profile of the ballot for the convention and of the convention itself will we ensure that anywhere near the numbers of young people who currently are able to cast their votes in Australia cast their vote in this, a voluntary ballot. The only way to do that is to constantly remind not only ourselves but the nation of how critically important this process is. It is this process, an educative one, that I wish to stress this evening.

Regardless of whether young people wish to support a republic or support the current system, it is still critical to vote, and we need to remind them of this. In particular, it is worth while noting the contributions of some who are doing their utmost to spread the word about the Constitutional Convention. It is particularly worth while to mention the contributions of the youth movements of the major political parties in Australia. Branches and divisions of the Young Liberals, the Young Democrats and Young Labor have all passed motions in support of the republic. In joining these organisations and in discussing issues such as the republic, these young Australians have demonstrated their commitment to participating in the electoral and democratic processes by which Australia is governed.

What is most pleasing about these expressions is the indication it gives that many young Australians are actively considering the future of their nation and the way they want this future to progress. Certainly my own division, the New South Wales Young Liberal Movement, has maintained constant consideration on issues such as the republic and those related to it. I see Senator O'Chee kindly acknowledging the participation of the organisation in that regard. It is leading the way not only for the New South Wales Liberal Party as a whole but for the party across the country. Their active debate and discussion does much to help educate all Australians about the issues surrounding the republic—issues at the heart of the convention.

I was also pleased to see that the Australian Youth Forum, held recently in Canberra during the session break, discussed not only the issue of the republic but also the broader topic of Australia's future. I would like to briefly revisit these papers of the Youth Forum to point out one of the many valuable recommendations that came from the conference. It was `to educate all Australians, particularly the young, about the issues surrounding an Australian republic'.

This recommendation of the forum strikes at the heart of what I am saying this evening. Education and awareness, both during the balloting process and afterwards, are the key to the Constitutional Convention not only representing all Australians but producing an outcome that all Australians can feel comfortable with. One of the most effective ways to encourage young people to vote is having young people with whom they can identify running as candidates for election for the convention.

I am proud of the fact that the Australian Republican Movement, with which I have been involved for a number of years, has an excellent field of young people on its tickets across the country. In New South Wales, the ticket boasts five young Australians committed to an open dialogue on the republic and related issues. These talented young people come from a range of different backgrounds, political persuasions and regions of New South Wales. I want to recognise the diversity and talent of these individual candidates and acknowledge their commitment to the process of Australia becoming a republic.

Gladys Berejiklian, a former President of the New South Wales Young Liberal Move ment, leads the young people on the ticket. She is highly involved with the Armenian community in Australia and has served her community in many capacities, including on the Armenian National Committee of Australia. Her commitment to the importance of the political process as a senior office bearer of a young political organisation is longstanding. By participating in this ballot, she continues that commitment.

A further demonstration of the broad diversity of appeal for the move to a republic is the candidacy of Stephen Crowe running on the ARM ticket. Stephen, who I am sure is well known to my Hunter based colleague Senator Tierney, is a member of the victorious ARL Newcastle Knights football team and is also a committed republican. He works with the well-known John's Boys to take the message to the people of the Hunter. Rose Kelly, currently a student at the University of Technology in Sydney, hails from the mid‐north coast of New South Wales and, at 18, has a substantial background in community and civic issues. As one of eight young people in attendance at the Bathurst people's convention last year, her experience in constitutional matters is already strong.

The candidacy of Jason Falinski, the current national President of the Young Liberal Movement and member of the ARM ticket in New South Wales, demonstrates the high level of support amongst the Young Liberals and, indeed, many in the Liberal Party for a move to a republic. Fifthly, Rania Wannous, at 22 years of age, is a long-time resident of Sydney's south-west and represents an Australian Lebanese background. Rania, who works for the Sydney based think‐tank the Evatt Foundation, is also on the Australian Republican Movement ticket.

It would be remiss of me not to mention that other tickets campaigning for election to the convention also have talented and accomplished young candidates standing. These people are running on a variety of tickets, including both pro‐republic and pro‐monarchy tickets. All are extremely committed to their individual beliefs. The crucial issue for all of us, though, should be that young people take the time to vote. In my state of New South Wales alone, there are 1.2 million people between the ages of 18 and 30. For many of them, the vote for the Constitutional Convention will be the first time that they have had an opportunity to vote. It is critical that they not only understand what it is they have the opportunity to do but understand the responsibility they have to help determine the future shape of our country—a shape they will live with.

While this is not a compulsory ballot, it is fundamental that all Australians exercise their right to vote. For young Australians, the opportunity to have a direct impact on the constitutional make‐up of our country is invaluable. Not since the conventions prior to Federation have Australians had this opportunity.

As a republican of long standing, it strikes me as passing strange that those who have long derided and condemned supporters of the republic for discussing and debating different issues and propositions for constitutional change this very day find themselves in turmoil while some of their number venture closer to the ground of progress and change. Former Governor-General Bill Hayden suggests that only a referendum can effect the change of name from Governor‐General to head of state. Lloyd Waddy, of the Australians for Constitutional Monarchy, immediately opposed any change to any part of the constitution today. Abandoned by their strongest advocates, who now also move to support change, the Australians for Constitutional Monarchy are in complete disarray and face their words coming back at them from the other direction.

In conclusion, I encourage all Australians to exercise their right to vote in the upcoming ballot for the Constitutional Convention. In particular, I encourage all young Australians to take the time to learn about the convention, to learn about the people running on different tickets and to learn about what it will mean for Australia to become a republic. The right to vote is the fundamental principle of any participatory democracy. It is critical that all of us, especially those who will maintain our democratic tradition in the future, especially young Australians, make an informed decision and cast their vote in this election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on the adjournment debate tonight to address the Howard government's ham‐fisted closure of the Radio Australia transmitting station on Darwin's Cox Peninsula and the equally ham‐fisted performance by the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston) in trying to fill the void. As honourable senators would be aware, the decision by this government to cut funding to Radio Australia and its Asian services in the last budget has left the Cox Peninsula transmitter station silent—a government decision that is directly against the national interests of this country. The station is a $40 million facility. In its last three years in office, the former Labor government spent more than $12 million upgrading the facility. I personally opened the broadcasting of the new transmitters. I might add that that money was spent in precisely the same way as the BBC World Service spent its money, for example, when it recently upgraded its short‐wave facilities.

SPEECH.PARA: You could be forgiven for wondering why, given the enormous sums of money that have been put into the facility and the universal acclaim for Radio Australia's output from the transmitters, any government would seek to silence the service. However, the fact is that the decision was taken in the budget by this government at the very time that Pauline Hanson was wreaking havoc in our relations with Asia. Of course, it was news today that it has recently been assessed that the impact of that kind of propaganda in Asia has cost us $100 million a year alone in the export of our educational services.

Senator Alston announced in a press release issued on 13 May that the facility would be mothballed from 1 July and the National Transmission Agency would explore possible future use of the Cox Peninsula transmitters. Nothing more was heard from the minister until the Senate estimates round in June when my colleague Senator Schacht took the issue up with him. The minister informed the Senate at the estimates hearing on 11 June that the government was proceeding as planned: the National Transmission Agency would mothball Cox Peninsula from 1 July. The government, Minister Alston hastily added, was `very much interested in exploring both buy and lease arrangements' for the facility `with interested parties'.

The National Transmission Agency informed the Senate that it had received a number of approaches from commercial and national broadcasters to use the facility. These included the BBC World Service and Radio Free Asia. Radio Free Asia is an American broadcaster, but quite distinct from the Voice of America. Radio Free Asia is in fact funded by the Congress—and very handsomely, I might add—on the same basis as Radio Free Europe was established during the Second World War. Senator Alston told the hearing that he did not consider there would be any objection to an overseas broadcaster using the facility. The Senate was also advised that Radio Free Asia had offered a `substantial amount' for the use of the facility. Senator Alston told us that he would be taking expert advice as to what guidelines would be put in place for the future use of the facility, presumably by a foreign broadcaster.

He saw nothing strange in the fact that overseas broadcasters were vigorously pursuing the use of an Australian facility that his Australian government had rendered redundant. He saw nothing strange in the fact that the facility was to be mothballed but that he had not moved to establish any guidelines. He presumably saw nothing strange in an American voice beaming out a huge `Good morning, Vietnam!' or `Good morning, Beijing!' from Darwin, replacing 50 years of factual, even‐handed and highly respected broadcasting into the region from Radio Australia.

Needless to say it soon became evident that the minister did not have a clue whom the National Transmission Agency was even dealing with, and the possible diplomatic repercussions. In answer to a question without notice less than a week later, the minister told the Senate that he recalled having a discussion with Radio Australia's General Manager, Derek White, in his office several weeks before about the interest of overseas broadcasters in using Cox Peninsula. Senator Alston was so disinterested in the closure of this Australian facility that he could not even remember the name of the American broadcaster that was actually the frontrunner—as we now know—to take it over. The minister thought it was `the Voice of Free America'.

Nothing more was heard publicly until the Sydney Morning Herald carried a report on Monday of last week headlined `Cabinet in a jam over US radio bid'. The story said that the Howard government was caught in a diplomatic squeeze between Washington and Beijing over a push by Radio Free Asia—or the Voice of Free America, as Minister Alston would have it—to broadcast into China from Cox Peninsula. According to the report, Australian intelligence agencies have predicted that Beijing would try to jam any Chinese language transmissions by Radio Free Asia from the facility. One of the attractions that was reported for Radio Free Asia was that the power of the transmitters at Cox Peninsula can apparently overcome attempts at jamming.

Beijing and Hanoi have both recently condemned Radio Free Asia broadcasts. The official China Daily newspaper warned recently against the `dangerous ambitions of the United States to create trouble and instability in regional countries by using Radio Free Asia'. Foreign Affairs Minister Downer pointed out to the Sydney Morning Herald that Senator Alston would have the responsibility for technical and commercial decisions in relation to Cox Peninsula but that he would examine the foreign affairs implications. `We are certainly not in a game of provocatively damaging our relations with China,' he told the newspaper. I assume he has since passed the message on to his hapless minister for communications, but many questions remain. The most obvious, in terms of the national interests of our country, is why this decision was taken in the first place. There has never been an adequate explanation provided on the matter by this government, especially by the relevant minister.

Has Senator Alston developed guidelines—the ones he talked about? If so, why has he not released them? If no guidelines have been developed by the minister, I believe the Australian public at this point in time has a right to ask: why not? Why had there been no communication between Senator Alston and Minister Downer on this sensitive issue before the Sydney Morning Herald report appeared last week? It is not as though this issue simply crept up and bit the government. The Howard government's plans to effectively silence Radio Australia and close down Cox Peninsula have been the subject of considerable debate both within and outside this parliament. I wonder if the minister could extract his feet from his mouth long enough during the current session to tell us what is going on.

The burning question of course is a simple one: what is the present status of negotiations between this government and Radio Free Asia, or indeed the BBC World Service or any other broadcaster, for the use of Cox Peninsula? Cox Peninsula is a world‐class short‐wave facility. The world's major broadcasters are well aware of its value and are literally queuing up in the hope of leasing transmission time on our transmitters for their access, on behalf of presumably the British government and the American government, into the Asian region—a region we continually say we are anxious to have better access to and relations with. Meantime, while we have an Australian government negotiating with the American Voice of Free Asia service, we have silenced our own Australian voice into the region. It beggars explanation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise again tonight to draw the Senate's attention to the essential role of the Office of the Auditor‐General, and in particular to draw attention to the work of the Victorian Auditor‐General in the management of public housing by the state Department of Human Services.

SPEECH.PARA: A recently published Auditor‐General's report included an analysis of the Victorian government's management of housing assets. That report, entitled Public housing: Responding to a fundamental community need, demon strated that the public housing sector in Victoria is not nearly as robust as the government would have us believe. It showed that on 30 June 1996 there were 61,700 households on the public housing waiting list—an increase, the report said, of 79 per cent over the last 10 years. It said that around 61 per cent of these households, or 37,600 households, have been on waiting lists for longer than two years with almost half waiting for periods in excess of four years.

The report also indicated that, despite the obvious trends toward a need for more public housing, the level of funding made available to the Department of Human Services for housing assistance by the Commonwealth has declined by 14 per cent in real terms since 1991‐92. The Auditor‐General's report indicated that the Department of Human Services was:
. . . taking a range of actions to address major shortcomings in past asset management.

By that they mean housing management. For example, the report referred to the accumulated backlog of maintenance and upgrading of properties at a cost of around $148 million, the difficulties experienced in providing justification required for redevelopment projects in country areas of the state and the practice of holding vacant land parcels unused for periods of up to 20 years.

Whilst the report obviously highlights the inherent weaknesses in past and present management of public housing assets, it also credited the Victorian government with at least examining some of the facts presented and formulating plans to address some of the deficiencies. The Auditor-General's housing report is a concise document which outlines the public housing situation in Victoria without attempting to lay particular blame. It is an independent assessment of a public problem. According to the Victorian Office of the Auditor‐General, and I quote from the report itself:
The Report was well received by the Department of Human Services which generally accepted the audit findings and agreed to consider audit recommendations as part of its public housing strategies.

One would assume from that that the Department of Human Services would use the audit findings to develop its plan of action, but Victoria is a state with a government which cannot handle criticism of any kind. It is a state where the needs of the less advantaged are rarely considered. This is a state government which is obsessed with boosting the needs of big business and which regards as a threat any research which points to deficiencies in its services. It appears to be a government which will take any action to silence its critics.

At about the same time that the Premier first announced his intention to drastically reduce the scrutinising powers of the Auditor‐General, he also announced a major restructure of the management of housing for people on low incomes in Victoria. As part of the new housing plan, responsibility for crisis accommodation would be centralised and offered up for tender by private contractors. Sweeping changes would be made to tenancy laws in the state which would render security in public housing pretty well a thing of the past. People on waiting lists for public housing would be subjected to an even stricter set of eligibility criteria. Most significantly, funding for many of the most active and, need I say, vocally critical housing advocacy groups in Victoria would be slashed.

These two events may not be directly related, but I think they are further evidence of the state government's campaign to silence any group which would dare to speak out about government policy or action, whether it be community groups, housing advocacy groups or the Office of the Auditor-General.

A week or so ago, the Victorian state government announced its long awaited plan for the future role of the Auditor‐General. As of July next year, all public sector and financial audits are to be contracted out. The present Office of the Auditor-General will be disbanded and the majority of the 151 staff members will move to the new audit body—Audit Victoria. Audit Victoria will compete with private accountancy firms for the audit work of government departments and statutory bodies.

I would suggest that this decision spells disaster for any semblance of government accountability in Victoria. Our independent Auditor-General has, to all intents and purposes, become redundant. I suggest that the federal government ought to be very concerned about this situation.

One of the inherent contradictions within state government departments in the management of the public housing stock is that those who manage the stock are also landlords and it is their responsibility to act on any deficiencies. If the department is seriously concerned about addressing the shortfalls in public housing management, then it really needs to have a critical look at its own policies and priorities in allocating and managing funds. Rather than take this more mature approach, however, the state prefers instead to nobble the Auditor‐General and bury the problem of housing management by contracting it out. In other words, shoot the messenger and sweep the problem under the carpet.

The state government claims that the real source of the current crisis in public housing is lack of support by the federal government of course. While the Commonwealth government continues to drag its feet in making any firm commitment to public housing in Australia, the state governments—and I include all state governments—can always find a convenient excuse to push through their own agendas of change and reform and the buck passing goes on.

It is our view that the federal government should be concerned about the developments in Victoria and the implications for the future role of auditors‐general in all other states. In September this year we did warn the government that this would happen and the Democrats proposed amendments to the States Grants (General Purposes) Amendment Bill which would have ensured the continuing independence of the state auditors-general in auditing state government use of Commonwealth funds. But the government and the opposition voted together to have these amendments defeated in the Senate.

I give notice, however, that, whenever a states grants bill comes before the Senate again, the Democrats will again seek support from both major parties to ensure that the independence of state auditors‐general are maintained and, hopefully, strengthened. Hopefully, both the government and the ALP will eventually have the sense to vote in favour of our amendments and protect the taxpayers' money from that lack of accountability which will occur if we do not ensure that auditors‐general are independent.

The auditor-general is the only formal body left which can provide an honest and impartial analysis of how government resources are allocated and managed in each state. He or she is not obligated by political or social allegiances to say the right things to the right people. It is a truly unique position of being able to tell the truth. We need the auditor-general to be independent so he or she can expose the problems to tell the public, to tell the governments and oppositions and minor parties such as ourselves what is really going on in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —Last month I spoke in the Senate about the unsatisfactory conduct of a major oil company in this country, Mobil, and in particular the unsatisfactory conduct of Mobil towards constituents of mine by the name of Boundy and their company which had operated under an agency agreement with Mobil, that company being Air Vision Pty Ltd.

SPEECH.PARA: In response to my speech in the Senate, Mobil wrote me a letter, the contents of which I can summarise very quickly. In that letter they denied the things that I had said in this place. They claimed in fact that they had made an offer of $450,000 which had been rejected by Air Vision and that they had not breached the Oilcode. In fact, they claimed that they had completed their obligations under Oilcode. They also deny, of course, the central reason why the Boundys increased their borrowings to increase their working capital, which was that there was an agreement between them and Mobil in relation to the possible expansion of operations at Sydney airport. I have now received, and I seek leave to table in this place, a very full and detailed letter written to me by APADA dated 21 October which deals with some of the inaccuracies in Mobil's statement.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Honourable senators reading this letter will note that there are a number of glaring errors. Maybe they are not errors; maybe they are deliberate inaccuracies in what Mobil has argued.

BREAK.PARA: First of all, let me draw the attention of honourable senators to Mobil's offer of $450,000 which was made to Air Vision Pty Ltd. Mobil made this offer after the recommendation of the conciliator was suspended on the production of further evidence. In other words, when it became obvious to Mobil that there was further damning evidence against them, then and only then did they make an offer in line with the conciliator's original recommendation. But at that point the conciliator was already looking at further evidence which, in his own letter which I have tabled in this place, he suggested could have substantially increased the amount of the recommendation which he would have made.

It is a matter of record that the conciliator could not make that recommendation. Why? Because Mobil withdrew themselves from the Oilcode process. They did so to frustrate the Boundys and to frustrate their attempt to get justice. One can only but note with dismay the fact that the Boundys were forced to produce information such as diary records and so on at a late stage because they were of the belief that Mobil was going to play fair, that they were going to play the game. They were playing a game, of course, but it was not the game that the Boundys thought they were playing. In fact, it was a game where the rules were written by Mobil for Mobil. Mobil showed a high disdain for the rights of my constituents.

It is interesting to note that Mobil say that they did not suggest to the Boundys that they would take over the operations at Sydney airport. Mobil in fact say, `Well we did not have the oil contract at Sydney airport.' That is, in fact, correct. They did not. But Mobil said to the Boundys that this was a matter of great confidentially. Mobil said to the Boundys, `We believe it is a good thing if you purchase a flat close to Sydney airport, but do not put it in your name and do not put it in the name of the company because this is key to the confidentiality of what we are proposing to do at Sydney airport.'
