You see, Mobil wanted the Boundys to be their pawns, wanted them to do their work, and then when Mobil changed their mind, they used that secrecy argument to say, `Look, we never had any operation there.' Of course they did not, but they were planning to have an operation there. The Boundys were used by Mobil as pawns in their plan and then cruelly dumped when it was not of interest or of benefit to Mobil to use them.

There is further evidence of Mobil's intentions in this regard. This relates to a mission statement which was made about the time that Air Vision entered into an enterprise bargaining agreement at Mobil's insistence. That mission statement made reference to expanding the operations of Air Vision and Mobil to other airports, most notably Sydney airport.

I am concerned that Mobil take the view that they have fulfilled their obligations. In particular, a key part of Mobil's argument is that they have fulfilled their obligations because the Oilcode process was complete. Let me make this very clear: the Oilcode process was not complete. The Oilcode process could only be complete when either a compromise was reached or a recommendation was rejected or accepted.

Not one of these three possible outcomes occurred. There was no compromise because Mobil never intended to have a compromise. A recommendation was made, but it was neither accepted nor rejected by Air Vision for the simple reason that, at the time at which that offer lapsed, Air Vision had asked for further conciliation so that the conciliator could give consideration to the further information that they had made available—in particular, the diary notes. In fact, if the Oil Code process was complete, why did the conciliator say in his letter—a letter which I have tabled in this place—that Mobil withdrew from the Oil Code process; that Mobil in fact prevented him from making a further recommendation?

There was no agreement, there was no compromise; no offer was accepted and no offer was rejected. Air Vision were entirely within their rights to ask that full consider ation be given to all of the evidence to support their case. Quite clearly the people who are in the wrong here are Mobil, because they withdrew from the process when the process did not suit them.

In a letter dated 16 October, Mobil have said to me that they acted at all times within the letter and spirit of existing and proposed legislation, so there can be no change in their position. If that is the case, then I challenge Mobil. I say to them: go back, comply with the requests of the conciliator and allow the Oil Code to reach a conclusion. Allow the conciliator to further consider the evidence before him and make a revised recommendation.

I do not know what that recommendation will be. I have my strong suspicions that it will not be to Mobil's liking. But, if they are truly interested in the Oil Code process, they will go back to the conciliator and say, `Right, we will comply with your requests and we will then see what recommendation you have to make.' At that point the ball will not be in Mobil's court; the obligation to complete this process will lie with Air Vision.

What do Mobil have to lose? If Mobil have played within the spirit and letter of this process, Mobil have nothing to lose. If they have dealt with my constituents fairly and honourably and decently, Mobil have nothing to lose. If Mobil are right and my constituents are wrong, Mobil have nothing to lose and nothing to fear.

But if any one of those premises is not true, if Mobil have not played fairly, if Mobil have not treated my constituents honestly and fairly and decently, then Mobil will prove that by their unwillingness to go back to the conciliator and see this process to a fair and just conclusion. Mobil will stand condemned by their inaction if they fail to do the honourable thing.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 26 May 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the following regulatory regimes on investment be supported under the MAI: (a) the Foreign Investment Review Board; (b) Australian laws limiting overseas investment or cross‐ownership, such as media cross‐ownership laws; (c) laws regulating investments themselves, such as the regulations requiring a certain level of Australian content in television; and (d) any manufacturing regime requiring a minimum Australian content or requiring reinvestment of profits in this country.
(2) If they are not explicitly supported, are any of the regulatory regimes in (1) likely to be challenged under the MAI.
(3) What provisions will the Government demand to ensure that nations can impose environmental and labour standards on investment.

(4) (a) What provisions will the Government demand to ensure that transnational investment in developing nations involves providing a living wage to workers, that investment is not exploitative, utilising child, bonded or prison labour, and does not involve unsustainable environmental practices; and (b) will there be any standards relating to investment.

(5) (a) What provisions will the Government demand to ensure that nations concerned with ecological sustainability or social welfare, or with the actions of totalitarian regimes or regimes suppressing organised workers, can act against companies exploiting such workers or nations; and (b) what freedom will there be within a nation to act against other nations, companies or products.

(6) What consideration has the Government given, and what position has or will it take in negotiation, in relation to the impact of the MAI on measures such as the sanctions against Burma, or against companies investing in Burma.

(7) What consideration has the Government given, and what position has or will it take in negotiation, in relation to the impact of the MAI on measures such as the United States' Corrupt Practices Act, and the United Nations' and Australia's own legal or regulatory attempts to govern corrupt practices by companies involved in bribery of foreign officials to facilitate overseas foreign investment.

(8) What consideration has the Government given, and what position has or will it take in negotiation, in relation to the impact of the MAI on measures such as the formulation of codes of environmental conduct for corporations and companies which operate in Australia, in relation to their operations in developing nations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Assistant Treasurer

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The Government re‐affirmed Australia's continuing support for an MAI at the May 1997 OECD Ministerial Council Meeting. The Government endorses the objectives of an MAI and looks forward to the development of a MAI providing a strong and comprehensive framework for international investment, thus enhancing the role international capital flows play in contributing to improving economic well‐being.

Much of the detail of the proposed treaty remains to be negotiated. It is important to note that the MAI will provide scope for country positions to be covered by reservations. Australia's approach to the MAI negotiations is to seek to ensure that Australia can maintain its current policy stance in relation to the coverage of the MAI, including foreign investment policy. Any international treaty that Australia joins also needs to take account of the limitations imposed by Australia's Commonwealth/State arrangements as provided for under the constitution.

(3), (4), (5) and (8) Australia supports the development of internationally accepted core labour standards. The International Labour Organisation (ILO) is the appropriate forum for pursuing such matters, a view shared by many other OECD countries. The Government will continue to work multilaterally through the ILO and the United Nations to encourage adherence to and observance of core labour standards. The Government does not see value in including matters relating to the development and enforcement of labour standards in international instruments governing the conduct of trade and investment activities, including the MAI.

On the MAI and environmental protection, the Government's view is that the MAI must be consistent with the basic principle of the need for investment liberalisation to be mutually supportive of environment protection in order to promote ecologically sustainable development. The MAI has the potential to promote international ecologically sustainable development through the transfer of technology and environmental management expertise and more efficient international allocation of resources. The negotiations are at an early stage on this issue and a consultation process with non governmental organisations regarding the MAI has been put in place by the OECD. Australia supports suitable non‐mandatory provisions in the MAI on codes of practice in the environment protection area. It is important that the MAI not prevent signatories from continuing to work together in other forums to promote environmental, or other important public policy interests.
(6) The scope of the MAI in relation to the basic issue of extra‐territorial action is yet to be determined. The Government is continuing to monitor developments on this important issue.

(7) A convention aimed at criminalising the bribery of foreign public officials is being negotiated in the OECD, separate to the MAI negotiations. The intention at this stage is for the convention to be open for signature by the end of 1997. The precise text of the convention is still being negotiated and, once it is finalised, the Government will give serious consideration to acceding to it.

(3) (a) When was this proposal first announced; and (b) why has the matter been unresolved for so long.
(4) Is the Treasurer aware that many councils in Queensland, for example, are due to decide whether to corporatise or commercialise their business operations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Assistant Treasurer

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission: Media Monitoring Services

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, upon notice, on 28 July 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What was the total cost of media monitoring services, including press clippings, electronic media transcripts etcetera, provided to the minister's office in the 1996‐97 financial year.
(2) Which agency or agencies provided these services.
(3) What was the total cost of media transcripts etcetera, provided to the department and its agencies in the 1996‐97 financial year.
(4) Which agency or agencies provided these services.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission has provided the following information in response to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: My office receives a copy of the ATSIC press clippings each week day. However, the cost of these and any media transcripts sought by my office are met by the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet which has answered questions (1) and (2) separately.

ATSIC itself generally uses the services of two agencies i.e. Media Monitors and Rehame Australia, through the Commission's Office of Public Affairs (OPA) in Central Office as well as through some of the State Offices i.e. NSW, Victoria, WA and SA. The remaining States QLD, Tas and the NT rely on Central Office press clippings and transcripts.

The total amount spent on the services highlighted in the 1996‐97 financial year was $92,026.45, comprising $80,450.45 for services provided by Media Monitors and $11,576 for services provided by Rehame Australia. On balance, Media Monitors provided the bulk of such services to ATSIC including the daily press clippings.

All of the $11,576 paid to Rehame came from Central Office. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 1 August 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are foreign investment finances for the Earl Hill north and south developments in Cairns, Queensland, secured by `on-shore' finances, and/or are finances conditionally guaranteed to be available `off-shore'.

(2) (a) What are the Government's terms and conditions for approval of the project with respect to foreign investment; and (b) if foreign investment is withdrawn, or is no longer available, how will the Government ensure that the project is to proceed.

(3) Are finance delays permitted under the Foreign Investment Review Board rules once the project; (a) has commenced; (b) is committed to a point where potential serious environmental harm exists; and (c) where delay has the potential to cause adverse social impacts and outcomes on or for local communities.
(4) What are the Government's contingency plans if the project is stalled or fails due to withdrawal of finances.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Assistant Treasurer

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) , (2) (b) & (4) The financing of the Earl Hill Project is a commercial matter for the parties. Similarly, it is for the parties to determine if the project is to proceed, once all the necessary regulatory approvals have been obtained.

(2) (a) & (3) Under the Government's foreign investment policy, the acquisition by foreign interests of residential/resort development sites is normally approved subject to a specific condition requiring construction or redevelopment to commence within 12 months of approval. Fulfilment of this development condition does not relieve foreign interests from having to comply with State and local government requirements.

The Government approved the parties' involvement in the Earl Hill project in July 1995. The parties were advised that there were no objections to the proposal under the Government's foreign investment policy, subject to the parties commencing development by 31 July 1996. However, the time limit for commencing development may be extended in instances where the parties experience delays in obtaining the relevant State and local government approvals for the project, which has occurred in relation to this proposal. The Government's approval of this project was also subject to environ mental conditions. Monitoring of these environmental conditions is the responsibility of the Queensland Department of Environment and Heritage.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 20 August 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that solar hot water storage tanks are subject to sales tax at a rate of 11 per cent.
(2) What is the total value of the sales tax levied on solar hot water storage tanks each year.
(3) Given that the storage tank accounts for about half the cost of a solar hot water system and is an integral and essential part of the system, why is sales tax payable on the tank.

(4) Is it a fact that goods which are used for generation or storing gas or electricity in residential premises in remote area power systems are exempt from sales tax when goods for storing the hot water generated by a solar system are not.

(5) Will the Government remove the sales tax on solar hot water storage tanks, consistent with the exemption applied to other components of the solar system, and thereby boost the market for solar hot water heating and help reduce a significant source of greenhouse gas emissions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Assistant Treasurer

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Solar hot water tanks of a kind ordinarily installed as fixtures in domestic premises are subject to sales tax at the rate of 12%.

(2) The total value of sales tax levied on solar hot water storage tanks each year is not able to be quantified, in part because sales tax payment forms do not separate out the amount of tax paid on these items.

(3) The sales tax law provides sales tax exemption for goods of a kind ordinarily used for collecting, absorbing or concentrating the sun's rays for the purpose of using them as a source of heat. As solar hot water storage tanks do not satisfy these criteria they do not qualify for sales tax exemption.

(4) The sales tax law provides sales tax exemption for machinery, implements or apparatus for use mainly in the generation or storage, or generation and storage, of electricity or gas. The law also requires that the use must happen while the machinery, implements or apparatus is installed as a fixture in residential premises. Goods used for storing hot water generated by a solar system are subject to sales tax.
(5) The taxation of solar hot water storage tanks is consistent with the taxation of other hot water storage units.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 4 September 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to an incident that occurred 25 years ago, on 8 September 1972, in which pilot Max Price and co‐pilot Brenda Hean, intending to fly to Canberra to plead that Lake Pedder not be flooded, disappeared (due to the inactivation of an emergency beacon the plane should have carried) and were presumed dead when their Tiger Moth, which took off from Hobart airport, never arrived resulting in significant allegations at the time that the hangar and plane had been tampered with, and that the subsequent police investigation was unduly limited:
(1) Has any Commonwealth agency investigated any aspects of this incident, at the time or subsequently; if so, which agencies and what was the nature of the investigation.
(2) Will the Minister release any documents held by the Commonwealth relating to the incident.
(3) Will the Minister re-open the investigation into the disappearance and/or co-operate if the Tasmanian authorities do so.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Development has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am advised that the then Department of Transport produced an aircraft accident investigation summary report and a copy of this report is attached.
(2) See answer to (1).
(3) I am unaware of any reason to reopen the investigation.
Attachment
Reference AS/723/1035
Aircraft Accident Investigation Summary Report
1. Location of Occurrence
Probably between Eddystone Point, Tasmania and Flinders Island
Height—Not Known
Date 8.9.72
Time—Not Known
Zone—Est
2. The Aircraft
Make and Model—De Havilland DH82A "Tiger Moth"
Registration—VH‐AQL
3. Conclusions

(i) On 8 September, 1972, a De Havilland DH82A aircraft registered VH-AQL, disappeared whilst on a private travel flight from Cambridge, Tasmania, to Flinders IsLand, in Bass Strait. No trace has been found of the aircraft or its occupants.

(ii) The pilot, Maxwell Henry Price, aged 58, held a valid commercial pilot licence which was endorsed for the aircraft type His recorded flying experience was 1, 968 hours of which 962 hours had been gained on DH82 type aircraft.
(iii) The only passenger was Brenda Mary Hean and she occupied the rear cockpit.
(iv) The pilot was the holder of the Certificate of Registration for the aircraft.
(v) The Certificate cf Airworthiness for the aircraft was valid until 9 November, 1975.
(vi) There is no evidence to suggest that the gross weight of the aircraft or its centre of gravity were not within safe limits.

(vii) The aircraft was fitted with an auxiliary fuel tank and approval had been obtained for the installation of a smoke generating system for use in sky writing operations. The owner/pilot, however, had integrated these two installations in a way which was not approved and would not have been approved by the Department on safety grounds. Thus, during this fight and arising from this situation there were potential hazards such as of undetected fuel loss or of fire in flight but there is no evidence that these or any other hazardous flight situations which could be related to this installation actually occurred or contributed to the disappearance of the aircraft.

(viii) The pilot submitted a night plan to the Hobart Flight Service Unit for a Right expected to commence at 1030 hours from Cambridge to Yarram, Victoria, with an intermediate landing at Flinders Island aerodrome. The plan Indicated that the night would be made in accordance with the Visual Flight Rules at altitudes below 5000 feet and that the pilot did not intend to report his progress by radio en route. The estimated time interval to Flinders Island was 160 minutes and the aircraft s total endurance was shown as 250 minutes. The plan indicated that the pilot would report to Flinders Island Flight Service Unit before 1400 hours EST.

(ix) There is no record of the pilot having requested or received a meteorological forecast before departure. The current area forecast indicated that the weather on the planned route would be suitable for the flight, and a post-flight analysis of reports and observations made in the area confirmed that the weather was substantially as forecast. There is nothing to indicate that weather was a factor in the disappearance of the aircraft.

(x) The night plan Indicated that the aircraft would carry life-jackets, first aid equipment and a VHF (Very High Frequency) survival beacon There is evidence that the VHF survival beacon was not carried on the flight and that the life-Jackets were not worn by the occupants but were stowed behind the rear seat.
(xl) The aircraft departed Cambridge at 1016 hours and, one minute later, the pilot made an on-course radio report to Hobart Control Tower. No further transmissions were heard from the aircraft.

(xii) At 1400 hours, when the pilot had not reported his arrival at Flinders Island, the Flight Service Officer on duty at the aerodrome commenced checking possible alternative landing places in the area. These checks failed to estab lish the whereabouts of the aircraft and search and rescue procedures were initiated at 1430 hours.

(xiii) An intense air, sea and land search was conducted over a period of twenty days and the search was continued on a reduced scale for a further twenty-nine days During this whole period a total of 374 hours 36 minutes were flown by search aircraft and 105 sighting or hearing reports were evaluated. The weight of the evidence indicates that the aircraft proceeded in a northerly direction along the east coast of Tasmania to Eddystone Point where it headed seaward in the direction of Cape Barren and Flinders Islands. The last reported sighting, by a witness at Eddystone Point, indicates that the aircraft was then flying at an altitude of about 2,000 feet and appeared to be operating normally.

(xiv) It was the normal practice of the pilot, when carrying fuel in the aircraft s auxiliary tank, to conduct the take-off with the main tank selected and then change to the auxiliary tank when established in cruise flight. He would then run the auxiliary tank completely dry, allowing the fuel supply to the engine to be interrupted, before re-selecting the main tank. Calculations based on the aircraft s estimated fuel consumption and probable en-route wind velocities suggest that, had the pilot followed his usual procedure on this flight, the auxiliary tank would have become exhausted in the Banks Strait area, between Eddystone Point and Cape Barren Island,
4. Opinion as to Cause
The reason for the failure of the aircraft to reach its destination has not been determined.
Approved for publication—Frank E Yeend

ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Resources and Energy

(3) See response provided by my colleague the Minister for the Environment, Senator the Hon Robert Hill to question on notice 874.
(4) See response provided by my colleague the Minister for the Environment, Senator the Hon Robert Hill to question on notice 874.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 23 September 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In relation to the National Plantations Strategy Co-ordinator: (a) who is the employer or who is contracting the co-ordinator, and to whom are they accountable; (b) where will their office be located; (c) what is the total cost of his/her employment, including salary, on-costs, administrative support, and operating costs; (d) from which portfolio and program are these costs to be met; and (e) is any money from the Natural Heritage Trust being used to fund the position.

(2) In relation to the "2020 Vision": (a) what is the timeframe and budget for this strategy, in total and annually; (b) where is the money coming from (please itemise the contributions from each state and territory, the Commonwealth, industry and other); (c) from which portfolio and program is any Commonwealth funding being allocated; and (d) is any money from the Natural Heritage Trust being used to fund the 2020 Vision, either from the Commonwealth, or States or Territories.
(3) Will clearing of native vegetation be prohibited for any plantation establishment or expansion funded or facilitated through the 2020 Vision.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Resources and Energy

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) The National Plantations Strategy Co-ordinator will be employed by a Standing Committee on Forestry (SCF) member agency or major industry body on behalf of SCF and industry, and will work under the direction of a board of management, consisting of representatives of Commonwealth and State governments on SCF, and the National Association of. Forest Industries, Plantations Australia and Australian Forest Growers

(b) The location of the co-ordinator's office is flexible. The coordinator is a national position and the successful applicant could be located in any capital city or major plantation region, as appropriate.

(c) The salary component for one year will be up to $73 000. The remainder of the costs will be subject to negotiations with the successful applicant. Administrative support costs are expected to be in the order of $50 000. Operating costs are expected to be in the order of $20 000.
(d) The co-ordinator is to be jointly funded by the Commonwealth, State agencies and Industry.
(e) No.

(2) (a) In 1997-98, the Commonwealth will contribute towards the costs of the National Plantations Strategy Co-ordinator, the launch of the 2020 Vision and a national workshop The Commonwealth contribution for these activities will come from the running costs of the Primary Industries and Energy portfolio. Commonwealth funding for future years has yet to be

(b) With respect to Commonwealth funding, see (a). we are not aware of the details of State, Territory and industry budgets. The Ministerial Council on Forestry, Fisheries and Aquaculture agreed that the Commonwealth, State/Territory Governments and industry will contribute to an initial budget of $100 000 (to be shared equally, one third each from the Commonwealths State/Territory Governments and industry) for the immediate implementation of the 2020 Vision.
(c) Commonwealth funding is expected to be allocated from the running costs of the Primary Industries and Energy portfolio.

(d) The Natural Heritage Trust (NHT) and the 2020 Vision are two separate Initiatives. The eligibility criteria for NHT funding are not linked to the 2020 Vision Initiative. However, there is some commonality between the objectives of elements of the NHT program and 2020 Vision actions. For example, action 5 (ensuring research and development is nationally coordinated and strategic), action 23 (promoting the natural resource management benefits of commercial trees, particularly in marginal areas) and action 24 (funding research and development on the natural resource management benefits of commercial trees, particularly in marginal areas), are consistent with the objectives agreed for the NHT.

(3) Under the Australian constitution, matters relating to clearing of native vegetation are the responsibility of State, Territory and local governments. The Commonwealth does not intend to provide funding for the establishment of plantations.

QUESTION.PARA: Given that calls from electorate offices are charged to the Commonwealth at the STD rate, instead of being a free call to the relevant airline, what will be the cost of this change.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 25 September 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the Federal Government make it possible for the National Network of Adult and Adolescent Children who have a Mentally Ill Parent (NNAAMI) to have representation on federal bodies such as the national mental health working group, health ministers advisory panels, federal mental health branch advisory bodies or policy review.

(2) With reference to a reply from the Minister to NNAAMI dated 31 October 1996, which advised that copies of NNAAMI's submission were sent to all State and Territory mental health branches, and that encouraged them to ensure that future planning of services include the needs of children of parents with a mental illness:
As this has not occurred to date, what does the Minister propose to do to ensure that the future needs of these adult and adolescent children are met.

(3) What proportion of the $28 million allocated to the implementation of the second National Mental Health Strategy/Plan will be allocated directly from the Federal Mental Health Branch to NNAAMI so they can set up a 24 hour counselling/support/ advice line, outreach support services, a referral source for psychiatric staff, youth workers, family agencies and protective workers and community education programs.
(4) Will the Federal Government provide funding for NNAAMI to initiate a national peak organisation co‐ordinating body; if so, when.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health and Family Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Input from NNAAMI on issues affecting its constituency will continue to be sought as appropriate.

(2) The responsibility for planning and delivery of services for special needs groups rests with the State and Territory governments. The draft second National Mental Health Plan, which is due to be considered shortly by health ministers, identifies children of parents with a mental illness as one of the specific groups warranting attention.

(3) National funding under the National Mental Health Strategy is generally not allocated for service provision along the lines outlined in the question. As noted in (2) above, children of parents with a mental illness are likely to be identified as a specific group warranting attention and thus national funding for relevant development projects will be considered.
(4) No. The Government is currently involved in a process to create a national peak body for mental health.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 26 September 1997:

BREAK.PARA: (1) What is the nature of such a defence partnership.

(2) Has the Government had any discussions with the PNG Government or does it have any plans or proposals to: (a) increase arms transfers; (b) increase equipment transfers; (c) increase personnel training; or (d) increase defence exercises between the Australian and PNG Governments.
(3) Is it the Government's intention to fill the gap made by the withdrawal from the Sandline mercenary operation in PNG.
(4) Does the Australian Government believe in defence cooperation/military aid to assist the PNG Government to win the war on Bougainville.
(5) Would the Government guarantee with any increased defence relationship that the PNG Government would not use this enhanced defence relationship to fight the war on Bougainville; if not, why not.

(6) Why is the Government planning to increase the defence relationship with PNG when there is no peace on Bougainville and when there is a potential for the defence relationship to be misused and inflict human rights abuse.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Minister for Defence met with the PNG Minister for Defence, the Hon Mao Zeming MP, on 22 October 1997 to discuss the bilateral defence relationship and sign a Joint Statement on the New Defence Partnership. The key principles of the New Defence Partnership, as outlined in the Joint Statement, are mutual interest, openness and transparency, mutual respect, achievable goals, and support for democratic and constitutional processes. Under the New Defence Partnership the primary joint activities will focus on strategic planning, management, and fundamental military skills, including leadership and discipline.
(2) (a) There are no current plans to increase arms transfers to PNG. Any proposal to export lethal goods to PNG would be subject to normal defence export controls.

(b) As part of the Short Term Package announced by the Minister for Foreign Affairs during his visit to PNG in August, 1500 sets of field uniforms and personal equipment are being provided to the PNG Defence Force. Generally, however, the focus of activities under the New Defence Partnership is on strengthening the human element of the PNG defence organisation, particularly through training and development of personnel.

(c) Under the New Defence Partnership, Australia is prepared to offer increased levels of training for the PNG defence organisation. The training offered will focus on priorities of strategic plan ning, management and fundamental military skills, including leadership and discipline. These priorities have been mutually agreed between Australia and PNG.

(d) In line with the New Defence Partnership, exercises involving the PNG and Australian Defence Forces may increase. Exercises are important activities which play a key role in developing mutual understanding, exchanging skills, and promoting interoperability between participating defence forces. Any increase in exercise activity would be subject to agreement with PNG.

(3) No. The Australian Government's position on the engagement of Sandline mercenaries has been made abundantly clear on many occasions. The Australian Government was greatly concerned to learn that the previous Papua New Guinea government intended to use mercenaries on Bougainville. The Australian Government's position is that any attempt to use mercenaries to impose a military solution would only have worsened the situation on Bougainville.

(4) (5) and (6) The Government does not accept the implication that it needs to choose between a defence relationship with PNG and support for the Bougainville peace process. A stable and secure PNG remains of fundamental importance to Australia and we will not walk away from the relationship. We will continue to seek to develop the professionalism, discipline, and basic military and leadership skills of the PNGDF, through training and personnel assistance provided as part of the New Defence Partnership. This approach is consistent with our strategic interests, and with the Government's continuing support of efforts to encourage a peaceful resolution of the Bougainville conflict and minimise the potential for human rights violations.

The Australian Government believes that a negotiated settlement is required to secure a lasting peace on Bougainville. In this context, the Government welcomes recent positive developments in the Bougainville peace process through the Burnham talks in New Zealand.

A major outcome of the Burnham II talks was the Burnham Truce, a document which has been signed by the Commander PNG Defence Force, as well as BRA/BIG leaders. While a final settlement remains subject to further dialogue between the parties involved, the resumption of dialogue and announcement of the truce are positive developments in the Bougainville peace process.
The Australian Defence Force played a key role in facilitating the Burnham II talks by providing transport for Bougainvillean delegates.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 1 October 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware of the work conducted by the National Network of Adult and Adolescent Children who have a Mentally Ill Parent (NNAAMI).
(2) Has the Minister received any requests for funding from NNAAMI.

(3) Is it true that people with mentally ill parent(s) are not currently represented on any national mental health working group, health ministers advisory panel, federal mental health branch advisory body or policy review board.
(4) Does the Minister acknowledge a need for NNAAMI to have representation on such a body.
(5) Will the Federal Government make it possible for NNAAMI to have representation on such a body.
(6) Is the Minister aware of the funding needs of NNAAMI.
(7) Will the Federal Government provide funding to allow the group to initiate a national peak organisation coordinating body, which would implement counselling/support services for its clients.
(8) Will funds allocated to the implementation of the Second Mental Health Strategy be available to NNAAMI; if so, how much.
(9) Is the Minister aware of the lack of services for, and subsequent isolation of, people (children and adults) who have at least one mentally ill parent.
(10) Is the Minister aware that no State Government has provided funding assistance to NNAAMI, despite the group's large clientele.
(11) Is the Minister aware of the high suicide risks involving children and adults who have at least one mentally ill parent.
(12) Would the Federal Government consider including the needs of NNAAMI in federal suicide prevention initiatives.
(13) Will NNAAMI receive a draft copy of the Second National Mental Health Strategy before it becomes public.
(14) Will NNAAMI be given the opportunity to comment on the final draft of this document before it is ratified by the Federal Government.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health and Family Services has provided the follow ing answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. I have received several representations from NNAAMI.

(2—6) Yes. As the proposal focused on service delivery which is the responsibility of the State and Territory governments, it was forwarded to all State and Territory directors of mental health on 15 January 1997 for their consideration.
(3—5) NNAAMI is not specifically represented on current bodies.

There are many organisations representing components of the mental health sector. It is not possible for them all to be represented on national mental health bodies. Where appropriate, NNAAMI has been invited to express its views on issues affecting its constituency such as at the Workshop on Children's and Young People's Mental Health held in Melbourne in April 1996.

(7) No. As an alternative to funding a number of organisations representing small segments of the mental health sector, the Government is involved in a process to establish a single national peak body for mental health which is representative of the whole mental health sector.

(8) Funding under the National Mental Health Strategy is generally not allocated for ongoing service provision such as that planned to be undertaken by NNAAMI. During the consultations for the development of the Second National Mental Health Plan, children of parents with a mental illness were identified as a specific group warranting attention. National funding for specific projects will be determined following consideration of the Second Plan by health ministers.

(9) I am aware that this group is one of those at higher risk of developing mental health and related problems. It is for this reason that children of parents with a mental illness have been identified for particular attention under the Second National Mental Health Plan.
(11) I am aware that the research literature suggests a slightly higher than average risk of suicide for children with at least one parent with a mental illness.

(12) The $31 million funding allocated to the National Youth Suicide Prevention Strategy (NYSPS) is already committed on projects, many of which encompass suicide prevention services which people with a mentally ill parent could access.
(13) The Second National Mental Health Plan will be released following consideration by Commonwealth and State Health Ministers in November 1997.
(14) I am advised that NNAAMI made a written submission which was considered in the development process of the draft Second National Mental Health Plan.

(3) In each instance, which firm or firms have been engaged to undertake this work.
(4) In each instance, what has been the cost of the work undertaken.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, without notice, on 22 September 1997 (Official Hansard page 6557):

QUESTION.PARA: Is the structure and financing of Sydney's eastern distributor similar to that of the M2.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Assistant Treasurer

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following information in response to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Both of these projects form part of the NSW road network, for which that State has responsibility, and I am advised that neither the Department of the Treasury nor the Department of Transport and Regional Development are party to information on the structure and financing of the eastern distributor. However, I understand that the Australian Securities Commission (ASC), a Treasury portfolio agency, does have information on the structure and financing of the eastern distributor, given that it is one of the investments of The Infrastructure Trust of Australia Group, which is a listed entity. That entity lodged a prospectus with the ASC in October 1996 and also discloses under the continuous disclosure obligations applying to listed entities. With relevant material being publicly available, the honourable senator may care to either access the ASC and/or Australian Stock Exchange databases, or take up this matter with the NSW Government.
